business.start.para: The SPEAKER (Hon. David Hawker) took the chair at 12.30 pm and read prayers.

subdebateinfo.title: 113th Inter-Parliamentary Union Assembly in Geneva and Bilateral Visit to the Republic of Singapore

talk.start.para: —It gives me great pleasure to report to my colleagues on both sides of the House on the 113th Inter-Parliamentary Union Assembly held in Geneva from 16 to 20 October 2005 and a bilateral visit to the Republic of Singapore from 23 to 27 October 2005. I had an outstanding delegation who made an outstanding contribution to the work of the 113th Inter-Parliamentary Union Assembly in Geneva. I was ably supported by the deputy leader, Mrs Julia Irwin, the member for Fowler; Mrs Kay Hull, the member for Riverina; and Ms Annette Ellis, the member for Canberra. They were the elected members of the delegation, but we also had Senator Julian McGauran, from Victoria, who played a very important role in our delegation, although he came to the assembly in a private capacity. We appreciated the contribution that he made to the work of the delegation in Geneva.

speech.para: We were accompanied by Neil Bessell, secretary to the delegation from the Department of the Senate. Both the work that he did to prepare the delegation for this visit and his work during the visit were very capably managed, and we appreciated the assistance that he gave us at all times. Jeremy Kruse, who was the adviser from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, provided excellent advice, sometimes on the run as matters came up that were unforeseen. We appreciated very much his assistance both prior to the delegation’s visit and after it.

The proceedings on this occasion were dominated by the election of a new president of the IPU to replace Mr Paez from Chile, who completed his term of office. We thank Mr Paez for the contribution he has made to the work of the Inter-Parliamentary Union. It was good to see that there was some good competition. There were two very capable candidates: Mr Pier Ferdinando Casini, the Speaker of the Italian parliament, and Mr Geert Versnick from Belgium. Mr Pier Ferdinando Casini was elected as the President of the Inter-Parliamentary Union for the next three years. His term will end in October 2008. They were both excellent candidates. Both had some experience but particularly Mr Versnick, who has had long experience with the IPU. We thank the delegates for their enthusiastic approach to the work of the assembly.

All members of our Australian delegation participated in the various forums of the assembly. Ms Ellis addressed the first committee on ‘The respective roles of the parliaments and the media in providing the public with impartial, accurate and verifiable information, especially on armed conflicts and the struggle against terrorism’—very topical. Mrs Irwin addressed the second committee on ‘Migration and development’, which Mrs Hull also addressed, and Senator McGauran participated in the third committee on ‘The importance of civil society and its interplay with parliaments and other democratically elected assemblies for the maturing and development of democracy’. I addressed the emergency item, ‘Natural disasters: the role of parliaments in prevention, rehabilitation, reconstruction and the protection of vulnerable groups’. My colleague the member for Fowler, the deputy leader, will address the Singapore end of the visit. Of course the whole visit was overshadowed when we arrived in Singapore by the impending death of Mr Nguyen by hanging, but I will leave my colleague to speak to that.

Before finishing, I would like to thank the ambassador, Mike Smith, in Geneva for the great assistance and the hospitality he gave to the delegation. I also thank his staff because certainly they were important in working out the logistics and providing administration and assistance at all times to the delegation. We also hosted a lunch for Mr Lu Congmin, who was leader of the Chinese delegation, and that was a very useful activity. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I support the remarks of the member for Pearce and leader of the delegation. I would add my thanks to Jeremy Kruse from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and our special thanks to Neil Bessell from the Department of the Senate. Neil is always a reliable source of advice and a tireless organiser for IPU delegations.

speech.para: As the member for Pearce has dealt with the proceedings of the IPU conference in Geneva, I will focus on the bilateral visit to Singapore. While the visit was overshadowed by the sentence of Van Nguyen, the delegation, as far as possible, fulfilled the commitments arranged beforehand. Our visit began with a tour of the World War II memorials at the Battlebox at Fort Canning and the Changi Prisoner of War Chapel and the Changi Museum built on the site where 15,000 Australians, captured at the fall of Singapore in 1942, were first interned. It is a solemn site and a stark reminder of the suffering of our service men and women, but it is also a memorial to their unbreakable spirit.

The delegation’s official round of meetings began with a visit to the parliament of Singapore where we met the Speaker and parliamentary members of the Singapore-Australia friendship group. Discussions covered the number of Singaporeans who have studied in Australia and the large number of Australians who have worked in Singapore. The Singaporean Minister for Health informed the delegation of steps being taken in Singapore to deal with bird flu. The leader of the delegation expressed our deep appreciation to the government of Singapore for their assistance in the treatment of Australian victims of the October 2005 Bali bombings.

Later the delegation made a special visit to the Mount Elizabeth Hospital to extend our best wishes to Bali bomb victims Paul and Penelope Anicich prior to their return to Newcastle, and also to thank the staff of the hospital for their assistance. At our meeting with the Economic Development Board, we learned of Singapore’s vision to become a global schoolhouse, and we also had the opportunity to visit the site of the University of New South Wales new Singapore campus.

Singapore is the location of the secretariat of APEC, and the delegation received an informative briefing from senior staff. At meetings with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Defence, the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies, the delegation was briefed on the Five Power Defence Arrangements and efforts to combat terrorism in the region. Free trade and people-to-people exchanges were also discussed and the delegation visited the port of Singapore to see the world’s busiest transhipment hub.

This report would not be complete without mention of the delegation’s efforts to secure clemency for Van Nguyen. On the day before the delegation’s arrival in Singapore, the President had announced that his appeal for clemency had been denied. The issue was raised with members of the Singaporean parliament at formal and informal meetings as well as being directly raised with the acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Defence. The delegation was moved to write to the President of Singapore seeking a review of Van Nguyen’s appeal for clemency.

The delegation left Singapore with heavy hearts, determined to continue to press for clemency, and delegates moved and spoke on the private members’ motion presented to the House on 7 November. In thanking the Australian High Commissioner to Singapore, Miles Kupa, I would also express the delegation’s admiration for and thanks to Second Secretary, Ms Annette Morris. Annette was the main point of contact between Van Nguyen and the Singapore authorities. Members will have seen her familiar and beautiful figure in the television coverage outside Changi prison. Annette was the last person to embrace Van Nguyen, and that was at the time of his arrest. Our thoughts are with Annette at this sad time, as they are with Van Nguyen’s family and friends. Van Nguyen’s execution has left the delegation saddened but very determined to advocate for the abolition of capital punishment in all countries through the Inter-Parliamentary Union and other forums.
In the short time I have left, I would like to thank three great women: the members for Canberra, Pearce and Riverina for their friendship, their courage and their conviction at such a very sad time.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Family and Human Services, I present the committee’s report entitled Overseas adoption in Australia, together with the minutes of proceedings.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

talk.start.para: —It gives me great pleasure to speak on the tabling of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Human Services report Overseas adoption in Australia. The number of adoptions in Australia has declined markedly, from a peak of over 9,000 in 1971-72 to approximately 500 in 2003-04, of which only 73 were domestic adoptions, the remainder being from overseas. This decline appears, in part, to be due to a backlash against the way adoptions were managed between the 1950s and 1970s and the growth of successful IVF births, of which there were 7,000 last year. Fostering and other forms of out-of-home care are now the preferred way for the bureaucracy to place children who need a home.

speech.para: In 2003-04, over 21,000 children were in such care. The pendulum has swung so far that there is now a pervasive anti-adoption culture in the bureaucracy across Australia which spills into the overseas adoption units. Parents face enormous personal and financial challenges to build a family through intercountry adoption and the committee is firmly of the view that adoption is a legitimate way to form families. However, Australia’s per capita rate of intercountry adoption is poor. It is only one-third the rate in most First World countries. The per capita adoption rate in New South Wales is only one-eighth that in the ACT.

The committee has made 27 recommendations in its report, the acceptance of which would make a significant difference in the lives of adopting parents and their children. An important recommendation is that non-government organisations should play a greater role in managing intercountry adoptions. Currently, no NGO is accredited to process intercountry adoptions in Australia, despite the Hague convention setting out guidelines for their establishment. Accrediting NGOs would result in intercountry adoptions being much less of a drain on the resources of community service departments from what they regard as their core business. The New South Wales Department of Community Services told the committee that it regards the 105,000 local children it considers to be at risk in New South Wales to be its core business. Accrediting NGOs would allow the department to focus on these children and improve its adoption service. The committee is pleased to see that New South Wales has at least begun this process by placing an advertisement asking for expressions of interest from NGOs.

The report also recommends that the Commonwealth government should manage the programs with overseas countries of origin. This is a matter of external affairs and thus the Commonwealth, not individual states, should be negotiating new programs and managing existing ones. The committee has combined this recommendation with the proposal that Australia should not limit its intercountry adoption programs to countries that have ratified the Hague convention and has suggested a role for AusAID.

This inquiry has attracted much media interest and has been received as a much needed report. However, the Queensland Minister for Child Safety, the Hon. Mike Reynolds, seems to have missed the point in his media release last week. The minister’s main message was that the Queensland government would postpone the review of its adoption legislation until the Commonwealth has formally responded to the committee’s report. Minister Reynolds has made no commitment to take any action to move on state controlled issues such as reopening their applications for intercountry adoptions, which have been shut now for 12 months. The minister could also devote more resources to processing existing files as well as moving to accredit NGOs to give them what, one must conclude, is much needed help. Any state government can take immediate action in response to this report. I should also add that the committee is happy to cooperate with the Queensland government, or any Australian government—state or federal—in order to progress this report.

Compiling such a report relies on the help of many people. I thank my fellow committee members for the assistance they provided, in particular my deputy chair, Julia Irwin, and Harry Quick, who on his own initiative went to Beijing to see adoption operations first-hand. I also thank the committee secretary, Mr James Catchpole, and all the staff who worked so hard with the committee, and the many individuals and organisations who assisted by making a submission or giving evidence at the hearings. Their expertise and experience are greatly valued and laid a strong foundation for our deliberations. I commend the report to the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I join with the Chair of the Standing Committee on Family and Human Services, the member for Mackellar, in expressing my thanks to the many people, organisations and government agencies who made submissions to and appeared before the inquiry into overseas adoption. This is their report. On one level, this is quite an emotive topic, but at the same time this is a serious task for the agencies charged with the responsibility of ensuring the welfare and safety of vulnerable young children. The committee detected in government agencies an unhelpful attitude towards adoption, although this was typically expressed as a lack of positive action by governments rather than outright opposition. The committee noted that the primary focus of state and territory agencies was children with problems in dysfunctional families.

speech.para: The committee received submissions which dealt with a number of aspects of local adoption. As this was clearly outside the inquiry’s terms of reference, the committee’s consideration of this aspect is included as an appendix. I should point out that, in the interests of presenting a credible report, this section should be viewed as a work in progress rather than a final report. The fact that individuals, organisations and government agencies were not advised, through the terms of reference, that local adoption practices were the subject of the inquiry makes this part of the report unbalanced and incomplete. The only conclusion that can be drawn from the section dealing with local adoption is that further inquiry is warranted.

Coming back to the subject of the report—overseas adoption—the most striking fact for me was the very low number of overseas adoptions. It is hard to see why, as a successful multicultural society, Australia is so close to the bottom of the table of Western countries in its per capita rate of overseas adoption. Countries such as Norway and Sweden have an adoption rate nearly 10 times as high as Australia’s. There can be little doubt that the arduous process of applying for overseas adoption is the main cause of the low rate of overseas adoption in Australia. And the experience of individual parents must discourage other potential adoptive parents. The report quotes Professor Peter Boss of Monash University, who sees the opponents of overseas adoption as being largely the professional groups involved in adoption, such as social workers and psychologists. It is hard to escape the conclusion that professionals who oppose overseas adoption do so for their own moral reasons.

Another issue was children from a different race being raised in an alien culture. But no evidence given to the committee suggested that this presented any major problems, particularly for children adopted at a young age, and many parents who have adopted children from overseas stated that the physical and emotional wellbeing of their child was much improved on the circumstances they endured in their home country.

The committee did not address the question of whether Australians should focus on improving the conditions of all children at risk in overseas countries in preference to encouraging the adoption of a relatively small number. Clearly, that is a matter for individual families to decide. But, having taken that decision, and subject to a process of approval which satisfies the requirements of the country from which the child is adopted and local requirements, the moral question of how best to assist the plight of children at risk should not influence the assessment process.

In the many recommendations of the committee, a greater role for the Commonwealth in overseas adoption appears to be the most effective means of overcoming the states’ bias against overseas adoption. In more immediate terms, the Commonwealth can assist families adopting children from overseas. Families adopting children over the age of two, which is not uncommon, are not eligible for maternity payment. The committee has therefore recommended that the Minister for Family and Community Services remove the age limit for eligibility for maternity payment in relation to adopted children. This measure would provide welcome assistance to many adoptive families. I hope that consideration of that recommendation begins immediately to introduce extended eligibility at the time of the next budget.

I thank very much the staff of the committee secretariat, some of whom are present today, and I especially thank the chair for such a wonderful and interesting inquiry. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —The time allotted for statements on this report has expired. Does the member for Mackellar wish to move a motion in connection with the report to enable it to be debated on a future occasion?

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

talk.start.para: —In accordance with standing order 39, the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

—On behalf of the Standing Committee on Procedure, I present the committee’s report entitled Inquiry into procedures relating to House committees, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

talk.start.para: —In this report the Procedure Committee addresses two issues: the amount of time for statements and debate on committee reports, and the admission of visitors and other members to committee meetings. The committee makes three recommendations. I turn firstly to the time allocated to committee work in the House and the Main Committee. The limited time given to discussion of committee reports has been of continuing interest to the Procedure Committee and a recurring theme in a number of the committee’s reports. The committee found that very limited time is devoted to presentation and statements on, and debate of, committee reports in the House and the Main Committee. During the past two years ended 30 June 2005, only 49 hours were devoted to committee business in the House and the Main Committee. This represented only 3.4 per cent of the available hours of the House and Main Committee during that period. If we look at the House alone, we can see that there was significantly less time. During that two-year period, the House allocated only 19 hours to committee business, and this represented only 1.6 per cent of the sitting hours of the House.

speech.para: To put these figures into context, during that two-year period House and joint committees held more than 1,400 meetings and presented 181 reports. These figures include domestic or internal committees. It is now standard practice for most reports to receive only 10 minutes speaking time in the House following presentation, and only a minority of reports are debated further. Over the past two years, less than 20 per cent of the general purpose standing and joint committee reports presented in the House have been referred to the Main Committee for further debate. The committee found that a factor in the small number of referrals is the timelag between report presentation and debate in the Main Committee. This has been particularly the case more recently.

One of the great bipartisan strengths of the House of Representatives is its committee work. Backbench members put an enormous amount of effort into this work and, on most occasions, it is undertaken in association with the community. The committee considers that the significance of committee work to the House should be reflected more substantially in the time devoted to committee business in the House and the Main Committee. However, there are limited options for change. Members do not favour increased sittings of the House, and they do not wish to reduce the time available in the House to debate private members’ business. However, they do support increasing the meeting hours of the Main Committee.

Accordingly, the committee has recommended that the standing orders be amended on a trial basis during 2006 to allow a dedicated weekly period of 4 pm to 6 pm in the Main Committee on sitting Mondays for the debate of committee and delegation reports. The committee will review the trial in late 2006 so that, if the arrangements are successful, their operation will be ongoing. The amendment will mean that reports presented on Mondays will be able to be debated later that day. Committee members and other interested members will be able to speak on reports for a maximum of 10 minutes each. As to how this will work in practice, as part of their report deliberations the committee will need to agree to seek referral of reports to the Main Committee and to identify members to speak on the reports. Committee chairs will need to write to the Chief Government Whip, seeking referral of the report and specifying the committee members who are to speak on the report, well in advance of report presentation. It would seem convenient to do this at the same time as advice is sent to the Selection Committee about the presentation of the report. The committee stresses that the success of the trial will be dependent on backbench members using the additional time available.

The second issue is attendance at committee meetings by visitors and non-committee members. The particular issue is that the revised standing orders introduced on 16 November 2004 may have inadvertently created some uncertainty about whether committees can admit visitors and non-committee members to some private meetings. The former standing orders excluded visitors and other members from meetings when the committee or subcommittee was deliberating or taking evidence in camera. Under the new standing orders, however, visitors and other members must leave when the committee or subcommittee is conducting a private meeting. Use of the broader term ‘private meeting’ instead of the narrower terms ‘deliberating or taking evidence in camera’ has meant that there is inconsistency in the standing orders as to whether visitors and other members can attend some private committee meetings. To resolve this matter, the committee recommends minor changes to standing orders 240 and 241. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to make some comments about the Standing Committee on Procedure report entitled Inquiry into procedures relating to House committees and also about the value of committees. As the chair explained, the report deals with just two issues: arrangements for presenting committee reports and attendance at committee meetings by visitors. I will comment on visitors at committee meetings first, since it is a relatively simple issue. When the standing orders were being revised and reorganised between 2002 and 2004, one of the underlying values was to rewrite them in plain English. The previous standing orders excluded visitors and members who were not members of the committee when a committee or subcommittee was ‘deliberating or taking evidence in camera’. It was felt that ‘deliberating’ was an outdated word. Similarly, the use of the Latin phrase ‘in camera’ to describe hearings at which the public would be excluded and the evidence taken would not be on the public record was also considered archaic. Consequently, the redrafted standing orders simply state that visitors must leave if the committee or subcommittee is ‘conducting a private meeting’. The exclusion also applies to members of the House who are not members of the committee.

speech.para: As you know, Mr Speaker, committees gather evidence and inform themselves about issues in a wide variety of ways. Some of these might be considered ‘private meetings’ even though they would not have been included in the exclusions intended by the standing orders. In order to avoid any doubt about when visitors should be asked to leave a meeting, the committee now recommends returning to the more precise terminology of a meeting in which a committee or subcommittee is ‘deliberating or hearing witnesses in private’.

That brings me to the more substantive issue addressed in this report—that is, the time of the House devoted to committee business, particularly the presentation of committee reports. In most cases, committees attempt to honour the intention of the standing orders by presenting committee reports during the time allotted for that purpose on Mondays. You will all know that a pattern has arisen in which the Selection Committee allocates 15 minutes per speaker at the time of presenting reports rather than the maximum 10 minutes allowed by the standing orders. Further, it is very common to allow only two speakers per report—generally the chair and deputy chair of the committee. This is a profoundly unsatisfactory state of affairs. It denies the majority of members of a committee the opportunity to speak at the presentation of a report. Even if a motion to take note of a report allows further debate, almost invariably in the Main Committee, this is removed in time from the presentation. Committee members will have moved on to the next big issue and what should be the culmination of their efforts in reporting on an inquiry becomes, instead, an anticlimax.

How has this situation arisen? In 1987, when the House committee system was restructured, it seemed the House was acknowledging the importance of committee work both for the parliament itself and for the members who work so hard at their committee work. Ten years ago much more time was made available for the presentation of each committee report—even acknowledging that there were fewer reports. In the contest for House time between government business, committee business, private members’ business and what used to be termed ‘parliamentary business’, time for committee business has been the big loser. The committee spoke to chairs, deputies and ordinary committee members to try to find a solution to the problem of lack of time for the presentation of and debate on committee reports. The outcome is not entirely satisfactory. The contest for House time is only one of the time management issues facing members. There is also the contest between House sitting time and time for electorate and other priorities.

The committee’s recommendation is for additional report-debating time to be created by having the Main Committee sit from 4 pm to 6 pm on Mondays if required. Members—not necessarily limited to committee members—would have 10 minutes each to speak to a report. If there were no committee or delegation reports to be debated, the Main Committee would not sit at this time. The suggestion is a compromise. It provides additional debating time for reports without impacting on the time members need to be in Canberra. We propose it be introduced as a sessional order, with the committee to review its operation at the end of 2006. I should note that the ‘father of the Procedure Committee’, the Hon. Roger Price, had some additional—indeed innovative—suggestions for adding value to the debate on reports. The committee has not accepted them at this stage. The suggestions appear as additional comments at the end of the report and the committee would welcome feedback on these comments, as well as on the recommendations in the report. I commend the report to the House and I thank all those members who participated—the chairs and deputy chairs of committees and also those who filled in the survey form. That is the way these reports should proceed: with proper consultation so that people are aware of the result. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)—The time allotted for statements on this report has expired. Does the member for McPherson wish to move a motion in connection with the report to enable it to be debated on a future occasion?

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

—On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, I present the committee’s report entitled Detention centre contracts: review of Audit report No. 1, 2005-2006, management of the detention centre contracts—part B, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

talk.start.para: —On 7 July 2005, the Australian National Audit Office, ANAO, released Audit report No. 1 2005-06: Management of the detention centre contracts—part B. This was the second of a three-part assessment of the management by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, DIMIA, of detention centre contracts. The current contract with the service provider Global Solutions Ltd, GSL, was the focus of the second assessment. The committee commends the ANAO’s rigorous and detailed work in conducting this audit and awaits with interest the final report in this series. The committee considers that the inherent vulnerability of the detainee population means that it is essential there be careful monitoring of how DIMIA is managing its detention function. The tabling of Audit report No. 1 2005-06 provided the committee with the opportunity to undertake a focused examination of certain aspects of DIMIA’s detention centre contract management.

speech.para: As members will be aware, DIMIA has come under intense scrutiny this year. Various independent reports and internal reviews have been undertaken into aspects of the department’s immigration detention function. The committee did not wish to duplicate the work of wider inquiries and has not examined Australia’s mandatory detention policy, arrangements for offshore processing or the lawful detainment or otherwise of individuals. The committee’s review focused on certain key issues identified by the ANAO in Audit report No. 1 2005-06 and the action that DIMIA has taken in response to the ANAO’s recommendations. The ANAO made four recommendations for improvement in key areas relating to the detention function: insurance, liability and indemnity; planning, performance information and monitoring arrangements; financial reporting; and the management of Commonwealth equipment and assets.

However, the committee could not consider Audit report No. 1 2005-06 in isolation. The release of the report was followed a week later by the release of the Palmer report, Inquiry into the circumstances of the immigration detention of Cornelia Rau, and the Comrie report in October. Many of the problems identified by the ANAO in its report in relation to the provision of services to detainees, contract management and performance monitoring arrangements were similarly highlighted as problem areas in the Palmer report. The committee held a public hearing on 10 October 2005, with representatives from the ANAO and DIMIA appearing. In evidence to the committee, DIMIA advised that the implementation of the recommendations of the Palmer report of the Inquiry into the circumstances of the immigration detention of Cornelia Rau—also known as the Palmer implementation plan—also included the department’s proposed action to address the ANAO’s recommendations.

The ANAO identified a number of problems with DIMIA’s management of the detention centre contract at the time of review. A recurrent criticism throughout Audit report No. 1 2005-06 is that the standards and performance measures for monitoring GSL’s performance lacked clarity and consistency, which compromised, in ANAO’s view, DIMIA’s ability to monitor GSL and subcontractor performance. The department was initially reluctant to accept this criticism. However, it has since conceded that certain improvements may be possible in this area. The committee shares the ANAO’s view that the nature and complexity of the detention services environment warrants a more proactive approach to performance monitoring to ensure that detainees’ needs are met, there is some degree of quality assurance in the delivery of detention services and agency responsibilities are met.

Linked to this, and of concern to the committee, was the ANAO’s finding that there is ‘insufficient information about the quality of services being delivered and their costs to allow a value-for-money calculation’. It was troubling that DIMIA could not demonstrate whether or not increased investments in contract administration were producing greater levels of operating efficiencies. At an annual cost of $90 million, plus overheads and administrative costs, and with an additional $230 million committed over the course of five years to the Palmer implementation plan, the committee considers it crucial to ensure that adequate financial reporting and measures— (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to table the balance of my statement.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —The public policy decision of the current government was to use private sector contractors to run immigration detention centres, and it is those contracts that are the subject of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration report entitled Detention centre contracts: review of Audit report No. 1, 2005-2006, management of the detention centre contracts—part B. I think this policy has been in place for long enough—indeed, since 1997—to pass judgment on its success or failure. In that time we have had three changes of providers and various reports indicating the performance of those providers and, by implication, DIMIA. There is no doubt that the privatisation of detention services has been a spectacular failure. Its costs for the last financial year now run over $300 million, and it exposes government to elevated risk. ANAO report that $16.9 million has been paid out in compensation since 2000, and there are numerous claims in the pipeline, some of them now notorious. There have been appalling outcomes for detainees—again, the subject of numerous reports—and persistent evidence of a lack of proper oversight and control by the government.

speech.para: No justification for shifting from public to private provision was ever given. It was really an ideological preference. I have searched high and low to find the reasons for the shift and have not found any justification offered by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs at the time or, indeed, the government. I think it was inevitable that the companies that were invited to contract for these detention centres came from the criminal detention sector where privatisation of detention facilities was pioneered. Unfortunately, they brought with them attitudes towards those detained that equated them very often with convicted criminals—certainly that is the way they appear to have treated them from time to time.

Of course, the privatisation necessitated the development of contracts which included agreed outcomes and standards—or at least should have—and apportioned responsibilities between DIMIA and the private providers. What the evidence to date shows, including from ANAO, is that those contracts were poorly designed and managed from the outset. No-one could claim, looking at all the evidence, that the policy of having the private sector run the facilities has been a raging success—indeed, quite the opposite. There have been riots, hunger strikes and the destruction of property. There has been evidence of the use of excess force, the abuse and mistreatment of detainees by guards, inappropriate use of isolation and so on. All in all, there has been a failure to provide adequate care, especially for the mental health needs of detainees. There have been many suicide attempts, numerous incidents of self-harm and endemic depression—all well documented.

We have had major reports by Palmer, Comrie, HREOC and ANAO identifying scandalous inadequacies, both in government and in the private providers. The two most recent major reports from ANAO show continuing weaknesses in the contracts with private providers. The audit findings, which, amongst other things, say—in that particularly bloodless language that is used by auditors—‘The current contract with GSL and associated arrangements do not adequately address best practice for public sector outsourcing and meet the practical operational needs of the detention services delivery function.’ In other words, they are not delivering on the contract. They go on to say:

quote.para: ... the contract does not establish clear expectations for the level and quality of services to be delivered; mechanisms to protect the Commonwealth’s interests are not clear; and there is insufficient information about the quality of services being delivered and their costs to allow a value-for-money calculation.

speech.para: This is a pretty damming assessment. They also go on to say that DIMIA’s ability to monitor the performance of GSL and its subcontractors was compromised—as pointed out by the chair—by the lack of clarity in standards and associated performance measures. So they did not even have a clear view of what should be done. Their reliance on the reporting of incidents to determine when standards are not being met and their limited control over subcontracting arrangements were also mentioned in those audit findings.

This is especially problematic, as the Palmer report vividly illustrates, for health services. We have sub-subcontracting, for instance, for psychological services and little or no accountability. The audit report points out that DIMIA had taken a purely financial view of the provision of psychological services and, in general terms, failed to deliver on the duty of care that was required of them and of the contractors. I think it is time to conclude that the policy of privatising detention centres is a failed policy. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: National Capital and External Territories Committee

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories, I present the committee’s report entitled Norfolk Island financial sustainability—the challenge: sink or swim, incorporating a dissenting report.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

talk.start.para: —This is the second part of an inquiry into governance arrangements for Norfolk Island to be considered in the context of the financial sustainability of the island. There is no doubt that Norfolk Island is a beautiful place. It has cultural and historical heritage which adds to the island’s attractiveness. However, Norfolk Island and its population have some serious issues to deal with. This bipartisan committee report considers all of these issues on the evidence before it, offers up recommendations to address the concerns and, I believe, adds value to Norfolk Island’s future.

speech.para: The island is facing serious concerns about its future financial sustainability. Its isolation, its very limited internal revenue base and its overreliance on a tourism industry that is facing ever increasing competition supports the committee’s view that a renewed direction be adopted. The committee believes that all Australians citizens, irrespective of where they live, deserve competent government administration and service delivery. The island has an ageing population at a rate significantly higher than the rest of Australia.

The committee examined the island’s internal revenue-raising options, and we have considered the ability of the Norfolk Island government to increase expenditure for government services and asset replacement. On the evidence, it is very clear that the challenge has become too great for the Norfolk Island government alone to resolve. The future direction we are recommending will be neither easy nor quick. We are recommending that Norfolk Island should come under the income taxation and welfare systems of the Commonwealth, as is currently the case for the Indian Ocean territories.

The committee stated its preference for the Commonwealth to resume responsibility for social security, health and aged care services, national census and economic statistics collection, immigration, customs and quarantine. Commonwealth law should be applied to Norfolk Island, most particularly in the areas of Corporations Law and trade practices. A range of state type services, insofar as they do not already exist, would also fall under the Commonwealth’s umbrella, including primary and secondary school education, vocational education and training, legal services and the courts, telecommunications, broadcasting, and environment protection. The Commonwealth would also resume responsibility for the funding and upgrade of island infrastructure, including the hospital, roads, the school, power generators, a deep water harbour and the airport.

We believe that a number of significant matters will require management and determination by the Norfolk Island government. A local representative body would be required to assist in providing appropriate services and to lobby on behalf of the Norfolk Island community. The Norfolk Island government and its administration, we believe, are best placed in this regard.

As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, being a member of this committee, the committee has worked long and hard on this report. As I said, this is the second of a two-part inquiry—the first part into governance and the second into financial sustainability—on behalf of the people of Norfolk Island. Many people on the island came forward to the committee in a very open and honest way and presented their views to the committee as best they could. It was very evident to the overwhelming majority of the committee and in this bipartisan report that something needs to be done to ensure the future of Norfolk Island. This in no way reflects on any of those people on the island who are working hard to provide those services. I particularly think of the school education system and the health system where we have people doing their absolute best. Locals on the island are also attempting to service that community with one lone ambulance. There is a lot to be done and it is with those people in mind that these recommendations come forward.

On behalf of the committee, I thank all of those people on the island who have represented their views and their concerns to us. I also thank my colleagues on the committee for the role that we as a committee have collectively played, I believe, in working on behalf of the population of Norfolk Island. I also thank the secretariat of the committee. We have had a change of staff on the secretariat of this committee in recent times but the committee’s thanks go to each and every one of them who have played a part in the work behind this report.

—I move:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

—On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD, I present the committee’s report entitled ASIO’s questioning and detention powers—review of the operation, effectiveness and implications of division 3 of part III in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979, together with evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

talk.start.para: —I present the review by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD of the operations, effectiveness and implications of ASIO’s questioning and detention powers. The committee’s name changed on Friday to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security; however, this review was wholly completed under the old name so that is the name that appears on the report being tabled today.

speech.para: This review is a fulfilment of the requirement in section 29 of the Intelligence Services Act that the committee would review the operations of this provision three years after its implementation and prior to the activation of the sunset clause in July 2006.

ASIO provided the committee with a substantial and comprehensive classified submission detailing the operations of the powers over a three-year period. The committee is most grateful for this information, which it found immensely important to its understanding of the operations of the act.

The committee’s findings in relation to the operations of division 3, part III are as follows. ASIO used its questioning powers, under warrant, 14 times over the period of the review. It did not use its detention powers. No request for a warrant was rejected by either the Attorney-General or the issuing authority. All subjects of warrants had access to legal advisers, although not all subjects used legal advisers for the whole period of their questioning. No legal representatives were removed on the grounds of disrupting the proceedings. All applications for financial assistance made to the Attorney-General’s Department have been granted.

ASIO complied with both the act and the protocol in relation to the general conduct of the questioning—that is, it adhered to the laws and regulations in relation to the periods of questioning, the granting of breaks, the allowing of prayer times and the explanation of the procedures to the subject et cetera. The Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security or someone from his office attended the first day of all questioning warrants. All questionings were videotaped and transcribed and all videotapes and transcripts were provided to the office of the Inspector-General. The committee also had an opportunity to view videotapes and transcripts for the first eight warrants, but not the last six.

The nature of the questioning was described by the IGIS as ‘professional and appropriate’ and ‘the subjects of warrants were treated with humanity and respect for human dignity’, even in the face of ‘abusive and evasive comments’. The prescribed authority described the nature of the questioning as ‘questions merely to get information’ rather than ‘cross-examination’.

No complaints were made to the Federal Court or to the Ombudsman. However, some complaints about the process were made to IGIS and to the committee. The details of these complaints are set out in the report. They included:

item.para: A lack of specificity in the warrants and therefore a limiting of the supervision of the questioning.
A series of complaints about the nature of the questions which, while they were acknowledged to be polite and professional, might be considered to be improper.
The right of lawyers to intervene—in circumstances where questions appeared to be improper, lawyers believed they should have a right to intervene.

Problems associated with the right to use interpreters—interpreters were refused on occasions and, where the period of questioning had been extended for those using interpreters, there was a danger that this might inhibit a subject from asking for the use of one even where that might be advisable.
There were claims of prejudicial reporting in the media about people subject to questioning warrants whose right of reply was curtailed by the secrecy provisions of the act.

speech.para: These complaints were central to the debate during the inquiry and have informed the committee’s subsequent recommendations. A number of the committee’s recommendations were supported by the IGIS and regarded as reasonable by officials from ASIO and the Attorney-General’s Department during the inquiry.

The committee has also asked that the secrecy provisions be re-examined—that penalties for breaches be made standard, that the definition of ‘operational information’ for the purposes of the secrecy provisions be narrowed, that greater disclosure be possible on questioning-only warrants and that the prescribed authority be given some decision-making power in relation to disclosure under the secrecy provisions.

The committee took a great deal of evidence from the Muslim community on the implications of the legislation for them. They expressed concern that the impact on them was negative, that it had created apprehension and a sense that they had to prove their innocence.

Finally, the committee acknowledged and accepted the view put to it by almost all witnesses that the powers within division 3 part III were extraordinary powers that should remain on the statute book only so long as necessary. Therefore, the committee believes that the sunset clause, albeit over a longer time frame, must be re-inserted into the legislation when it is re-enacted next year.
I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise also to speak on the report that has been tabled by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD into division 3 part III of the ASIO Act 1979 which, obviously, governs ASIO’s questioning and detention powers. In rising to speak on the tabling of this report, I would like to acknowledge and welcome the return of the committee chair, the Hon. David Jull, and to also acknowledge the excellent work that his predecessor and acting chair, Senator Alan Ferguson, put into the committee. It was a relatively difficult inquiry, and the manner in which Senator Ferguson chaired that committee—in a very bipartisan and a very fair way—was a great credit to him and also to the spirit of the committee. I would also like to thank the staff of the secretariat of the committee, particularly its secretary, Mrs Margaret Swieringa, Dr Cathryn Ollif, and the executive assistant, Donna Quintus-Bosz, for their assistance, without which we would not be tabling this particular report.

speech.para: As a member of that committee, examining something which is regarded as a relatively controversial piece of legislation, I was particularly grateful for the cooperation that was exhibited by the members of ASIO and particularly its former director, Dennis Richardson. It enabled us as committee members to have a detailed understanding of the operation and the execution of a law which had generated much debate within a particular community. It enabled us to see how it worked and some of its potential shortcomings as well. Getting that frankness out of ASIO and watching the workings and the operations of this law gave us a very detailed insight into its execution, particularly in light of the current debate about existing legislation.

A lot of the committee’s deliberations on these matters—whether or not the actual legislation needed further strengthening, shall we say—were shaped on the first day of the hearing in evidence that was put forward by the former director of ASIO, Dennis Richardson. He was questioned by Senator Ray, putting aside the question of the sunset clause, as to whether or not there should be increased powers in this legislation. The answer to that was no. In fact, a member of the Attorney-General’s Department said:

quote.para: With us, the answer is no as well. In fact, the amendments we included in our submission are about clarifying the powers probably in the direction of the rights of the individual.

speech.para: The director-general was asked, again by Senator Ray:

quote.para: ... you are satisfied that the existing powers equip you to do the job you need to do?

speech.para: The answer by the director-general was yes. In effect, the committee was not arguing for an increase of the powers in this particular piece of legislation to combat the threat of terrorism but, in the words of the Attorney-General’s office, ‘improving the safeguards of the powers and clarifying the rights of the individual’.

In reflecting as an individual committee member on this piece of legislation, when I looked at the debate in June 2003 I found that, in his concluding remarks, the Attorney-General said about these particular powers:

quote.para: We have always said that we recognise that this bill is extraordinary; indeed, I have indicated repeatedly that I hope the powers under the bill never have to be exercised. But this bill is about intelligence gathering in extraordinary circumstances ...

speech.para: We have heard from the chair that the use of those powers has been appropriate by the agency and it has been appropriately independently monitored by the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. I would say in this place that it emphasises that, when you bring legislation of this nature to the Australian parliament, it should be subjected to an independent and bipartisan committee process. There should be some independent supervision and some accountability to this place.

I would certainly welcome the insertion of the sunset clause. This is a very important mechanism to keep agencies accountable—not because we believe that they will not exercise their powers prudently, as has been the case in the execution of the 14 questioning warrants, but because we need to provide the legislative security protection for them to be exercising their powers. That was one of the key recommendations arising from this report.

I would also argue this: in terms of the execution of this particular legislation and its passage through the various committees, which has strengthened the legislation—in fact, we have 19 recommendations which, in my view, strengthen the effectiveness of the legislation—that, in future, when governments bring forward legislation like this, they should refer it to this committee: a bipartisan committee. (Time expired)

—On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties I present the committee’s report entitled Report 69—treaties tabled on 13 September and 11 October 2005: amendments to the schedule to the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling; Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child on the sale of children, child prostitution and child pornography.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

talk.start.para: —Report 69 contains the findings and recommendations of the committee’s review of two treaty actions tabled in parliament on 13 September and 11 October 2005. The treaty actions relate to the maintenance of the moratorium on commercial whaling and to measures to protect children from commercial sexual exploitation. The amendments to the schedule to the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling will maintain the moratorium on commercial whaling, which commenced in 1982, for an additional year. The International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling establishes an international system for the regulation of whale fisheries to ensure proper and effective conservation and development of whale stocks. Australia has been a signatory to the convention since it came into force in 1948 and, with the closure of the last Australian shore based whaling operation in 1979, remains a strong advocate of whale conservation.

speech.para: The committee was concerned that under Japan’s latest whaling for scientific research program its next whale harvest from Antarctic waters will be more than double the previous number. The committee was told that the number of minke whales harvested will unfortunately increase from 440 last season to 935 this season. Japan will also harvest another 10 fin whales annually during its two-year program. At the end of its research program, Japan will harvest annually up to 50 fin whales and 50 humpback whales as well as the 935 minke whales. The committee discovered that Australia has developed non-lethal ways to conduct whale research. The committee was told that Japan has rejected the use of such non-lethal methodologies and, despite concerns expressed to it by the International Whaling Commission, has proceeded to commence with its latest whaling program. Australia is continuing to make strong representations both to Japan and within the commission to end whaling.

The second treaty examined by the committee—the Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child on the sale of children, child prostitution and child pornography—is designed to protect children from the worst forms of commercial sexual exploitation. The optional protocol obliges Australia to prohibit the sale of children, child prostitution and child pornography and any acts which may assist in the sexual exploitation of children. Submissions received by the committee were supportive of the optional protocol, with one submission raising two issues. The first issue raised was whether the definition of ‘sale of children’ in article 2(a) could be misinterpreted to include the legitimate adoption of children. The second issue is whether the optional protocol includes provisions relating to advertising material that depicts or describes a person who is, or who appears to be, under the age of 18 in a sexual context or activity.

In relation to the first issue, the committee found that the definition of ‘sale of children’ under the optional protocol is limited by article 32 of the Hague Convention on Protection of Children and Co-operation in Respect of Intercountry Adoption. This interpretation allows distinction to be made between the sale of children and the legitimate adoption of children, where fees or costs may be incurred. In addition, the optional protocol contains provisions requiring states parties to criminalise the improper inducement of consent for adoption. Legislation between tiers of government differs on the second issue, but generally, under the optional protocol, states parties must take appropriate measures aimed at effectively prohibiting the production and dissemination of material advertising the offences described.

In conclusion, the committee believes it is in Australia’s interest for the treaties considered in report 69 to be ratified. I thank all committee members who contributed to the report, especially the deputy chair, who is in the House today. I would particularly like to thank the secretariat members for their advice and support during our deliberations. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties report 69 contains the review of two proposed treaty actions. I will comment on both the treaties contained in the committee’s report. The amendments to the schedule to the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling come before the committee each year and extend the moratorium on commercial whaling for an additional year. The committee received evidence about Japan’s latest Antarctic research program. The chair has already mentioned the increased number of whales that will be harvested under that arrangement, about which we were very disappointed. We also believe there are other methods. In fact, the committee were informed that Australia has developed non-lethal ways of conducting whale research and has also been active within the International Whaling Commission to compel Japan to desist from whaling for scientific research purposes.

speech.para: The second treaty action reviewed by the committee is the Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child on the sale of children, child prostitution and child pornography. The optional protocol would protect children from commercial sexual exploitation and supplements the Convention on the Rights of the Child, to which Australia is already a contracting party. Not only does the optional protocol require Australia to prohibit the sale of children, child prostitution and child pornography; it also prohibits supplementary acts which might aid or assist these areas. These include offering, delivering or accepting a child for the purposes of sexual exploitation, the transfer of organs for profit or the engagement of the child in forced labour; improperly inducing consent, as an intermediary, for the adoption of a child in violation of applicable legal instruments on adoption; offering, obtaining or procuring a child for prostitution; and producing, distributing, disseminating, importing, exporting, offering, selling or possessing child pornography. Finally, the optional protocol requires states parties to cooperate to prevent, detect, investigate, punish or prosecute acts of child prostitution, child pornography or the sale of children.

I would also like to thank the acting chair, who has been looking after the committee while the chair has been away in the UN. She has done an admirable job in some adverse circumstances on occasions—often created by us. I would also like to commend the work of the secretariat and thank them for the work they have done during the year. We are tabling another report tomorrow, but unfortunately I will not be present. The secretariat have done a fantastic job, as I believe the committee has. I would like to wish the secretariat staff and their families all the best for the festive season and for next year.

debateinfo.title: CRIMES ACT AMENDMENT (INCITEMENT TO VIOLENCE) BILL 2005

talk.start.para: —Today I introduce the Crimes Act Amendment (Incitement to Violence) Bill 2005, which would provide new offences in the Crimes Act for threats and incitement to violence on racial and religious grounds. Labor have supported laws like these for a long time and we think that in a multicultural and multi-religious society we can have no tolerance for those who preach violence on the basis of race, religion, ethnicity, colour or nationality. Every government has a basic responsibility to protect citizens from violence and the fear of violence.

speech.para: Lately we have been most concerned about protecting the whole community from terrorism but we should also be concerned about racist thugs who terrorise minority communities. Indeed, there is a link between the two. Heaven forbid that there should ever be a terrorist attack on Australian soil, but if there were, we would need to make sure that thugs and bullies did not use it as an opportunity to whip up hostility against scapegoat groups from a particular religion or racial background—or any other reason they had for singling them out.

The laws that we propose would act against all those who make threats and incite violence on racial and religious grounds. It would give our authorities the power to act against jihadists preaching terrorism but also against neo-Nazis terrorising Jews or others terrorising Muslims or ethnic communities—along with many other examples.

Every time we have proposed laws of this sort in the past they have been opposed by the Liberal and National parties. In the past John Howard has always argued that these laws impede free speech. Labor does support free speech, but the right to free speech is not absolute. Free speech should not permit people to cross the line and whip up or incite violence against others.

After years of opposition to the idea, in the last few months the Howard government has swung to the other extreme. It now proposes tough new sedition laws that are so badly designed and drafted that they will cast the net too wide—possibly catching journalists, artists and peaceful protesters—with the effect of chilling national debate. The problem is that the government is using a 16th century law for the 21st century challenge of terrorism. Not surprisingly it is ill-suited to maintaining multicultural harmony and controlling violent material on the internet. This result is a clumsy and unfocused law.

The bill I propose is designed for a particular purpose. The link to violence gives Labor’s proposal precision by focusing exactly on the type of conduct to be prohibited. Under our plan there is no way anyone could be prosecuted for mere criticism, evangelism, mockery or satire. To get in trouble you would have to go that extra step—actually making threats or calling on others to commit acts of violence motivated by religion or race. The focus is on catching the promoters of violence before their followers actually commit violent acts. This is a current gap in our law.

The Howard government sedition provisions do provide a crime of encouraging violence between groups but it will only be activated when the urgings of violence between groups also threatens the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth. So the big gap is that the government’s planned law will not be effective against localised neighbourhood thugs even though they can cause just as much fear and risk to the community. The sedition provisions also imply that the offence will apply to minorities that urge violence against majority groups but not necessarily the other way around—another odious weakness.

On the whole, Australia has avoided problems on the scale that we have seen overseas. All around the world we have seen examples of conflicts between ethnic and religious groups. The success in Australia of avoiding these problems is the result of a more open and active approach that we have taken to multiculturalism. We have encouraged ethnic communities to maintain cultural practices and we have celebrated the diversity that results. But we have also made efforts to make sure that immigrants and their children learn Australian values and have opportunities to participate in the economic and cultural life of the nation.

The Australian experience has not been perfect. We have problems to iron out, for sure. But on the whole we have created a multicultural miracle—not through luck but through effort. The next step in that effort is to have laws that stop incitement to racial or religious violence. These might help us to protect the community before harm is caused and underwrite the harmony our nation is fortunate to take for granted.

If we are to limit free speech in any way, the laws must be drafted carefully and in a considered and targeted way. We do want to catch the violent cheerleaders who urge followers to terrible acts against the community but we do not want to prevent others simply from speaking their minds. This bill seeks to achieve both those ends. I commend it to the House and present a signed copy of the explanatory memorandum.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: —In accordance with standing order 41, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

—The people of my electorate believe in the dignity of work. They also believe in a fair day’s pay for a fair day’s work. They are certainly very concerned about the government’s extreme industrial relations legislation. In that respect, I table a petition, about the industrial relations changes, containing 2,143 signatures. This brings the total of concerned people signing petitions in the electorate of Chifley to 5,692. Their dearest wish is that this legislation be killed.

speech.para: The petition read as follows—

quote.para: To the Speaker of the House or Representatives and Members of the House assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that Australian employees will be worse off as a result of the Howard Government’s proposed changes to the industrial relations system.

The petitioners call upon the Howard Government to adopt a plan to produce a fair industrial relations system based on fairness and the fundamental principles of minimum standards, wages and conditions; safety nets; an independent umpire; the right to associate; and the right to collectively bargain.
The Petitioners therefore ask the House to ensure that the Howard Government:

item.para: Guarantees that no individual Australian employee will be worse off under proposed changes to the industrial relation system.
Allows the National Minimum Wage to continue to be set annually by the independent umpire, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.
Guarantees that unfair dismissal law changes will not enable employers to unfairly sack employees.
Ensures that workers have the right to reject individual contracts and bargain for decent wages and conditions collectively.
Keeps in place safety nets for minimum wages and conditions.

Adopt Federal Labor’s principles to produce a fair system based on the fundamental principles on minimum standards, wages and conditions; safety nets; an independent umpire; the right to associate; and the right to collectively bargain.

speech.para: from 2,143 citizens.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to make special mention of two successful local business owners in Bayside of my electorate who have very recently offered a positive solution to the new Welfare to Work requirement that encourages single parents whose youngest child is eight to re-enter the work force. Bayside Family Day Care manager, Linda Harnett, and Wynnum Family Day Care manager, Cathy Bavage, are offering to train parents so they have skills to run their own home day care businesses. Through operating their own businesses in the home, parents could fulfil their 15 hour a week work requirement whilst still being able to spend quality time with their children. This is a realistic and viable option.

speech.para: I realise that there is some angst in the community at present about this government’s Welfare to Work policies and that this issue, alongside workplace relations reform, has been a subject of debate within the Bonner electorate. Subsequently, I find it refreshing to note the enthusiasm with which Ms Harnett and Ms Bavage have encouraged single parents in the local community to consider a career in family day care. In doing so, single parents can ultimately determine their own working hours, receive the personalised support and training that is unique to the industry and maintain a family-oriented lifestyle that meets the new Welfare to Work requirements. Family day care is a scheme that I believe should be more widely embraced by parents and families. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am rising today because the girls of St Scholastica’s College in Glebe in my electorate have brought me this wonderful banner, which they have signed. I will not spread it out in here, Mr Speaker, but I have been given leave to table it and I hope you do not mind. It has on it ‘Make Poverty History’. Make Poverty History has been a fantastic campaign this year and a very important one. Thirty thousand children die every day due to extreme poverty. We have done an excellent job in getting this issue onto the agenda internationally, but much more needs to be done. On 13 December, World Trade Organisation talks begin in Hong Kong and it will be very important to make sure that those talks address the issue of trade justice for the world’s poorest people. We need more and better aid, and we need to drop the debt. In July this year the G8 made some significant commitments on debt and aid, and there were further commitments made by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in September. But there is still a long way to go to ensure that the world’s poorest people, mostly living on below a dollar a day, are able to lift themselves and their families out of poverty and have a decent standard of living. With your permission, Mr Speaker, I will table this banner from the girls of St Scholastica’s.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Last Thursday night I attended the Prime Minister’s New South Wales and national Employer of the Year Awards. It was tremendously encouraging to see during the evening the number of employers from around the country who are providing valuable employment opportunities for young people with disabilities and giving them a real chance to stand on their own two feet. I was particularly encouraged because one of my local employers won both the New South Wales category and the national category for medium sized business of the year. My sincere congratulations go to Blaxland Super IGA for their work in providing employment opportunities for people with disabilities. My congratulations go to the owner, the manager, Peter Smith, and Work Choices, who provided the connection and support for these people. This store really tries to find the best opportunities for these people, opportunities that will meet their abilities, provide them with a chance to gain valuable work experience, to interact with other employees and to develop pride in their own ability. Employment like this gives these people and their employers a chance to focus not on their disabilities but on their abilities. These employees all have something valuable to contribute to the workplace. Blaxland Super IGA, as well as many other employers around the country, is doing a tremendous job in providing valuable employment opportunities for these people.

—On Friday a group of workers got together in my electorate to establish a public appeal to support a local family in need. At the Multiplex site in Parramatta, the CFMEU launched a public appeal to help the family of Lauren Huxley with the assistance of Unions New South Wales and Parramatta City Council. Lauren was the subject of a horrible crime that shocked our local community. This young woman was attacked and left for dead in her Northmead home. She has since undergone more than 10 hours of facial reconstruction and neurosurgery. Recent reports are cautiously optimistic.

speech.para: Lauren’s mum and dad are members of the FSU and CFMEU respectively. Her father, Phil, a carpenter by trade, did his apprenticeship in Granville and has worked on some of the biggest sites in Sydney. He has been a big supporter of workers’ causes and not so long ago was out supporting Marlene Shaw and her two teenage daughters after Marlene’s husband was killed during the construction of the cross-city tunnel. Unfortunately, Phil’s family is now in trouble but his fellow workmates have gathered around to help. The Huxley family home was burnt as part of the malicious attack and the family have had the overwhelming task of staying strong for Lauren. Neither parent is working; both are living in a one-bedroom flat. Both parents are off work as they provide 24-hour comfort and support for their daughter. The money raised will help the family financially so they can give their daughter all the attention and care she needs. Multiplex management and workers joined to launch the campaign, and approximately $20,000 was raised in the first 48 hours of the appeal. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Like the Chief Government Whip, I wish to acknowledge the 2005 Prime Minister’s employer awards that were held in the Great Hall on Thursday. I particularly congratulate Avia Produce, tomato growers in Torquay in the heartland of Corangamite, on their win in the small business section. Proprietors Andy and Porta Kakouros run this enterprise and have provided 30 opportunities for workers with disabilities. They have been genuinely committed to the concept of looking after those people who have not got their full capacities but can enjoy full-time work. They justly won the prize here in Canberra against all other competitors. I also acknowledge the contribution of St Laurence, through their ability to coordinate the program, and that of Colin Entwistle and Michele Marcu, who were here on Thursday night to celebrate this great win for Corangamite. I congratulate the minister on a wonderful evening. Some of the speeches and reports were heart-rending as to the ability of small business, medium sized business and big business to provide opportunities for people with a wide range of disabilities so that they can join the work force and make a meaningful contribution to the profitability of these enterprises and, more importantly, make a contribution to their own esteem. (Time expired)

—I am pleased to be able to table, later in the week the Micah Challenge petition that was presented to me by local churches within my electorate with 760 signatures. Micah Challenge is a global international Christian campaign that seeks to provide a voice to the poor in communities around the world. Micah Challenge is derived from the Millennium Declaration that was signed in 2000 by all UN member states. It was great to see so many churches within my electorate brought together by their shared concern for world poverty and for the needs of others.

speech.para: We are living in a time when half the world’s population lives on less than $US2 a day, when one woman dies every minute as a result of problems with pregnancy or childbirth—of these, 99 per cent are in developing countries—and when one child dies every 15 seconds from water related diseases. The petition that will be tabled later in the week is a great example of local churches acting locally but thinking globally. Although many of the signatories to this petition may never meet those they seek to help, they do not choose to see them as strangers but rather as their neighbours. This is an integral part of the Christian ethic, an ethic which has long had a strong tradition in Ballarat.

While I welcome the government’s recent decision to increase Australia’s level of development assistance from the embarrassingly low levels to which it had fallen, more needs to be done. Labor has a longstanding commitment to the internationally agreed target of 0.7 per cent of gross national income as our long-term objective for development assistance. When you think what could be achieved if we worked as one, we have little choice but to do everything that can be reasonably expected to make sure the goals laid down are reached. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on a function that I attended in my electorate over the weekend. It was organised in conjunction with Leigh Thornton, who is the school chaplain at Golden Grove High School, as well as the Pedare Uniting Church. The function was a skate competition presented by ARKAID, an organisation which has been established in my electorate to assist at-risk kids. The day was attended by hundreds of young people, as well as their parents, who came along to support ARKAID. I want to pay particular tribute to some of the sponsors who were there for the day—people from the local Dial-A-Digger were out in force, as was the Daily Grind, which is based in Tea Tree Gully.

speech.para: All of these young people working together to achieve a sense of comradeship and sportsmanship made for a truly great afternoon and a truly great function for me to attend. I am especially proud because one of the organisers and one of the people to act as master of ceremonies was my own son, Graham David Draper, with Lisa-Marie, who is one of the youth leaders for the Pedare Uniting Church. He did a fantastic job, along with some of his other friends, including Andy Dunt from Ingle Farm Uniting Church— (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last week saw the release of the latest current account figures. And what a frightening picture that was.
