talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I have a question to you and it relates to the requirement you placed on the member for Calare on Wednesday, 30 November to withdraw a series of statements he had made about you outside the House by way of press release. As you would recall, and I am not intending to take the House to the detail of it, the member for Calare made an assertion about a procedural matter during the final stages of the Anti-Terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2005 in this House. In respect of that assertion he was wrong, as we are aware, but I believe that the assertion was made in good faith by the member for Calare.

speech.para: Mr Speaker, you would be aware that the precedents for requiring a member to apologise for remarks made outside the House about the Speaker or the Speaker’s conduct of parliament are actually very few and far between. In fact, the one relied upon, the one that has stood the test of time, was what was referred to as the Tuckey case of 1987. I do not think it would surprise anybody to learn that it involved the member for O’Connor. As you may be aware, Mr Speaker, his remarks publicly made on that occasion included saying, ‘Speakers who are in control don’t get troubled,’ ‘Yes, I think the Speaker should resign,’ ‘I believe the Speaker was very unfair,’ and, ‘I think the Speaker is now just a political animal and I say she has been intimidated.’ Mr Speaker, I would put to you that the remarks made by the member for O’Connor in 1987 are of a completely different nature to the press release remarks issued by the member for Calare—

talk.start.para: Mr Tuckey interjecting—
—Order! The Manager of Opposition Business has the call.

—Showing the normal understanding of the procedures of the House, we have the member for O’Connor chiming in. But, Mr Speaker, my submission to you is that the remarks made by him in 1987 are of an entirely different nature to the assertion made by the member for Calare. Mr Speaker, I can understand that, while no-one likes to be criticised, you should err on the basis of allowing the maximum amount of free speech by members of the House when it comes to the conduct of the House. Mr Speaker, in that regard and for some guidance on this matter, can I perhaps somewhat unusually refer you to the opening paragraphs of the speech of the now Prime Minister when the member for O’Connor’s suspension from the House was debated by the House.
Mrs Bronwyn Bishop interjecting—
—It is a question to the Speaker, thanks, Member for Mackellar.
—The member will come to her question.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The House of Representatives Practice refers not only to the fact that there is not to be a long preamble to a question but also to the fact that it applies to this stage of proceedings. This is not a question, it is a speech, and it infringes every point set out in standing order 100.
—I thank the member for Mackellar. I will ask the Manager of Opposition Business to conclude her question.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker, for that wise guidance. We understand why you hold the office you hold. Mr Speaker, I was referring you finally—
—I am asking you to conclude your question.
—I am concluding but looking after your interests at the same time, Mr Speaker. I am referring you to the words of the now Prime Minister when he said:

quote.para: You cannot look at the events in isolation from the way in which the Government has stretched to their very limit the theoretical meaning of the Standing Orders of this Parliament so far as Question Time is concerned.

speech.para: I think you will find, Mr Speaker, that some of the criticism of the conduct of this place arises for comparable reasons.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Manager of Opposition Business and I will respond in two parts. First of all, I will give consideration to the point that she has raised, but the response to the member for Calare was very much aligned with the comments he had made in the press release which reflected on the chair—not on the occupant but on the chair itself. I will report back to the member in due course.

talk.start.para: Ms Vamvakinou (from 21 citizens)
—I move:

item.para: notes that petrol prices in regional areas have dramatically increased and are averaging well over $1.20 per litre;
recognises that these prices are becoming prohibitive for families and small businesses and are adversely impacting on tourism—an industry which many regional areas rely on; and
calls on the Government to direct the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to formally monitor prices under Part VIIA of the Trade Practices Act 1974.

speech.para: The cost of petrol is hurting families and businesses in regional areas across Australia, and my electorate of Richmond is no exception. Locals are telling me loud and clear that they are doing it tough and they are sick and tired of this government doing nothing about the massive increases in petrol prices. Businesses are finding it harder and harder to keep in the black because their stock prices, delivery costs, running costs and production costs have gone up—all flowing on from the huge rises in petrol prices. To add to this, soaring petrol prices are having a huge impact on our lucrative domestic tourism industry as families realise it is just too expensive to get on the road for their holidays.

The Northern Rivers region, which includes my electorate of Richmond, is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Australia. Consequently, tourism is one of our most important industries and many local businesses depend either directly or indirectly on the tourist dollar for their survival. For local families, the cost of living—or simply surviving—is going up and up all the time. Health care, food and housing prices have all risen, and petrol prices have skyrocketed to over $1.20 a litre in parts of my electorate. The Howard government tells us that petrol prices are solely dependent on world prices and that nothing can be done. This is not much comfort to the mums and dads in my electorate who are breaking the family budget at the bowser every week. The government is just plain wrong. Global prices are not the only factor impacting on petrol prices.

We all saw the press reports last week on petrol price gouging and Caltex’s staggering profits. An article in the Daily Telegraph on 29 November 2005 entitled ‘Petrol giant’s $70 million rip-off’ said:

quote.para: Spiralling profits at Australia’s biggest oil refiner have at last revealed the true extent of the petrol gouge.

speech.para: What this means is that, months after world prices have dropped, motorists are still being charged at the bowser on the basis of higher world prices. The profit Caltex made on each barrel of refined crude oil surged from $9.54 to an average of $15 in the second half of the year. So we are not talking about small bickies. Caltex revealed a staggering $70 million jump in post-tax profit to $420 million. Ordinary Australians are footing the bill for this profit, especially those from regional areas such as my electorate of Richmond.

The General Manager of Fueltrac, the price monitoring firm, Geoff Trotter, said that oil companies have especially not passed on any price decreases to rural and regional centres of Australia. In short, where petrol companies do not have to compete, they simply will not. So in regional centres, where wages are lower, unemployment is higher and people can least afford it, we are being ripped off the most at the bowser by oil refineries. In the words of the President of the NRMA, Alan Evans, ‘the Howard government must get off its behind’. And it certainly should.

Federal Labor is calling on the Howard government to show some leadership on this issue and do something about it. First, we need an ACCC inquiry into petrol prices and we need it now. Local people are constantly telling me that some action has to be taken. We need to have that inquiry started immediately. The ACCC themselves have said something funny is going on. The rest of Australia knows something funny is going on, so it is about time the Howard government did something about it. It is not enough for the Prime Minister to sit down with his big mates from Caltex, BP and Shell and let them satisfy him that they are not petrol gouging. We need an independent ACCC to monitor prices and ensure that consumers are being protected from the price gouging around Australia.

Second, we need to develop a long-term strategy to reduce our dependence on overseas oil. This is vitally important for our future. If we take no action now, we face the very real possibility of $5 per litre prices at the pump within 10 years. Labor’s blueprint for developing the Australian fuel industry outlines how we can foster an Australian fuel industry and provide relief to families at the petrol bowser in the long term. While Mr Howard sits on his hands, we as a nation are becoming increasingly dependent on foreign oil. We need to put measures in place immediately to increase the use of Australian fuels so that we are less vulnerable to external price shocks. We need to develop existing alternatives such as liquid petroleum gas, ethanol and biodiesel and emerging alternatives such as compressed natural gas, liquid fuel from gas and stored electricity.

Australians deserve a government that is willing to show some leadership on petrol gouging and a plan for the future. People in regional areas are doing it tough. They see petrol prices increase day by day and week by week and they want to have something done about it. They need to be relieved of the burden of having to continue to pay these high prices. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—Petrol prices will always be a significant issue among the Australian people because, per capita, they are large consumers of that product. But popular solutions such as ‘the government should do something about it’ were even rejected by the member for Rankin in a very intelligent paper that put together the realities of the petrol market, with the point being that, whilst you can accuse people such as refiners of profit gouging, those figures are not supported when one looks at the international marketplace in which Australia properly operates. For instance, we have international prices for crude oil that are measured in Australia by the Malaysian Tapis rate, and we have retail prices for which the benchmark is Singaporean Mogas 95 unleaded. So if there has been price gouging, as the member for Richmond has just alleged, one would think things would be a little different. Obviously, the gross profit margin of refiners is the difference between the Tapis price and the Mogas price, which was $6.25 on average during 2004, before we saw this massive escalation in world crude prices. In August 2005, as the price of crude started to increase, that margin was $5.96. In September 2005 the margin had increased to $11.29, and in October 2005 it had crept back down to what one could almost call the average at $7.42.

speech.para: But what have we been told about this escalation in the price of refined product? There is an international shortage of refinery capacity. So the member for Richmond wants us to believe that, if by some regulatory mechanism we keep screwing down the retail margin or the margins available to fuel refiners, they will go and build a new refinery and will spend the hundreds of millions that governments on both sides have demanded they spend to improve the quality and reduce the emissions of the fuels we use at this stage. I note that Caltex got a mention from the member for Richmond. It is a company that is struggling to meet those particular requirements, and that might be because it is the only publicly traded fuel refiner in Australia. Where do those profits go that the member for Richmond complains about? In many cases they go to union super funds. We all get this wonderful view from time to time that profits are consumed by the chief executive or some other powerful individual in the world when our marketplace today recycles profits into the investment community, with credit to be given, as I have been reminded previously by the member for Gorton, to an initiative of the Keating government—or Keating as Treasurer, I have forgotten which side of the fence he was on at the time. It was at about the time that he did not put in two tax returns, as I recollect—a matter that has always been ignored on the Labor side because they say they knew nothing about it. The reality is that, in these matters, investment has been created by compulsory superannuation, and no doubt on the computer screens every major super company has a share in Caltex. But the reality is that in Adelaide there still sits a mothballed refinery. Why was it closed? Because the margins were insufficient to keep a relatively small operation open.

So that is the first thing. In my remaining couple of minutes I do want to complain about some of the differentials that exist in the prices between city and country. I cannot understand them. It costs half a cent a litre per 100 kilometres to freight fuel by road to virtually anywhere in Australia, and there are some pretty big outlets outside of the capital cities. This economy of scale argument is relative, but not always. I will never know why those prices have to jump in that fashion.

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Richmond for placing the issue about petrol prices on the Notice Paper. It is an important motion, because it allows us an opportunity to consider the consequences of very high petrol prices and the adverse effects on ordinary consumers of petrol. There are a number of areas relating to this consumer concern. There has already been some discussion about the way in which the ACCC should regulate how petrol companies behave and, indeed, about the relative difference between crude oil and produced oil prices. Why is there a much greater increase in prices of petrol at the petrol pump compared with the price of barrels of crude oil? That is the concern that a number of members on this side of the House have had with the hike. As members of this place who are sensitive to concerns of constituents would know, the massive increase in petrol prices has had an adverse effect on families in terms of making sure they can pick up their kids from school and go to work and get home by car. These everyday things have become more difficult for many who are on low incomes.

speech.para: As I have said before in this type of debate, we can look at a number of options. I have said before that there was an opportunity to consider cutting excise tax, and that is certainly an option, but the government has chosen to do nothing. The Reserve Bank could obviously consider tightening monetary policy, and the government could also have considered cutting income tax. The one option that I do not think has been considered as regards a response by government has been the cutting of excise tax.

There is no doubt that monetary policy can deal with any inflationary consequences of an oil price shock. Monetary policy can generally squeeze away any inflation. It is slow but sure. The difficulty is that if that is the sum total of the policy response then the consequences for economic activity, as I have said before, are very painful. So I suggest an answer may be something that simultaneously alleviates the need for tighter monetary policy and offsets the worst consequences of any tightening that occurs. A cut in fuel excise taxes may be that magic bullet. One way to describe the argument for cutting fuel excise duty is that, if the government does not do something, the Reserve Bank surely will. The economy faces stagflationary pressures. The sensible response is some policy change which is price-decreasing and which also encourages economic activity. A fuel excise tax cut does that. None of the other policy options does so.

The essential conceptual problem which the government view entails is that, if it acts as if it is independent, it means it is irrelevant. Just because the Reserve Bank is independent does not mean that its likely actions and reactions can be ignored. If a macro-economic shock is large or sustained, the consequences are known. There is a policy response which is effective, macro-economically responsible and powerfully superior to the main alternative. This last point bears emphasis. It would appear that the government proposes to do nothing with a view to later cutting income taxes. No doubt the Treasurer would like to delay any further tax cuts to coincide with his challenge to the Prime Minister for the prime ministership next year.

I think it is important that the government looks at ways to respond to this particular crisis. It is fair to say that the hikes in the petrol price have been on the decline in recent weeks for a number of reasons, but the hikes allow us to consider whether we use fiscal policy or monetary policy. They allow us to consider examining alternative fuels. Allowing this potential crisis to precipitate proper consideration of taxation and environmental concerns allows the parliament and parliamentarians to—I hope—confront issues and provide answers for future problems. I suggest parliamentarians consider this. The government should investigate the options available for cutting excise tax because I think it can provide the benefits without the disadvantages associated with other forms of taxation policy.

talk.start.para: —The motion on petrol prices is an important one. It would be good if we could do something about this issue. But the fact of the matter is this: of the 30 OECD countries, we have got the fourth lowest petrol prices. Ours are much lower than most countries in the world. In fact, one of the reasons for the low price of petrol in Australia compared with other countries is the low taxes applied to fuel by the Australian government. This was brought about in part by a decision not to continue the indexation of excise that was introduced by the Australian Labor Party. The fact of the matter is that if Labor’s policy had continued then the price of petrol would have been roughly 14.7c per litre higher than it currently is. That is the story that we confront today. We have got the Australian Labor Party saying that we should do something about petrol prices; the Australian government has. The member for Richmond ought to remember that half of her constituents are driving across the border to Queensland to fill up their cars because the Queensland government is actually giving back some of the GST funds provided by the Commonwealth with the changeover in excise and GST at the time of the introduction of the goods and services tax. The government in New South Wales is not interested in anything but raising more taxes everywhere it can with every means it can think of.

speech.para: It is interesting to note that the ACCC does conduct informal inquiries and keeps a check on oil prices. Its summaries are very useful. Its summary indicates that the higher margins recorded in recent months are primarily due to the shortage of supply of refined product in the US following Hurricane Katrina and the Chinese government’s recent decision to take steps to halt the export of petrol because of an acute shortage of fuel in several of China’s southern and eastern provinces. So we have got the US and China gobbling up fuel. I refer to an article by the member for Rankin, which I thought was a pretty interesting sort of article and at complete odds with what has been said in the House today. He said on 20 July this year that it is simply not feasible or practicable to legislate lower prices. He said:

quote.para: China is burning oil products for its industrialisation as if there is no tomorrow.
Added to the price increase from Chinese consumption is a terrorism premium on the world oil price.

speech.para: He concluded his comments by saying:

quote.para: So no, there are no magic solutions to high petrol prices. It might seem clever to pretend there are, but the Australian people are smarter than that.

speech.para: The comments of a prominent member of the Australian Labor Party are completely at odds with the presentations here today by fellow members of the Australia Labor Party.

The support for Australian families by this government has been substantial. Our costs for energy rose only 13.4 per cent in the September quarter, compared with an OECD average of 21.1 per cent. In the September quarter the CPI increased by 0.9 per cent, including the price increase in petrol. If we exclude the price of petrol in the CPI increase, the CPI increase was 2.2 per cent. The increase was 0.9 per cent for petrol; that means 3.1 per cent is the actual increase in the CPI. So the impact is significant but restrained, as it is not elsewhere in the world. For the 2005-06 year, Australians will be able to earn up to $63,000 and stay in the 30 per cent tax bracket. From 1 July 2006 this will rise to $70,000. So there are tax concessions coming through consistently, year after year and as the budget can afford in the government’s management of the Australian economy.

The ACCC informally monitors. It gives prices. It monitors 4,000 sites. It puts out a regular price list. It conducts random sampling of prices throughout Australia. Recently, in Ballarat, it took a number of retailers to court for fixing prices. The ACCC is on the job. It is doing what it is designed to do. I believe that the government is managing high oil prices and high petrol prices as best it can. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Can I respond to some of the comments made by the member for Mitchell. I would argue that most of what he said indicates exactly why there should be a legislative requirement on the ACCC to do exactly that.
—Your own members don’t agree with you.

—While the member for Rankin did make the point that there is no silver bullet, it does not exempt the government from attempting to do something about an issue that is impacting on all of our electorates. In my electorate and that of the member for Throsby, a large number of people commute to work. According to most recent studies, it is probably the largest commuter corridor in Australia. Most of the 16,000 people a day who travel into Sydney in order to obtain work are doing that trip by car. For many of those people, the experience a few months ago of spiralling petrol prices created a great deal of anguish for them and a great deal of pressure on their family budgets.

speech.para: People can come into this House and say that there are always international pressures and other forces causing this and that we cannot be exempt from them—that is absolutely true—but it does not mean that the government can therefore hold their hands up and say, ‘Unfortunately, that will flow through to family budgets and there is not much that we can do about it.’ There is a great deal that the government can do about it, including ensuring a legislative requirement for the ACCC to monitor and report on petrol prices.

Despite comments and explanations as to why the spikes have occurred, the most constant monitors of petrol prices are family members who go to a petrol station every two to three days—particularly those who commute to work—to fill up their cars. They see quite clearly that when oil prices at the international level go up, petrol prices very quickly go up at their local petrol station. When they hear reports that the international price of oil is going back down, they see that petrol prices at the pump where they are filling up are very slow to go back down.

That is the reality for constituents. We are consistently having concerns expressed about the monitoring of petrol prices. That is why I support the member for Richmond’s motion about petrol prices today. There should be a requirement that petrol prices be consistently monitored. If there is nothing smelly or dirty about the way the price of petrol is being set, what is the problem with having it monitored?

talk.start.para: —They already monitor it.

—Not in a formal and ongoing manner, as the member for Ryan very well knows. If there were no problem, the positive outcome would be a six-monthly report that went out to the general public. That would at least enable them to make assessments. If members want to get up in this House and say that there is absolutely no problem, I challenge them to put that on the front page of their next newsletter to their constituents. When they do that, I will accept that they are genuine and sincere in the comments that they make in this House. For any members who wish to send me a copy of their next newsletter to their electorate, outlining that there is no great problem with petrol prices, I will be very glad to come into this place and acknowledge the genuineness of the comments that they make in this place.

speech.para: As much as government members may not like to acknowledge it, there is a rolling sense of discontent amongst families in our communities about their capacity to manage spending an amount of their income on things that they choose rather than on costs that they feel are an unnecessary burden on them. If people in this House think that the GST is a forgotten issue, I say to them—

talk.start.para: —There have been two elections since the GST.

—Perhaps the member recognises that people do not always react immediately and that there is significant resentment about the impact of the GST on family budgets. That is being compounded by things like petrol costs. I suggest to you that, under the new industrial regime, people will be concerned about whether they will get their overtime and penalty rates. In many households, they are the only things keeping their budgets above the red line of debt. That will be a real concern for many families. If members want to laugh, I suggest that they get out and talk to families, because that is the reality for those households. (Time expired)

—I am pleased to speak on the motion on petrol prices moved by the member for Richmond, because it is another example of the opposition and, in this case, the member for Richmond gilding the lily. The presentation by the member for Cunningham, who has just spoken, is another example of an incomplete contribution in every sense of the word. This is another motion that tries to challenge the credibility of the Howard government, and it fails miserably.

speech.para: The motion fails to take into account, as my colleagues have already suggested, that a former shadow minister of the Labor Party, the opposition, has written an article in the Canberra Times about all the factors that contribute to the increase in petrol prices and all the dynamics that are involved with rising prices where that occurs. I want to quote from that article because it is very instructive. The member for Rankin says:

quote.para: Australia’s record petrol prices have one cause and one cause only—high world prices. The OPEC oil-producing countries are pumping oil out of the ground as fast as they can, but not as fast as the world want to use it. China is burning oil products for its industrialisation as if there is no tomorrow. Nobody really anticipated how fast the Chinese economy could grow and how thirsty for oil it is.’

speech.para: Anyone listening to this address or watching it here in the parliament would be very interested to know what this motion is about. I want to read the motion by the member for Richmond. She asks:

item.para: notes that petrol prices in regional areas have dramatically increased and are averaging well over $1.20 per litre ...

speech.para: The sum of $1.20 per litre is the essence of the motion. I actually took the opportunity today to have a look at what petrol prices were in the electorate of the member for Richmond. Lo and behold, what do I discover? Remarkable prices that stand well below the price of $1.20 per litre, as suggested by the member for Richmond. That is another superb example of a federal Labor opposition member gilding the lily and failing to be complete in the entire story. In Murwillumbah, the price of petrol is $1.10.9; in Kingscliff—in the electorate of Richmond—it is $1.17; in Brunswick Heads, it is $1.14.9; in Alstonville, it is $1.15; in Hastings Point, it is $1.08.5; in Tweed Heads, it is $1.09.9; in Bangalow, it is $1.14.9; in Uki, it is $1.15.9; and, in Tyalgum, it is $1.15.9. That is in sharp contrast to the motion that says that regional petrol prices are $1.20 per litre. It is very important for members of the coalition to remember—and I am sure they do not need any reminding—to always be careful regarding what members opposite say. It is very important because they quite often fail to be complete and accurate in what they allege.

When we compare petrol prices in this country to international prices, such comparisons reveal that we are better placed than many of our international competitors. This country enjoys more competitive prices than most places in the world. We rank fourth lowest among OECD countries for petrol prices, according to the International Energy Agency. Only the USA, Mexico and Canada have lower petrol prices. I am highly disappointed that someone who is so concerned about petrol prices and has moved in this House a motion on petrol prices fails to sit in the chamber whilst this motion is being discussed.
The motion also refers to jobs. As the Treasurer mentioned in question time today, the Howard government has created over 1.7 million jobs since its election in 1996. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. The member for Ryan will have leave to continue speaking when and if the debate is resumed.
—I move:

item.para: recognises that:

item.label: (a)
item.para: good health is the single most important factor necessary for individuals to lead a happy and successful life;

item.label: (b)
item.para: what individuals think, eat and the amount of activity they undertake are important determinants of health and wellbeing;

item.label: (c)
item.para: Australians have a high incidence of preventable diseases that are influenced by lifestyle and behaviour including cardiovascular diseases, cholesterol, obesity and diabetes;

item.label: (d)
item.para: for many Australians, health is simply access to medical goods and services; and

item.label: (e)
item.para: once illness has taken hold, because of the mind/body connection, many do not have the mindset to better improve their health until they get a ‘scare’ which often comes too late; and
calls on the Australian Government to:

item.label: (a)
item.para: educate youngsters in schools about health and ways of preventing illness;

item.label: (b)
item.para: educate couples before starting a family on healthy lifestyles for children;

item.label: (c)
item.para: refocus the training of our doctors from ill health to good health with an emphasis on preventative care; and

item.label: (d)
item.para: implement a National Health Strategy with a strong focus on preventative health.

speech.para: There is no doubt that healthier people are happier people. They remain in the work force beyond traditional retirement age, they are more productive and they require fewer support systems in later life. In fact, overall, if one is healthy, life is pretty good. But this country is facing the burden of chronic disease, and the effect of chronic disease is reflected in the increasing incidence of disability and premature death. The rise of obesity is alarming, particularly in young Australians. The level of diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, cancer and cholesterol are all increasing—diseases that in many cases are preventable. These diseases are often influenced by lifestyle choices and behaviour, but the levels still keep climbing because Australians are not taking responsibility for their own health.

We have one of the best health systems in the world. We have high standards of treatment and preventative care—and of course there is always the local public hospital and the specialist care that is available to all in this country—but all too often individuals believe they are invincible and that a trip to the GP will solve any health problems. It amazes me that individuals will continue down a destructive path with regard to their health, even armed with all the information that is available about healthy living: how to eat, how to cook our food and how we must take up some exercise and breathe in fresh air, have adequate sleep and rest, throw out the cigarettes and cut back on the alcohol—everything in moderation. We do not need to stop living but, to live and enjoy life, we need to monitor our behaviour. There is nothing wrong with a glass of red, but too many glasses of red every night and eventually one’s health will suffer.

More than half the Australian population is overweight or obese. These are shocking statistics when you consider that an estimated 1.5 million of those people are aged under 18. Childhood obesity in Australia is rising at the rate of one per cent each year, and over half of all young Australians will be overweight by 2025 unless parents, governments and the community start addressing the problem together. An overweight child often becomes an overweight adult. In fact, the AMA have said that nutrition is the key in the fight against the obesity epidemic. They launched a plan last week with some simple steps on addressing poor nutrition in babies and children, the adult population and older Australians. The steps are simple; it is basic commonsense. As a country, we need to take heed of those steps and get serious about the health of this nation.

Australians who do not take responsibility for their own health just expect that, by having access to medical goods and services, they will be fine. I wonder how many think about the long-term effects that an unhealthy lifestyle will have on them. The health system cannot fix every health problem, but the burden on the health system both in an economic and social sense is enormous. We must not give up. Through our schools and local sporting groups and community bodies we must find ways of introducing healthy lifestyle programs. We need to get our kids away from the computers and onto the playing fields. Around 40 per cent of children aged between five and 14 years of age do not participate in any organised sport.

The federal government has gone some way in addressing this situation by supporting a number of programs to help address the very real problem that will have long-term effects on a whole generation of Australians. The parliament legislated in 2004, requiring schools to include at least two hours of physical activity per week in their curriculum for children in primary and junior high schools. There are healthy eating programs supported by school canteens and education staff, but more needs to be done. The AMA has made recommendations that include the banning of selling chocolates and lollies as fundraisers and banning junk food advertising. Some people would say they are extreme measures, but it is time for extreme measures if we as a nation want to ensure the young people of this country lead healthy, happy, productive and active lives.

We also need more emphasis on preventative medicine. Our health work force needs to be skilled in delivering interventions to address the major risk factors for chronic disease such as smoking, poor nutrition, risky and high-risk alcohol use and physical inactivity. But it is not a one-way street. Quite frankly, every Australian needs to take on the personal responsibility of their health. It is not the job of governments to continually fund soaring health costs if individuals are negligent and do not heed the warnings of lifestyle choices and the impact those choices have on their short- and long-term health. This is a partnership, but I fear we have reached a time when extreme measures, or maybe even incentives, must be put in place so that individuals take control of their health today and in the future. I would like to take this opportunity of thanking my parliamentary colleagues for their contributions to this motion today.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I support the motion moved by the member for McPherson because I am also a firm believer in preventative medicine and physical activity. There is no avoiding the statistics warning us of a looming and largely preventable health crisis in Australia. We will all pay the price unless we start giving greater priority to preventative health measures—and start right now. For example, the government estimates that the cost of obesity in Australia is between $680 million and $1.239 billion per year. The AMA estimates that around 15 per cent of our children are already overweight and that that figure will increase by one per cent each year so that, by the year 2025, half of Australia’s children will be overweight. Figures for Australian adults are even worse: 58 per cent of Australian men and 42 per cent of Australian women are currently classed as overweight or obese. And, with overweight children being 50 per cent more likely to become overweight adults, this constitutes a real problem both now and into the future.

speech.para: Obesity is a risk factor for a number of diseases including diabetes, coronary heart disease, high blood pressure, stroke and cancer. To combat the increasing levels of obesity within the Australian population, Australians need to be educated about the health risks posed by obesity and the benefits of incorporating physical activity into our lives. There are numerous programs across the country aimed at increasing Australians’ physical activity levels. Today I would like to talk about a fantastic community based program which many people in the chamber will already be aware of: the 10,000 Steps program.

This program began in Rockhampton in 2001 as a Queensland Health funded whole-of-community project to encourage greater physical activity. Rockhampton was chosen as the location for a two-year trial of the program due to its residents’ typical level of activity. The program is based at Central Queensland University and has a number of other active partners throughout Rockhampton. The program has consistently shown results and has rapidly spread to many other centres across Australia. 10,000 Steps now boasts 372 providers and has logged over three billion steps. The program uses the message of 10,000 steps per day as a way to encourage people in the community to increase their physical activity levels. Participants in the program use a pedometer to measure the number of steps they take per day with an aim of consistently reaching 10,000 per day.

The 10,000 Steps Workplace Challenge has become a particularly popular program across the country with the 10,000 Steps program estimating that over 40,000 people have taken part in that element of the initiative. Indeed, several Commonwealth departments and agencies, including the tax office, Finance and Administration, Centrelink and Treasury, have taken part in the challenge. The challenge consists of workplaces organising teams who log the number of steps per day that each team takes. The goal is to increase participants’ awareness of their level of physical activity. By taking note of the number of steps they take each day as part of their normal activities, participants can see where they are deficient and need to increase their physical activity in order to maximise the health benefits.

The Rockhampton community have really gotten behind this program, and several local groups, including the Central Queensland University, the Rockhampton City Council, Queensland Health and local media outlets, have been heavily involved in promoting the program. For example, the Rockhampton City Council has established a number of walking paths around the city under the 10,000 Steps logo and has also set up a program of organised activity in local parks to encourage people to get out, get active and get moving. The 10,000 Steps program is a fantastic tool that is spreading across the country. The program shows people that physical activity does not have to be time intensive, cost a lot of money or be too strenuous. The message is clearly that everyone can do it and, echoing the member for McPherson’s remarks, everyone should do it—young or old, thin or not so thin. The point is to get out there, become aware of your health and get those 10,000 steps per day.

Physical activity is a vital part of any preventative health regime. I think that everyone would agree with the member for McPherson that it is important to try to prevent illness rather than just treat it. That very obvious point needs to be reflected in both policy development and funding priorities if we are to protect the sustainability of our health system into the future and at the same time assist Australians onto the path of a longer, healthier and happier life.

talk.start.para: —I congratulate the member for McPherson on moving this motion, and I endorse the comments of the member for Capricornia. So far we have heard from the mothers, and one of the key things in terms of return to health has been the involvement of mothers returning to health post pregnancy and looking after the early childhood years of their children in a healthy way.

speech.para: The function of protecting and developing health must rank even above that of restoring it when it is impaired, so Hippocrates said, and the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council has put together a national approach through the National Health Priority Action Council. That is made up of six volumes. The first volume is the National Chronic Disease Strategy, which is a nationally agreed strategy for taking on chronic diseases. Volume 2 is the National Service Improvement Framework for Asthma; volume 3, the National Service Improvement Framework for Cancer; volume 4, the National Service Improvement Framework for Diabetes; volume 5, the National Service Improvement Framework for Heart, Stroke and Vascular Disease; and volume 6, the National Service Improvement Framework for Osteoarthritis, Rheumatoid Arthritis and Osteoporosis.

Chronic disease is estimated by these ministers to account for nearly 70 per cent of our health spend. The behavioural and social risk factors for those chronic diseases are poor health in early childhood, tobacco smoking, risky and high-risk alcohol use, poor diet and nutrition, physical inactivity, excessive sun exposure and social isolation. Those are the things that we have to address. I endorse the motion put forward by the member for McPherson about looking at young people and those early childhood factors for a lifetime of health. In my electorate of Lindsay, the Active After-school Communities Program, funded by this government, has been introducing children from Joey’s Outside of School Hours Care to baseball, softball and T-ball, providing opportunities to child care and to schools for physical activity outside the school curriculum, which is already jam-packed with advice on drugs, alcohol and healthy eating. We are aiming to engage children with fitness and team sports to carry them through life with those activities.

Other schools in my electorate are growing vegetables and introducing breakfast programs under the Healthy School Communities program. A number of my schools have also elected to receive the $1,500 the government offers for schools to get their canteens in order. But there is only so much we can ask schools to do. At most, five meals a week are consumed in the schools. The parents must take responsibility for the rest. In doing so, we can have a lot of intervention in the early preschool years. I have advocated for a national preschool program where we involve a number of agencies to support parents with parental, nutritional and activity advice.

If the mother is returned to health post-partum, she will be an active mum. I have lost about 10 kilos in the last 12 months and, with two toddlers, it is amazing the difference it makes: you are able to actively engage with your children—with piggybacks on the beach, the old shoulder carry and the things that encourage children to be active, running and in motion all the time. When you are running and out of breath, it is important to call your children back to walk close by because, in Western Sydney, there have been a number of school kidnappings. So the way we design our cities is a social issue.

I recommend the 10,000 Steps program to the Penrith City Council. Footpaths should be designed so that people can partake of exercise in their local area. By setting up community walking programs around the local area, people can be encouraged to become physically active and less socially isolated. Physical activity should be a normal part of their day—from the age of 12 months, when you learn to walk, until you are well aged and into your active retirement years. Congratulations to the member for McPherson and all our health ministers, but I stress that more needs to be done.

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for McPherson for moving a motion that is intended to encourage the government to pursue policies which would see a greater emphasis on actions, particularly in education, which would increase the awareness and uptake of preventative health measures. It is a timely and welcome motion, but it is also a rebuke of current government policy and particularly the efforts of the Minister for Health and Ageing, Mr Abbott, who is presiding over an obesity epidemic of young people in this country but seems incapable of overcoming his ideological barriers and doing something effective and real about it.

speech.para: The urgent need for front-end health prevention can be seen in the rising costs of the health budget and health related technology. No doubt it will become increasingly important for nations to focus on preventative health in the future, especially with the high incidence of preventable diseases, including cardiovascular diseases, high cholesterol, obesity and diabetes.

I note that since 1996 federal government health spending has grown from around 15 per cent to over 20 per cent of the budget, a rise of around 3.8 per cent to 4.4 per cent of GDP. The cost imbalance of treating the endgame of poor health practice rather than investing in preventative health measures is clear. If you look at something like minimally invasive heart surgery, the costs are in the order of $3 million up front and then $2,300 for each procedure for disposable equipment that cannot ever be used again. Surely this is the wrong way to achieve effective and prudent treatment of health issues.

The member for Capricornia pointed out the health measures that are present in the community, such as 10,000 Steps, but the fact is that there has been a huge increase in obesity in Australia—from nine per cent in 1989-90 to 16 per cent in 2001. Alarmingly, the projections for 2010 suggest that at the current rate of obesity there could be 5.6 million Australians overweight—not obese, but overweight. By 2020, this could stretch to 6.3 million overweight and three million obese. These are startling figures and demand the attention of the Howard government and the health minister. If we say that the estimated growing rate of childhood obesity of one per cent a year continues, half of all young Australians will be overweight by 2025. Clearly, this is an unsatisfactory state of affairs.

I refer to the fact that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are twice as likely to be obese than non-Indigenous people. There are a number of historical factors, including the removal of children from their families, which have meant that a generation of mothers has not learnt traditional childrearing and feeding practices. A recent study shows us that 28 per cent of Indigenous low birth weight babies could be attributed to maternal malnutrition, and obesity is a factor there too.

It is time for the government to act, but it has been remiss. Labor state governments have moved to address the issue of childhood obesity, but the minister continues to blame parents for the national epidemic, washing his hands of responsibility. Parents and families for Minister Abbott exist in hermetically sealed isolation—not impacted by government policy, the commercial sector and its expertly constructed advertising campaign or the substantial budgets that go with it. I think a reasonable person would accept what Kaye Mehta, the nutrition lecturer at Flinders University, says:

quote.para: Food advertising does create increased preferences for those food products and increased pester power to their parents.

speech.para: That is why Labor supports the Australian Medical Association’s call for a nutrition survey—the last one was conducted 10 years ago—and a national nutrition centre to coordinate a national response to Australia’s obesity problem. Additionally, Labor calls on the government to conduct a national audit into junk food advertising during children’s programs, examining the impact it has on children’s health.

This is urgently needed. If the minister addressed himself to the situation that I have described—a national childhood epidemic in obesity—then it is absolutely clear that the government must act. The government’s 2004 announcement for $116 million over four years to curb Australia’s declining physical activity needs to be brought into effect now. The National Obesity Taskforce’s recommendations to understand and assess the impact of current food and drinks advertising practices on community levels of overweight and obese people need to be taken into account by the government. It is time for the federal government to accept its taskforce’s advice and do something about childhood obesity. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the motion of the member for McPherson. It is a motion that shows great wisdom on her part.

speech.para: We have many great medical professionals, but one of the most influential health practitioners is the individual themself. Many people believe that their health care starts when they see a doctor and that it is the doctor or the nurse who is somehow responsible for their health. It is a case of ‘When I’m ill, it’s “bulk-bill and pill” treatment to solve all the problems.’ There are times when we need a medical practitioner, but in reality the individual can contribute a great deal to their own health and wellbeing. It is the individual who should be taking greater responsibility for their own health by a good diet, by taking regular exercise, by drinking only in moderation and by not smoking. It is really important that we focus on preventative measures. Preventative measures create good health outcomes—preventative measures by way of education but also preventative measures by way of individuals themselves ensuring that they conduct the type of lifestyle that produces good health.

I am amazed that people persist in smoking. Figures in 1989 and 1990 showed that 28 per cent of adults smoked; by 2001 that figure had reduced, but only to 24 per cent. With regard to exercise, there was only a five per cent increase in the number of people conducting low levels of exercise between 1989 and 2001. We know what the benefits of regular exercise are, yet the uptake of exercise or the increase in exercise has been relatively modest. By taking regular exercise, people dramatically improve the health outcomes that they can achieve.

The rate of obesity has almost doubled amongst Australian adults over the last two decades. Australia is now ranked as one of the fattest developed nations, closely following the US. We are being supersized, and many people are not doing anything about it. If current trends continue, at least 60 per cent of Australians aged over 18 will be overweight or obese by 2010. That figure will increase to 65 per cent by 2020. We have already passed the point where more men are overweight or obese than are not. This is not a good scenario. Some 20 to 25 per cent of Australian children are overweight or obese. Between 1985 and 1995, the combined level of overweight and obese children more than doubled. The figures are alarming indeed. Figures on smoking, exercise and obesity show that we have a long way to go in encouraging a sense of personal responsibility with regard to health matters.

As I said before, this bulk-bill and pill approach to medicine, requiring medical practitioners to be the sole solution to the problem, just is not on. Obese people as a group receive more sickness benefits and more unemployment benefits than people within the normal weight range. I believe in the concept of a social contract. We as a community have the responsibility to provide high-quality health services. But in return for that, individuals have the responsibility to do as much as they can to preserve their own wellbeing through the measures I mentioned—not smoking, not excessively consuming alcohol and taking the appropriate amount of exercise. It is vital that there is a two-pronged approach.

This motion should be commended. It has a focus on education, putting people in the picture with all the information they need to make correct lifestyle choices—to avoid obesity and to ensure that they are conducting a healthy lifestyle—and, in doing so, to produce great outcomes for our community through reduced health care costs.

Medical technology is making huge strides in solving a whole range of problems, but we can leave more funding available for acute areas by taking care of the things that can be handled through personal responsibility. As I said, they are proper diet, regular exercise, drinking only in moderation and not smoking. The government has done a great deal in promoting those ideals, but it is very much in the hands of the individual. I believe that people have to take that personal responsibility much more seriously to ensure that we get very positive outcomes. We have an ageing population. In the future our medical resources are going to be very much focused on the more elderly people in our community. If, through a healthier lifestyle, we can produce lifelong health into old age, we can dramatically reduce the call on our health services and we can dramatically increase the availability of resources for others who could not help the situation that they were in, who could not help the condition that they had. Personal responsibility, like improved medical technology, is going to be a major driver in improved outcomes.

talk.start.para: —I would like to congratulate the member for McPherson on bringing this motion before the House. I encourage the government to act upon the motion, because I believe that she has identified some very important issues in it.

speech.para: There is no single factor that impinges more on a person’s quality of life than their health status. A person who enjoys good health has a positive outlook and a sense of wellbeing. A person who has poor health tends to have a more negative outlook, and that detracts from their sense of wellbeing.

There are many factors involved. It is multifaceted. There are many factors that influence a person’s health. There is diet—and diet starts at childhood. From the time they are born, diet plays an important role in people’s health. There is physical activity. Unfortunately, our lifestyle tends to lead to a lower level of physical activity than we previously enjoyed. Socioeconomic factors, unfortunately, also impinge upon the health status of people in Australia. People who are in lower socioeconomic groups tend to have poorer health than others. That relates to the cost of obtaining good foods and good nutrition. Other factors that impact upon a person’s health are their sense of connectedness or isolation and their psychological wellbeing. These are just a few factors that impinge upon a person’s health.

In considering this motion, I would like to focus on the epidemic that is consuming our society—the obese and overweight. It is a disease of affluence. Worldwide there are one billion people who are overweight. There are only 792 million who suffer from malnutrition. That is quite a telling factor. Most of those one billion people can be found in affluent countries.

Obesity leads to high blood pressure, liver disease, type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. I looked at what the Heart Foundation had to say and found that 37.6 per cent of all deaths in Australia were caused by heart disease, stroke and cardiovascular disease. There are 3.67 million Australians affected by cardiovascular disease, while 1.10 million Australians are disabled long term by cardiovascular disease. The prevalence of cardiovascular disease has increased by 18.2 per cent over the last decade. This can be really closely associated with obesity.

Last week the AMA released a paper that highlighted the importance of good nutrition and the impact obesity was having in Australia. It pointed out that childhood obesity is increasing by one per cent a year, and it gave some strategies for addressing this. Babies should be solely breastfed, where possible, for at least the first six months of their lives. School canteens should not profit from selling junk food. Vending machines within schools should not be able to stock anything other than water. Selling chocolates and lollies as fundraisers should be banned. All junk food advertising should be banned. I think it is very important that we are very mindful of the impact on children of the advertisements shown with children’s programs on television.

The federal government funds a program to improve the nutritional status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women, especially women under 20 who are pregnant and breastfeeding and women with children. I think that program needs to be extended.

talk.start.para: (Mr Lindsay)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. The member for Shortland will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—I grieve today for those who experience mental illness and for the carers and companions of those who experience mental illness in this country. It is not as though this subject is unfamiliar to this House or to any level of government but, in light of the horrendous cost of untreated mental illness and uncared for mental illness in this country, something that continues to disturb me is the number of our fellow citizens who are committing suicide or leading lost lives—and the terrible costs to the carers of those with mental illness in the community.

speech.para: In 1993, there was a groundbreaking study and report by the then Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin. It spoke about mental illness, about how those with mental illness were being treated and about the stigma associated with mental illness. Primarily as a consequence of that report, two good federal government programs have arisen. Two other reports have followed that 1993 report—Out of hospital, out of mind, an excellent report by the Australian Mental Health Council; and the most recent report by that same council, in conjunction with the Human Rights Commissioner, called, interestingly, Not for service: experiences of injustice and despair in mental health care in Australia.

With respect to Not for service and its recommendations, the report really hits the nail on the head when it talks about why governments of all persuasions must take some level of responsibility for fixing this community disaster. I will read from the executive summary of Not for service, which is the latest report to be commissioned into the state of mental health in this country:

quote.para: What this cumulative data shows is that after 12 years of mental health reform in Australia, any person seeking mental health care runs the serious risk that his or her basic needs will be ignored, trivialised or neglected. The adverse health, social and economic effects of Australia’s mental health care system falls largely on those with recurrent or chronic disorders and their families and carers. These are some of the most vulnerable people in our community.

In the short-term, the system as it currently operates may result in a failure to provide basic medical and psychological health care, inappropriate use of short term seclusion, confinement or over-reliance on sedating medications. Longer-term, the impact may include deteriorating mental health and wellbeing, suicide, higher rates of homelessness, prolonged unemployment, incarceration or increased financial burden and poverty. Failure to attend to the urgent needs of those with severe mental disorders on a systemic basis may also lead to infringements of the wider rights of the community to reside in a safe and secure environment. For many people, ongoing financial and personal support from family and friends is the only real safeguard against these outcomes.

speech.para: These are stories that we heard 12 years ago. Given the problem with the provision of mental health services in this country acknowledged in this latest report, it is incumbent upon us as legislators in this place—and people that provide funding to health systems in some ways, particularly to the mental health system—to do something.

I understand that as a consequence of this report the Prime Minister has given an undertaking to raise this matter at COAG. I would like to point out that this is a national priority. In 2001, 2,454 persons died by suicide. Virtually all those deaths occurred as a consequence of mental illness. So it is not as though we have a lot of time. We do not have time, because the more time we spend not addressing this particular situation the more people are dying in this country. In a fair-minded country—and a country that professes to look after its most vulnerable—we cannot stand here as legislators, as a government and an opposition, and say that we have done enough. We have to do more.

Speaking about statistics: currently, for example, I think as a consequence of the lack of funding across all levels of government for mental health services, 62 per cent of people with mental health disorders do not actually access services. Most of the 38 per cent of people who do access services will seek treatment by a general practitioner. There are a lot of people who are literally dying in this country because they cannot get access for appropriate treatment, services and care. I say in this place that we cannot accept that.

We speak about statistics—we talk about, say, the fact that one in five people have a mental illness in this country. I would like to read you the story of someone who could not get access to the treatment that she needed and what sort of effect it had on her. I have been told that I can tell this story but obviously not relate this person’s name. This was a person who sought a treatment that had been successful at a psychiatric facility in the south-eastern suburbs of Melbourne but who was told that she could not continue to get that treatment because of funding cuts. She says:

quote.para: A cloud of depression has enfolded me. I have been fighting so hard, trying to think positive and trying to keep busy and exercise, telling myself it will pass ...
Everything is too hard—I am scared, frustrated and sad, my head is going round and round. I can’t turn it off—everything is too worrying.

speech.para: This individual has a psychotic disorder. She continues:

quote.para: I have tried, I can’t do it. I want to slip away quietly. I love—

speech.para: this particular person—

quote.para: with all my heart. I don’t want to hurt them, but my feelings are too overwhelming ... I need to turn off permanently. It’s got to the stage where I can’t keep a lid on things ... It’s time to end this turmoil. I have to turn everything off.

speech.para: This is where, I am afraid, it gets a little bit difficult:

quote.para: I tried to suffocate myself for 1 hour in bed this afternoon with a big rubbish bag ... It didn’t work. I was so upset. I wanted to go off in the car, attach a hose and drift off to sleep ...

speech.para: But she could not actually do it. She continues:

quote.para: Please everyone know that I did try extra extra hard, but I failed ...

speech.para: This person, in this state in this country—what are we doing as a fair minded country? Whilst this is a horrendous situation, this person has now been able to access appropriate treatment and is well. So the fact is that, if people in this country who cannot get access to treatment and are contemplating killing themselves, as I have read in this place, do get access to treatment, they can restore their lives. Many of those with psychotic disorders are untreated because of the stigma, because of the lack of access to services. Very effective treatments are available, provided governments of all levels appropriately fund the services.

The other thing is to basically talk about it, because it is still one of the taboo subjects in this society. There are many issues that you read about in magazines; you can read about virtually everything. But one of the things that you consistently do not read about is mental illness and the cost to the community. It is not a sexy story. It is not a quick fix story. It is not a story that you can splash on page 3 in a bikini. But it is a story that affects every level of this community and every layer of government.
Now I have spoken quickly about someone who is experiencing mental illness, I want to speak of the despair of someone who is a carer of a person with mental illness. She says:

quote.para: I have witnessed and been subjected to a distinct lack of understanding of mental illness, a distinct lack of compassion for mental illness, a distinct lack of care towards the relatives and sufferers of this illness, and most disturbingly, a distinct lack of adequate and appropriate facilities for the sufferers of this illness.

The plight of a carer of a mentally ill person is fraught with much unpleasantness: heartache, sorrow, sadness, worry, misgivings, fear of and for the future, fear of being labelled, fear of being ostracised ... In short, the path we carers travel is all too often intolerable, insufferable and at times inhumane.

speech.para: It is time that we in this place actually make a commitment to do something. I ask—in fact, I beg—the Prime Minister to convene this summit, to make it a priority issue. The longer that we leave this issue untreated, in the way we have in our community, more of our citizens are going to die, more people are going to be untreated, more lives will be lost to mental illness. In this country, we just cannot allow that to continue.

talk.start.para: —When I consider the most important issues facing communities in my electorate, roads are without a doubt one of the main priorities. For all towns, but in particular for towns like Gloucester, Dungog or Forster-Tuncurry, roads keep their economies alive. They need the infrastructure for agricultural business, to attract tourists and to keep jobs going. Since 1996 the Australian government has provided the electorate of Paterson with $295.8 million in Roads of National Importance funding; $8.7 million in national black spot funding; $142.3 million in financial assistance grants to local councils; and $7.8 million in Roads to Recovery funding.

speech.para: But when I look back on 2005 it is with great disappointment that I look at the appalling way that roads have been managed, resourced and funded by the New South Wales government. The Commonwealth provides the states with funding for roads and it is then the states who manage them—and, in the case of New South Wales, it is the Roads and Traffic Authority who manage the roadworks. To say that I have been appalled by the management of some projects in my electorate would be an understatement. The Pacific Highway and Weakleys Drive are two of particular note.

But I have also been angered by the failure of the New South Wales government to match Commonwealth funding of $10 million for local roads, as budgeted for under AusLink. When you consider the debacle of the cross-city tunnel in Sydney and the millions of dollars it has cost, taxpayers in my electorate can quite rightly question why it is that money is not going to their projects from the state government. In the case of the Australian government’s commitment of $10 million to specific roads in Paterson, a matching contribution of $10 million from the state would greatly assist local councils in the upgrade and maintenance of important regional roads. The funding is earmarked for the Dungog Shire, for the Dungog to Clarence Town road; the Clarence Town to Raymond Terrace Road, which also crosses into the Port Stephens Shire; the Dungog to Paterson road in the Dungog Shire; and the Lakes Way in the Great Lakes Shire. To bring these roads up to scratch, all levels of government need to make an extra contribution in funding. The Commonwealth have put money on the table and, to date, we have heard nothing from the New South Wales roads minister, Joe Tripodi.

Take the case of the Bucketts Way, which links the Pacific Highway to the New England area and goes through towns like Stroud, Gloucester and Kramback and all the way to Taree. The Australian government are investing $20 million over four years into this road, and we are currently into the third year of funding. This money is on top of any federal funding that councils receive from the Roads to Recovery program, the black spot program or the Financial Assistance Grants Scheme.

The funding has made a considerable difference to the quality of the road. Anyone who has ever driven on the Bucketts Way will appreciate the enormity of this upgrade task. The road falls across four council areas and covers terrain that is very hilly and winding—but very beautiful country at that. Once again, the state government has not matched funding on this project. The Commonwealth had no responsibility for injecting extra funds into the upgrade, but it understood that it was the right thing to do for the community.

Another project that I have fought hard to obtain funding for is the Weakleys Drive intersection on the New England Highway. The Australian government has committed $25 million to finalising this project, which involves the construction of a flyover on Weakleys Drive to carry traffic unimpeded in both directions along the New England Highway. Weakleys Drive will extend over the New England Highway via a new section of road, connecting it directly to the Thornton-Beresfield link road. Traffic lights will be installed on Weakleys Drive at the intersection below the highway to provide for safe turning movements for traffic to and from the highway.

While I had hoped that, in this the second year of funding, construction would have already started, we found out in May this year that the RTA had not finalised their planning. As a result, only a further $5 million was allocated to the project in this year’s budget to complete the process of design, development and land purchases. I have been advised by the minister’s office this week that a stage 3 project report for construction will be delivered to the department in January next year, and tenders are expected to be called in the following months of February or March. So I hope that 2006 will finally herald the start of construction of the long-awaited Weakleys Drive project and that ongoing delays with planning will finally be overcome.

Also of particular interest to me is the Pacific Highway. Last week there was a horrific accident which claimed the lives of four people from one Maitland family. It occurred between the Tea Gardens turnoff and Bulahdelah. The crash happened when the car carrying the Maitland family, which was southbound, veered onto the other side of the highway, colliding with another vehicle. No-one was killed in the second vehicle, but passengers from Bulahdelah did sustain some very serious injuries and are in hospital recovering. As police have said, the site of the accident was not known as a dangerous section of the highway and was in fact a straight corridor with three lanes. Only time will tell why this accident occurred, when the results of an investigation are known.

Unfortunately, when there is an accident on the Pacific Highway, finger pointing and squabbling seem to be the order of the day. To my mind, it is completely disrespectful for politicians to start waving their fingers at each other when families and communities are grieving for their loss and investigations have not been completed. This is also fuelled by sections of the media who do not understand jurisdictions when it comes to road responsibilities, nor respect when it comes to the fatalities that occur.

Perhaps when the construction of a dual carriageway on the Pacific Highway is completed, this debate will be over, but until such time I will continue to fight for priority to be given to specific road projects that my community wants. Of particular concern on the Pacific Highway is the turnoff to Tea Gardens. Anyone who drives past this intersection will see a great deal of work currently under way, but unfortunately it does not include a flyover. For a very long time now, the community, headed by Patricia Michelle, have been calling for a flyover to be included in this roadwork design, similar to the flyover at Karuah, to enable traffic moving on and off the highway to do so in a safe manner.

We lobbied the federal roads minister about the project, who then wrote to the New South Wales roads minister, asking for a design and the cost of the flyover project to be canvassed. Hundreds of people from Tea Gardens and Hawks Nest rallied on the steps of Parliament House in Sydney, calling on the state government to build a flyover, yet to date no-one has seen a report detailing possible designs or costings from the RTA. The state government, in their usual arrogant way, have dismissed community concerns. The silence from John Bartlett, the member for Port Stephens, has been deafening. At the next election he will take over the Tea Gardens-Hawks Nest area. His only response is that this area is not in his electorate yet—and, with a response like that, I doubt it will be in his electorate!

When it comes to the Pacific Highway, I make no apology for lobbying all levels of government to build a dual carriageway in my electorate, just like federal members north of me all the way to and beyond the Queensland border do. I have welcomed the increase in funding from the Australian government under the AusLink proposal, which recognises the importance of upgrading the road as soon as possible. The government has increased funding from $60 million to $160 million per year, and over the next three years both the Australian and the New South Wales governments will provide $480 million for the upgrade.

There has been significant progress made in the Paterson electorate so far. Completed projects include the Raymond Terrace bypass, Raymond Terrace to Karuah, the Karuah bypass, Bulahdelah to Coolongolook, Coolongolook to Wang Wauk and Wang Wauk to Bundacree Creek. There are two projects now under construction. One is the $114 million construction of section 1 of the Karuah to Bulahdelah upgrade, which will provide 11 kilometres of dual carriageway from the Karuah bypass to just south of Viney Creek Road. Construction has also started on the $115 million Bundacree Creek to Possum Brush section, which is 23 kilometres south of Taree. It will provide 9.7 kilometres of new four-lane divided freeway, including an interchange serving Nabiac. Twin two-lane bridges will be constructed over the Wallamba River to replace the existing narrow bridge. Planning is also under way for two further projects, being the F3 link to Raymond Terrace and the Bulahdelah upgrade. We need to upgrade the Pacific Highway to a dual carriageway as quickly as possible. Certainly, the accident last week has again highlighted why it is that the Karuah to Bulahdelah section must be made a priority. I understand that the state minister announced last week that tenders will be called.

One of the most frustrating aspects of being a member of the federal parliament is that, whilst the Australian government provides funding for the Pacific Highway, it is the state government who prioritises the work, and the Pacific Highway is actually a state road. In an effort to expedite the construction of a dual carriageway, the Australian government agreed some time ago to increase their level of funding support. As I said earlier, we now have an agreement where both levels of government will be paying $480 million each over the next three years.

This is an investment into road infrastructure that has to be made. Most importantly, priority has to be given to those areas on the highway which are known to be the sites of frequent accidents. The concerns of local communities have to be heard. This is a topic that I am very passionate about, and I do not apologise for banging on the doors of all levels of government to try to have this completed as quickly as possible. This year the federal government will have a $14 billion surplus. I call on the government to invest some of that money—to be matched by the state governments—in infrastructure development like the Pacific Highway under an AusLink proposal. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Article 6 of the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights states:

quote.para: Every human being has the inherent right to life. This right shall be protected by law. No one shall be arbitrarily deprived of his life.

speech.para: The Australian Van Nguyen was hanged on Friday, December 2 by the government of Singapore after pleas for clemency by this parliament, by the government and by many others were declined. Singapore’s mandatory death sentence must now come under closer scrutiny because government sponsored execution of a human being is a crime against humanity and a breach of the UN convention. As such, Singapore stands condemned for the wilful deprivation of human life.

Certainly Van Nguyen’s grotesque punishment was absurdly disproportionate to his crime. No amount of spin on the part of the government of Singapore can disguise the fact that this is a government with attitudes and practices towards punishment of crimes that are archaic and barbaric. Singapore is one of the world’s leaders in the execution of people, and my condemnation of its actions is not reserved for the execution of Van Nguyen alone but extended to the killing of other foreigners as well as of the citizens of Singapore.

When Prime Minister Lee explained his refusal to grant clemency, he said that he was aware of the seriousness of the matter and was therefore making his decision knowing that he would be accountable for his actions. But the question is: who is he accountable to? The organs of accountability do not appear to work independently of government in Singapore.
