Reporters Without Borders have ranked Singapore’s press freedom 149th out of 167 in its 2005 world press index. Singapore’s former Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong attacked this report by saying:

quote.para: It is a subjective measure computed through the prism of western liberals.

speech.para: Such dismissiveness is typical of this government, which argues that its draconian laws and control of the media are necessary to ensure its stability. Suppressing freedom of the press, and in fact government control of the media and journalists, is a sure sign of a government desperately trying to maintain its rule by the use of totalitarian practices that are inconsistent with the principles of accountability and freedom of speech. State control of people’s rights to congregate and protest without a permit, draconian laws and the quashing of dissenting voices through the use of fear and repercussion are certainly characteristic of a totalitarian regime and are, again, inconsistent with the values and practices of our Australian democracy.

I want to join with the many Australians who have come together to offer support to the Nguyen family and in particular to Van’s mother, Kim. I want to concur with the statement by Father Peter Hansen that he was proud of the compassion shown by the Australian people. Like most Australians who have been horrified by this barbaric act, I do not know the Nguyen family personally. But I deeply empathise with their tragic circumstances and in particular with Van’s mother. As a mother myself, I know she will endure an unspeakable grief. I offer her my condolences and I know that she will find comfort in the compassion and the humanity of the people who have come to her aid—everyone from her lawyers to the staff of the Australian High Commission in Singapore, to friends, to the Australian public and to the caring hands of the Catholic Church, amongst them Father Peter Hansen, who leads the Catholic Church congregation in Craigieburn in my electorate of Calwell.

I am aware that there are many Australians who were supportive of Van Nguyen’s execution. It is easy for people to be unforgiving and to loathe those who they believe by their actions perpetuate the misery of drug abuse. But we must never allow such feelings to cause us to lose sight of our humanity. I cannot therefore agree with those who support capital punishment. Putting aside all the moral and legal arguments that militate against the use of capital punishment, for me personally it is a simple case of a profound belief that no human being has the right to take the life of another under any circumstances. I particularly derive this conviction from my own Christian faith, which preaches the sanctity and dignity of life and the power of forgiveness and mercy. I know this to be an absolute truth applicable in all circumstances without exception.

Particularly indefensible, therefore, is the case of Singapore and, might I say, the other 74 countries in the world—including the United States, which I understand has just hanged its 1,000th prisoner—who retain and employ the use of capital punishment. State sanctioned or judicial killing is immoral and senseless because it is wilfully employed and sanctioned by governments, some of which claim to uphold the highest standards of democracy and are at the forefront of defending human rights violations in places other than their own backyards.

Singapore in particular must answer to the claims put forward by many that there is an inherent contradiction between their hardline stand on punishment for drug smugglers, on the one hand, and, on the other hand, their alleged tolerance of Burmese businesses operating out of Singapore and, indeed, of known Burmese drug lords frequently moving into and out of Singapore. If these allegations are true then the government of Singapore are guilty of gross hypocrisy and double standards, making their mandatory death penalty regime even more outrageous and indecent and a perfect example of why the fear of capital punishment will never succeed in eradicating drug abuse or obstructing the global movement of narcotics. It appears that the big players are rarely caught and punished, and it also appears that some may even enjoy the hospitality and tolerance of governments who purport to be tough on drugs.

The execution of Van Nguyen and the issue of capital punishment will continue to confront and to challenge our civility both as individuals and as a nation for some time to come, particularly as we await the fate of other Australians facing death penalties abroad, including the Bali nine. We are a democratic country that long ago abolished capital punishment because we realised it to be barbaric and inhumane. We believe in the rehabilitation of those who transgress and commit crimes, and we are a fair-minded people who believe in the principle that the punishment must fit the crime. As such, I would like to support Amnesty International’s growing global campaign calling for the end of the death penalty. I would also like to welcome and support former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser’s calls, and those of Nguyen’s lawyer, Lex Lasry, for Australia to become an advocate for the abolition of capital punishment.

However, it is not enough to run such a campaign only at a people-to-people level, even though history does teach us that the drive for change always begins at the grassroots and is then followed by politicians and governments; such a campaign should also transact at a government-to-government level. There are ways that this could be done and we, as a parliament, should be exploring them. I know there have been many calls, in particular from the public, for the government to link the issue of human rights with trade. That in itself, I understand and acknowledge, is a difficult issue; nevertheless, it is one that may need to be considered.

As I said earlier, I did not know Van Nguyen, but he was a young man who had much to live for. He made a mistake for which, unfortunately, he paid with his life. Common human decency, however, tells us that this young man’s punishment far outweighed the severity of his crime. His death was therefore senseless and cruel. Although it should serve as a warning to other young Australians, unfortunately it will not, such is the cold reality of the lucrative world of drug merchandising. For me and other Australians, the Van Nguyen tragedy serves not only to remind us of the fragility of human life but more importantly to reaffirm the need to uphold the sanctity and the dignity of human life. We have a duty and particular governments have a duty to preserve, protect and, indeed, uphold every human being’s inherent right to life. Capital punishment is a violation of that right and we must fight for its abolition.

In conclusion, on Friday many Australians expressed their grief in many ways. A former university professor of mine sent an email to me and no doubt to other people. It is a poem written by a very prominent Greek poet, CP Cavafy. It is about a young man who was executed by hanging and is headed ‘27 June 1906, 2 pm’. I would like to dedicate this poem to the memory of Van Nguyen. It reads:

quote.para: When the Christians brought him to the gallows,
that seventeen-year-old guileless boy,
his mother, grovelling and writhing
in the dust nearby
under the fierce midday sun,
now whined and howled like a wolf, like a wild beast,
and now, exhausted by her martyrdom, lamented:
‘Just seventeen years is all you lived for me, my child.’

speech.para: (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last Wednesday, a scathing 538-page report into the Dr Death scandal was presented to the Premier of Queensland by Commissioner Geoff Davies. This report is the result of a six-month $6 million inquiry that was undertaken at the request of the Premier after allegations that India-trained surgeon Dr Patel was linked to the deaths of more than 80 patients at the Bundaberg Base Hospital. The report is damning. It is damning of a health system that has been out of control and inadequately funded and which has operated under a culture of secrecy. The report said that the former health minister, Gordon Nuttall, had hidden information about a report into Dr Patel, which was ‘at best naive and at worst disingenuous’. The report states:

quote.para: Such misconduct was misleading, unreasonable and careless.

speech.para: This long-awaited report does not reflect the heartache, the tears and the suffering of so many patients who have survived to tell their horrific stories—stories where patient care was compromised and elective surgery was less than adequate and certainly, in many cases, not safe.

It is important to put on the record how this inquiry came about. In fact, if it was not for one very brave intensive care nurse, Ms Toni Hoffman, this inquiry might never have taken place. But Ms Hoffman, to her credit, blew the whistle. She took her concerns about Dr Patel and the treatment of patients at the Bundaberg Base Hospital to her local MP, Mr Rob Messenger, who detailed her concerns in the state parliament. Ms Hoffman gave damning evidence to the inquiry. She told how she had repeatedly tried to raise her concerns with hospital management and senior doctors but had gotten nowhere. Her courage and compassion on behalf of her patients is to be commended. If she had not taken her concerns to her local member, we might never have heard the true story of the state of Queensland Health.

When the report was delivered last week, Toni Hoffman was at work in her job as nurse unit manager in Bundaberg’s intensive care unit. She said that she and fellow ICU nurses welcomed the charges that had been recommended against Dr Patel and their former bosses, Darren Keating and Peter Leck. Toni Hoffman has been vindicated. Her concerns about the cover-up of Dr Patel have been borne out in the report. Mr Davies found Dr Keating and Mr Leck had displayed a ‘gross dereliction of duty’ in not investigating complaints against Dr Patel. The report recommends that Dr Keating be referred to the Australian Federal Police over allegedly knowingly or recklessly giving false information to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs over Dr Patel’s application for a four-year visa. It also recommends that Dr Keating be prosecuted for official misconduct. As for Mr Leck, the report found that he had failed to check Dr Patel’s qualifications. Dr Patel had been banned from practising in Oregon and New York. In addition, Mr Leck’s failure to suspend Dr Patel may constitute a disciplinary breach that would warrant dismissal.

This inquiry opened on 23 May 2005 and finished with the final report being handed to the Premier on 30 November 2005. Tony Morris QC was the first commissioner to oversee the inquiry; however, he was sacked after 50 days and 85 witnesses by a Supreme Court ruling of apprehended bias. After being dismissed from the inquiry, Mr Morris provided the federal Standing Committee on Health and Ageing with a 33-page submission cataloguing a plethora of systemic problems, serious dysfunction at Bundaberg Base Hospital and a shocking culture of concealment in the bureaucracy. Mr Morris urged that a rapid response team investigate serious clinical problems in Queensland, that there be a review of pay scales for doctors and nurses, and the re-education of bureaucrats to ensure that they were effective rather than remote and aloof. In his report to the standing committee, Mr Morris said:

quote.para: One of the most urgent needs was honesty about the limitations of the public health sector ... what occurred at Bundaberg is not itself the disease—it is merely an acute symptom of a condition which is chronic, widespread and potentially terminal.

speech.para: Those are damning statements about the Queensland health system. And what now for the former health minister Gordon Nuttall? We know that several bureaucrats were advised last week that they will face criminal charges or disciplinary action, but their former boss, Gordon Nuttall, has shrugged off the scathing findings on his behaviour and until late last week had his bags packed for an all-expenses-paid, 10-day, taxpayer funded jaunt to Brazil and the United States. Even worse, he was going with the blessing of the Premier. But the trip has now been cancelled, and so it should be. The Premier has refused to sack this minister, despite the commissioner describing his conduct as ‘misleading, unreasonable and careless’.

Gordon Nuttall himself should do the honourable thing and resign. He was the minister in charge. He was aware of what was going on. His departmental staff will pay the ultimate price. He should fall on his sword and take full responsibility for what happened in Queensland Health. Ultimately the buck stops with the minister. Mr Nuttall has rejected all claims made against him in the report in a statement to parliament. This is a man who is currently being investigated by the Crime and Misconduct Commission over allegations that he lied to a parliamentary committee over his knowledge of problems with overseas-trained doctors.

Key recommendations made by Commissioner Geoff Davies in the report include charging Dr Patel with manslaughter and assault, charging him with assault occasioning bodily harm, charging him with negligent acts causing harm and charging him with fraud. It has been reported that relatives of patients who died at the hands of Dr Patel, and the living victims of the botched operations of the so-called Dr Death, are delighted at the charges recommended against him. However, the patients and their families will not experience complete closure to this horrific chapter in their lives until Dr Patel is extradited from the United States to face prosecution in Queensland.

There is no doubt that we have in Queensland a crumbling health system and a premier and a government who will not accept responsibility for the situation we now find ourselves in, even with a damning report—an extensive report—that highlights the grossly inadequate and underfunded public health system, a system that has let down the people of Queensland. They have not enjoyed for many years a safe and effective health system that they can have faith in.

Instead, the finger pointing has begun—the blame game, a game that the Premier plays very well: hand on heart, ‘I will fix the problem; we are an open and accountable government.’ But of course he claims to have been underfunded by none other than the Commonwealth government. Premier Beattie is a master of shifting blame, particularly to the Commonwealth, for the underfunding, but the truth is that the most recent data clearly shows in a June 2005 report that the gap in the underfunding of Queensland public hospitals is growing. Queensland’s recurrent expenditure per person on public hospitals in 2004 was still the lowest in Australia, at $440, which is below the national average of $552 per person. As for the remuneration rates for doctors, Queensland Health specialist rates are low by Queensland and Australian standards. It is no wonder that we have experienced a severe shortage of doctors in Queensland. Now the Premier is on a recruiting drive to encourage doctors back to Queensland, and it is about time.

Gold Coast City has also experienced severe cutbacks as a direct result of a dysfunctional health system, a health system that has been ignored for years and starved of funding, with waiting lists that continue to grow for elective surgery. Only recently I spoke in this House about the blow-out in the number of patients waiting for elective surgery and the shutdown of the cancer treatment ward at the Gold Coast Hospital. Oncology services have been suspended and patients now have to travel to Brisbane—another indictment of the Beattie government.

The Queensland government must be made to answer for the mess the health system is in. The abominable delivery of health services in Queensland has cost lives, and there is nothing as yet to indicate that conditions will improve. This government has put the lives of its citizens at risk, and one would hope that this report will see an end to that culture.

There is absolutely no reason for this state government to short-change its citizens on health care. The Beattie government has received record amounts of funding under the Australian health care agreement. The Commonwealth will spend $42 billion on public hospitals over five years, and $8 billion of that budget will go to Queensland to assist with providing public hospital services to public patients. So one would have to ask: where are these dollars being spent? Why isn’t the state government delivering adequate and safe health services for all Queenslanders? There is also the GST bucket of funding, a growth tax that has seen record dollars delivered to Queensland. In 2004-05 the Beattie government received $7.328 billion. No state has benefited more from the GST arrangements than Queensland.

In Queensland we have experienced boom times with boom revenue, but where has it gone? It certainly has not gone into our health system. With our growing population, it is important to make the right decisions for Queensland’s future, but it would appear that we are moving backwards. Premier Beattie only recently said: ‘Our government are the No. 1 economic managers in the country—ahead of any other state or territory.’ It would appear that Queenslanders are paying a very high price for Premier Beattie’s shallow and bungling style of economic management that does not deliver.

In conclusion, I want to pay tribute to all those involved in exposing the Dr Death scandal. Their courage to speak out will undoubtedly deliver a safer public health system to our state. To those who lost loved ones: I hope your pain diminishes. To those who are left bearing the scars: I wish you well and hope you recover to lead productive lives, free of pain and suffering. This era in Queensland politics has been a nightmare. I hope we can now move on and put this incredible chapter in Queensland history behind us. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I recently received a number of letters from a group of year 7 girls at Kilbreda College in Mentone in my electorate. Lucinda Bishop, Emily Johnston, Taylor Wilcox, Beck Crowe, Alisi Falevai, Nicole Agapitos, Stephanie Hay, Marissa Moro, Lydia Honan, Michelle Mah and their teacher Louise Harms wrote to ask me to encourage my fellow parliamentarians and the government to help make poverty history. These girls have been studying experiences of poverty from around the world. Many of the girls were shocked by the enormous gap in living standards between First and Third World countries. The girls were inspired in their studies by the grassroots energy generated by the Make Poverty History campaign.

speech.para: Sadly, Australia lags far behind many developed countries in its pursuit of the eight Millennium Development Goals which are at the core of the campaign. One of the goals is a target of 0.7 per cent of gross national income to be spent on foreign aid by developed countries by 2015. Australia’s aid level remains at an embarrassingly low level of about 0.25 per cent of GNI.

In writing to me, one of the girls, Nicole, asked a question I would like everyone in this House to consider. She asked: ‘Are we really doing everything or is there more? If there is, why aren’t we doing it?’ I found myself quite moved by the sincerity and emotion of the girls, which comes through very clearly in their letters. It is a pity that time constraints prevent me from reading more of their letters here.

We are approaching Make Poverty History White Band Day, which is on 10 December. Now is the time to renew our commitment and to redouble our efforts. The girls of Kilbreda College are doing whatever they can to make poverty history. It is to our national shame that the same cannot be said of every member of this House. We can and must do better in our contribution to this very achievable aim. I join the girls of Kilbreda in saying that it is time to get serious: we can make poverty history.

I recently met with a constituent who has campaigned for many years to promote a greater understanding of a heavily stigmatised and often mismanaged disease: Huntington’s disease. Jim Rutherford lost his first wife, his mother-in-law, four sisters-in-law and his youngest son to Huntington’s disease. His eldest son is now in the final stages of the disease. Huntington’s is a genetically inherited, rapidly acting degenerative brain disease. It tends to hit sufferers in early middle age, and its effects can be similar to Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s. Sadly, specialised care for Huntington’s sufferers is almost nonexistent and they are often placed in aged-care facilities. Given that management of the disease involves intensive mental and physical stimulation, aged-care facilities are entirely inappropriate for Huntington’s sufferers.

Mr Rutherford explained to me how frustrated he has been over the years in his efforts to raise awareness of this problem in political circles and in the wider community. Recent scientific developments have given some hope to sufferers; however, a cure for the disease is still many years away. Until that day comes, it is essential that, as a community, we give greater understanding and more effective support to the thousands of Huntington’s carriers in our midst and to the many thousands who are destined to battle the disease.

Isaacs has been short-changed a number of times in recent weeks and will be short-changed on an ongoing basis once some particularly nasty bits of legislation have been passed. Isaacs has been short-changed, firstly, because I have been gagged from speaking on three out of four critical pieces of legislation that have recently been before this House. I was gagged from speaking on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005, on the Employment and Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (Welfare to Work and Other Measures) Bill 2005 and on the Anti-Terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2005. I was lucky that I had already spoken on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Work Choices) Bill 2005 when the government gagged that debate. Many of my colleagues have not had the opportunity to represent their electorates in any of these important debates. The second ‘short-change’ is ahead for many people in Isaacs, who will be short-changed once the Work Choices and the Welfare to Work legislation kick in.

I would like to spend some time talking about the issues around the Welfare to Work legislation. The essence of this bill is that the government plans to move people from one form of welfare payment to another cheaper form—that is, those who are already under financial strain will have their incomes reduced. There are no real plans to actually help people move into work. The kindest thing that can be said is that the government is naive and thinks that a lower income will encourage people to look for work. Those of us with a better grip on reality know that most people on the DSP and on the sole parent payment are already working if they can.

For those on the DSP, there are many barriers to finding suitable work, and these measures will make life even more difficult for those already under considerable financial stress. There are a number of myths circulating about the DSP, and these need to be debunked before a sensible discussion can be had about it. The Australian Council of Social Service issued an excellent document in January this year that set out 10 myths and facts about the DSP. I recommend this document to anybody interested in learning a bit more about it. Three of these myths are as follows. The first is that many people on DSP do not have ‘real’ disabilities, just ‘bad backs’. The second is that people who can work part time do not have a ‘real’ disability and should not be on the DSP. The third is that Australia has more people on disability payments than do comparable countries. The facts are that people only get the DSP if they have a severe disability that has been assessed by medical or other experts chosen by Centrelink. People with poor vision or hearing or who use wheelchairs are not the only ones with disabilities that stop them from working full time. For example, over one-quarter of DSP recipients have a mental illness. If your only problem is a back condition, you have to be in almost constant pain or be unable to sit or move around properly to get the DSP. Many people, such as multiple sclerosis sufferers and people with recurring mental illnesses, are able to work part time but cannot hold down a full-time job. Allowing these people to keep the pension while they work part time, as the present DSP rules allow, is sensible because it encourages DSP recipients to look for work. About five per cent of Australians of work force age are on the DSP, which is around the average for wealthier OECD countries.

One of the myths that regularly bobs up is that single parents are all young girls intent on having babies in order to get onto welfare and live an easy life ever after. Those of us with children know that that is a bit of a myth in itself. The facts are that the majority of single parents are aged between 30 and 50 years, less than three per cent are teenagers and 45 per cent of single parenting payment recipients who have school-aged children work. The barriers to single parents working include a lack of education. Sixty per cent of those who are not working have education only to year 10, 20 per cent have recently experienced violence and five to 10 per cent will have moved in the last year.

I would be more convinced about the government’s stated intentions if there were any sign of positive help being offered to those on the DSP or sole parent payment. The rationale of the government seems to be that DSP recipients and sole parents are rorting the system and that a big stick will sort them out. Let us look at the DSP compared with Newstart. I am grateful to the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling for providing the following information. Currently a DSP recipient receives $257 per week compared with the Newstart allowance which is $211 per week—a difference of $46 per week. DSP recipients can earn $64 of income before payments are reduced; Newstart recipients, $31—a difference of $33 per week. The DSP cuts out once private income reaches $706 per week; Newstart cuts out at $398 per week—a massive difference of $308 per week.

Now let us look at the parenting payment single. These figures are based on a person with one child. Currently the PPS is $257 per week. The Newstart payment would be $228, a difference of $29 per week. The amount a parent can earn before payments are reduced is $76. On Newstart it will be $31, a difference of $45 per week. The difference in the cut-out point—the point beyond which the payment stops—is a private income of $718 per week for those on the PPS compared with Newstart’s $426, a huge difference of $292 per week.

We hear about a thing called the effective marginal tax rate. This is the rate at which someone moving from welfare to work loses on each dollar they earn because of the combination of income tax and reducing social security benefits. The effective marginal tax rate for DSP and parenting payment single recipients moving into work from Newstart will be in the range of 70 to 80 per cent. We have heard a lot of talk lately about an argument that a marginal income tax rate for higher income earners of 47c is a disincentive to those seeking more work. If we are going to accept that argument, why on earth are we asking those moving between welfare and work to accept an effective tax rate of 70 to 80 per cent? And we forget the extra costs that come with going to work—the bus fare, child care and buying a clean shirt to wear to work.

Labor supports real welfare reform. We believe that people who can work should and that those who cannot work should be supported, and we recognise the value of looking after young children. Labor wants real reform that tackles the reason someone is not working and that delivers practical solutions.

talk.start.para: —I take this opportunity to speak today about a number of issues which are having a significant impact on constituents in the Hume electorate. I will begin with a matter that I have raised already with the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and also the Minister for Human Services, as the person responsible for Centrelink. That matter is the administration of this government’s exceptional circumstances relief payments. I am thankful that both ministers have already acknowledged my concerns. However, I would like to place my disappointment on record with regard to events which have occurred during the past few months.

speech.para: Several weeks ago, farmer constituents in the Hume electorate, in the community of Young in particular, found themselves in a very difficult financial situation because of this government department’s procedural tardiness. Families who had been relying on the exceptional circumstances relief payment were shocked to receive notification from Centrelink that their payments were being cut off. Despite countless phone calls and letters from my office in the weeks and, indeed, months prior to the deadline, the minister for agriculture and his department failed to ensure that assistance was extended in a timely manner. The result for farming families was that Centrelink cut off their payments, and they were left in limbo for close to two weeks before a decision was announced and the payments reinstated.

It is all well and good for the minister’s office to say that payments will be backdated. However, that does not put food on the table or fuel in the truck or tractor for families surviving just above the breadline. And although families in Young have now been granted their extension, at least for a few more months, the same issue is threatening to put an end to Christmas for families in other drought affected areas, including East Gundagai, Yass and Goulburn, the South Coast, Moss Vale, Braidwood and the Central Tablelands. For them, the government assistance runs out this Thursday.
In a letter to me back in September, the Yass Rural Lands Protection Board sought my assistance to ensure that relief would be extended beyond the 8 December deadline. The letter stated:

quote.para: In November 2003, support under Exceptional Circumstances Assistance was granted for the areas covered by the Yass RLPB. The assistance was provided to help producers through one the most severe drought periods in history and through the subsequent recovery period.

Whilst the district has received substantial rainfall throughout winter of 2005, during the remainder of the recovery period the district has endured severe drought conditions. To maintain financial viability and sustainability under these circumstances, a large number of producers have been forced to sell off increasing numbers of their core breeding stock, invest large sums of money in failed crops and the purchase of fodder supplies.

Sheep numbers in the district have dropped approximately 20 per cent and beef cattle by 10 per cent from 2001 to 2005. Whilst this may seem relatively insignificant, it equates to 274,700 sheep and 6,224 cattle. This is a significant number when it comes to rebuilding flocks and herds.

The Yass RLPB would like to bring to the attention of the Federal Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry the fact that this district was in drought for the term of the EC recovery period and is in fact still drought declared. Time and support is required for producers to rebuild their stock numbers, fodder supplies and to try and recover some financial backing which has been drawn upon so heavily during this period.

speech.para: I understand that the government cannot enter into decisions lightly and that decisions must be based on solid fact. My complaint is that, to date, investigations have not been conducted, results examined and recommendations considered by the minister within a reasonable time frame. This is not just numbers on paper but people’s lives and futures we are talking about here.

I call on the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry to ensure that, come Thursday, families in the rest of Hume will not have to face the same stress and uncertainty as those rural producers at Young which I referred to earlier. This issue is too important to linger at the bottom of some public servant’s ‘to do’ pile or on the desk of a government minister. This decision needs to be made now so that families can make plans not only for this Christmas but also for the months and the years ahead.

I move on now to an issue which has angered residents in the Hume electorate for a very long time. Petrol prices may have begun to fall in our metropolitan areas. However, in country areas, including Goulburn in the heart of my electorate, prices remain at more than $1.20 a litre. Late last week, for example, the local Shell service station in Goulburn was selling unleaded petrol for 123.9c a litre. On the same day, the same fuel in Young, in the western part of the Hume electorate, was selling for 127.9c per litre. Meanwhile in Picton, still in the Hume electorate but on the outskirts of Sydney, fuel was just 109.9c a litre. That is a price differential of 18c per litre between an outer metropolitan petrol station and a rural one.

According to the Australian Automobile Association’s FuelTrac pricing summary, unleaded petrol in the Sydney metropolitan area during October 2005 averaged 124.6c per litre, with a top price of 139.9c per litre. In Goulburn, by comparison, the average price for October was 135.9c per litre, with a top price of 143.5c per litre. That is an 11c difference in the average price of fuel between the city and a rural area. On several occasions I have contacted the ACCC to report this price difference and the way in which fuel prices locally fail to move in line with the price of oil, only to be told that unless collusion could be proved there was nothing they could do.

The government so often points out that fuel prices are driven by world oil prices and market forces. However, as was pointed out in the media this week, Caltex has reported that its profit per barrel of oil increased from $7.28 to $11 this year, as consumers in many areas paid more than $1.40 a litre for their petrol. To my constituents, that is highway robbery. Surely when we talk about keeping the economy strong we should also be thinking about how we can ease the burden of high petrol prices on Australian families. It is what Australian families want.

Moving on now, what Australian families also want is affordable and accessible health services. Like all members in this place, I know that the provision of hospital services is a state responsibility. However, the situation is getting so bad in New South Wales that I am starting to feel, and my constituents are starting to feel, that it is time for the federal government to step in and put pressure and conditions on the state government for all Commonwealth funding. In one local example, it was reported recently that the Greater Southern Area Health Service owes somewhere in the vicinity of $7 million to its medical staff and suppliers. So bad is the situation that, in one case, a woman who had gone through the trauma of a mastectomy—and, might I add, I know this woman personally—went to her local department store to be fitted with a prosthesis and was told that they could not help her because the health service had not paid its account. The hardworking Liberal state member, Daryl Maguire, had to step up and pay for the prosthesis himself, and I compliment him for doing that. What sort of government can allow this sort of thing to go on?

The local branch of Country Labor cannot even get action from their own government, so Country Labor members have organised a rally, to be held in Goulburn this coming Sunday, to protest against any downgrade of Goulburn health services as a result of both the health service’s current financial position and the shortage of nursing and medical staff. Country Labor have their hands tied, because we all know they are restricted to public posturing, as any effective action taken against the Iemma state government will break caucus solidarity and see their members expelled from the ALP. The rally will also recognise the wonderful job that nurses, doctors and other health personnel do for the community. On the day of the rally I have commitments elsewhere in the electorate, but the point I make is that there is an increasing concern within the community about these important health issues. Our hardworking local doctors, nurses and health personnel deserve better.

Constituents in my electorate are constantly asking me to do something about the state of health services both in Goulburn and elsewhere in the electorate and, as a committed local member, I will do everything I can do to assist. In a letter to me recently, one very vocal and passionate advocate issued a plea:

quote.para: When you and I were boys things were different: our local hospitals—St John’s, the Base and Kenmore—were LOCAL, run by local administration and serviced by local organizations such as Hospital Auxiliary, Pink Ladies, and service clubs. Our women and children, the elderly and mentally ill were well looked after.

Wonderful things have happened with health services over the years but unfortunately it has not all been good, particularly now when people are being turned away from hospitals because there is a lack of staff/accommodation, expectant mothers have to travel to centres an hour away, the mentally ill wander the streets and contribute to the ever growing population of homeless people.
Something must be done to bring our hospitals back to being well run, viable, safe institutions, for the staff and patients.

You are our Federal Member and I am asking you to speak to the Prime Minister and Mr Tony Abbott, both of whom I am sure are aware of the state of the NSW health system, and ask them to use their expertise in solving this very real problem.

speech.para: So, I take this opportunity in the House to issue a plea to our Minister for Health and Ageing to put whatever pressure he can on his New South Wales counterpart to ensure that something is done about the crisis which is currently facing health services in New South Wales, before it is too late. It has gone beyond the political posturing being undertaken at the moment. It is a serious issue and it needs to be addressed.

talk.start.para: —I join the member for Hume in his indictment of the Howard government’s shocking and systematic failures in the area of health. Of course, most of the things he mentioned are things that the Howard government could address if it chose to, but it refuses to do so. I rise to grieve also about a health issue—that is, the shameful record of the Minister for Health and Ageing and, in particular, his failure to heed the advice of his experts not to take calcium tablets off the PBS for people who need them for osteoporosis. I grieve not only on my own behalf but on behalf of the oldest and sickest Australians, who will disproportionately bear the impact of this policy. I also grieve on behalf of the Australian Medical Association, which wants the federal government to rethink its decision to remove calcium tablets from the PBS. As you would be aware, there is an old song that goes, ‘All I want for Christmas is my two front teeth’—a child’s song, of course. Unfortunately, this Christmas there are too many older Australians who are saying that what they want for Christmas is their calcium tablets. But, like the Grinch that stole Christmas, the minister for health, Tony Abbott, is denying them access to this basic dietary supplement, which is so important to their health.

speech.para: Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, you would recall that in the last election campaign the Howard government gave a rock solid, ironclad guarantee to maintain the Medicare safety net, and its failure to honour its promise on the safety net now is a matter of public record and public consternation. We should also note that during the last election campaign the Howard government made no mention of what it was planning to do to the PBS safety net. But, since the election, it has hacked into the PBS safety net, including by increasing the thresholds to qualify and excluding from the safety net many prescriptions filled within 20 days of the previous prescription. There is only one goal here, and that is budget savings.

These measures come at a time when the data show that the growth in PBS spending has slowed to 2.5 per cent, down from an average of 12 per cent over the past four years. This slowdown is due primarily to the 21 per cent increase in copayments—that is, the amount that patients have to pay to access medicines—introduced in January and does not as yet fully reflect the impact of the 12.5 per cent generics pricing policy. More particularly we see, in the four-month period from 1 July to 31 October, that there was a decrease of over 1,300,000 scripts over the same period last year. Given that the growth rate in PBS scripts over this time frame has averaged 3.8 per cent over the previous four years, the decrease is really around 3.8 million scripts in that four-month period. More work needs to be done on these statistics, but I think we are right to exhibit real concern that there may be millions of times that people are making a decision not to fill their scripts because of lack of affordability, and such a drop in the access to prescription medicines requires careful analysis.

PBS spending in that same time frame has dropped from $2.2 billion in 2004 to $2.034 billion in 2005. Given that the growth rate in this time period over the previous four years has averaged 13.3 per cent, the savings are actually $461 million in four months. If these trends continue we can expect to see savings for the year 2005-06 of $1.38 billion on the PBS and 11.4 million fewer scripts being filled—and that is before the implementation of the new safety net provisions.

The government seems certain to meet its savings targets, but at what cost? Who is missing out on medicine when we look at these statistics? I think we are right to fear that it is the poorest and sickest Australians who are missing out. Depending on what medications they are failing to take due to affordability issues, it may not really be a saving at all, as the consequences of not taking their medicine show elsewhere in the health system when they need other forms of care.

The decision to take calcium tablets off the PBS is a clear example of what happens when you look for a saving today but do not give a second thought to the costs tomorrow. In making this decision the minister for health has completely disregarded expert opinion and sound policy. The minister for health was in a rush to find savings to deliver to the Treasurer in the lead-up to the last budget. On that basis of rushing around and looking for savings, he decided to remove calcium tablets from the PBS to achieve savings of $36 million over four years. That is a $9-million saving a year.

What damage has this rush for savings—a rush for savings that was done without expert advice—created? That is right. I think Australians need to clearly understand this: the Minister for Health and Ageing in the budget decided to take something off the PBS without any expert advice. If this were to keep up, what else would be coming off the PBS when he is looking for a saving? Cancer medication, antidepression medication, cholesterol-lowering medication; are they things that are going to be ripped off the PBS next when the minister for health is looking for savings?

We know that the cost of calcium tablets to the government when they are on the PBS is around $13 a bottle. This means that the cost for concession card holders who are accessing calcium from the PBS has gone from $4.60 to around $13 a bottle. We should note that it was not everybody who could have access to calcium on the PBS. You could not just get calcium on the PBS because you felt like taking a supplement; calcium on the PBS was only available on authority from your doctor and the doctor was required to certify that the patient needed calcium tablets. Only then were you subsidised by the PBS.

The minister for health was the subject of a great deal of criticism after he took this decision. Instead of getting expert advice before the decision, he sought expert advice after the decision. He consulted the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee about his decision. They sent him some advice. He sent that advice back to them for review and then they sent him some further advice. That advice stated that they were:

quote.para: ... concerned that ... patient groups would not be optimally treated if they ceased taking calcium tablets should they become less affordable by de-listing.

speech.para: So the experts told Tony Abbott, the minister for health, that he had made a mistake and that he ought to put calcium back on the PBS. What the minister did in the face of this expert advice was to complete half a humiliating backflip. He backflipped on the question of the provision of calcium tablets to people with kidney conditions, who need a lot of calcium. But he has not backflipped on the rest—which is what he should do, no matter how humiliating the decision for him.

The people who have been left without access to PBS calcium tablets are people with osteoporosis. This is a disease that costs Australia $1.9 billion per annum in health costs, putting a heavy burden on hospitals and nursing homes. It costs a further $5.6 billion in indirect costs. It represented a total of 1.2 per cent of GDP in 2000-01, or $389 for every Australian. The mortality rate for hip fractures in the elderly is high—about 20 per cent in the first 12 months. Elderly Australians around the country have been raising this issue, including at a seminar held by the member for Richmond, where one of the attendees stood up and said she had voted for The Nationals all her life but would no longer do so, specifically because of this decision.

This decision is a disgrace. It came into effect on 1 December. I am using my first parliamentary opportunity to raise it. This decision needs to be reversed. The minister for health should stop pretending to be the Grinch who stole Christmas and actually do something positive for the health of Australians before we leave this parliament. The positive thing that he should do is accept the advice of experts, recognise he was wrong when he desperately clutched for budget savings and put calcium back on the PBS.

talk.start.para: —I rise in this debate to grieve about the way a water by-product of the mining and extraction of coal bed methane gas from the Surat Basin is merely being left to evaporate away. There are many companies in the Surat Basin extracting coal bed methane and obviously being able to find a ready market for the methane gas. This is a technology that even 10 years ago was in its infancy. Twenty years ago, coal bed methane was just lost to the environment as part of a coalmining operation. It is really about value adding to the coal industry and being able to utilise something that would otherwise have been wasted.

speech.para: I will explain to the House this afternoon how the coal bed methane is extracted from these coalfields. First of all, they drill to find the reserves and then they have to extract the gas. As they extract the gas, a large volume of water comes up with the gas. Why is that? The water molecule is larger than the gas molecule; so, as part of the extraction process, the water comes up to the surface ahead of the gas, as I understand it. The companies that are mining the coal bed methane gas, obviously stripping the gas from the water, are able to process it and feed it into the Roma-Brisbane pipeline to supply industries in Brisbane. There are gas pipelines that head north to Gladstone and Townsville. So an invaluable source of energy is being extracted from the Surat coal bed, and coming up with it is water.

The problem with this water at the moment is that it carries salts with it, and it has to be cleaned up if it is to be used in any way other than perhaps in an industrial sense. An industrial use, for instance, could be to wash coal, as the coal industry develops in that part of Queensland. There are a very large number of feedlots in that region which require water. More water will be required as both those industries expand in the future. One of the first things that industries require before they invest capital is a known reserve of water, whether it is in the development of the coal industry or whether it is in the feedlot industry. Both of those industries really are being held back through the lack of guarantees of an available or suitable water source.

Here we have a known water source which is a by-product of the coal bed methane being sold for purposes within Queensland now. Why, on the driest continent on earth, are we allowing this water that comes up as part of the coal bed methane extraction process to be merely evaporated away? It is beyond me. These companies are not doing anything illegal; it is quite legal. One of the conditions of their licence is that they can actually evaporate this water away.

I want to talk a bit about the Queensland Gas Co. It has put a proposal to the federal government, under the National Water Initiative, for financial assistance to build a water pipeline so as to be able to sell this water into markets in the Condamine-Murray-Darling Basin system, particularly for towns in that region. The Queensland Gas Co. is to be commended for its actions because it wants to amend the use of the water, which is merely being evaporated away now, and to use a process of reverse osmosis to provide potable water for urban communities. Some of the water that is a by-product of that reverse osmosis process could also be used for industries.

The size of the known water reserves that, over the next 20 years, will be extracted from the fields that the Queensland Gas Co. is operating in at the moment is quite staggering. There are something like 352,000 megalitres of water that is known to be available over the next 20 years just from the current extraction wells of the Queensland Gas Co. There are other wells in the region from other companies. North of Roma, where I live, I know that for a number of years they have been evaporating the water away once they have extracted the coal bed methane. There is a large number of them. But, going back to the proposal of the Queensland Gas Co., 352,000 megalitres of water is known to be available over the next 20 years.

The City of Toowoomba right now has a proposal, under the National Water Initiative, in front of the federal government for some money to secure more water or to have more sustainability in their water supply. Toowoomba is a city of some 95,000 people and it needs something like 14,000 megalitres of water per year. To put that into context, that is 352,000 megalitres of water over the next 20 years just from the operations of the Queensland Gas Co. that will evaporate unless something is done to assist companies to utilise this water in ways other than just evaporating it away. Put another way, 352,000 megalitres of water would provide enough water for 20 years for 2.388 million people. That gives you some idea of the sheer magnitude of the water that will be evaporated away unless something changes in the way we use it and unless financial assistance comes from both the Queensland and the federal governments.

Progressive towns in my electorate—Dalby, Chinchilla and Miles—are all looking with great interest at this water source. They recognise that, if they are able to buy this water at affordable prices—because at the end of the day they would have to on-sell this water to the residents of these local council areas—and if they are able to enter into contracts with the Queensland Gas Co. and other companies that are in this industry, it will release water from their sources now into the Condamine-Balonne-Murray-Darling Basin system. In other words, if we are able to see a process whereby this water is not evaporated away but is put through a process of reverse osmosis and then the potable water is made available to these shires—and I know the Chinchilla Shire has shown a great deal of interest in this—then we will see a market for that water. The water would be released and, I would suggest, they would be then able to sell their current allocation of water out of the Condamine River. That would be a win-win situation for the community and for the environment because it would release that water for other purposes downstream or for environmental flows.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you can see that what I grieve about this afternoon is that, whilst current licensing conditions allow these companies that are in the coal bed methane extraction industry to merely evaporate water away, we must do more than that in the future. I am supporting the application of the Queensland Gas Co. under the National Water Initiative for financial support for that project because of the benefits that will flow to industry, the community and the environment. At the end of the day we will be utilising a resource on the driest continent on earth. It is one of the most valuable resources we have—I could almost say that it is more valuable to us than the coal bed methane gas itself. We have to use water better in the future, and I am strongly in support of seeing this water not being evaporated away but utilised to a greater extent for industry and the community.

talk.start.para: (Hon. DGH Adams)—Order! The time for the grievance debate has expired. The debate is interrupted and I put the question:

speech.para: Question agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be considered at the next sitting.

debateinfo.title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT (IMPROVEMENTS TO SELF ASSESSMENT) BILL (NO. 2) 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Mr Brough:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr Fitzgibbon moved by way of amendment:

para.inline: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:

item.para: maintaining and allowing the self assessment system to so seriously deteriorate over a long period of time so these radical reforms are needed;
failing to provide sufficient certainty on how oral advice will be recorded and made available; and
failure to clarify in this bill how the personal tax affairs of a taxpayer will be linked to the tax affairs of a company with which the taxpayer is associated”.

talk.start.para: —Before my contribution to this second reading debate on the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005 was interrupted by question time last Thursday, I had made a number of comments about how tax issues had troubled the Treasurer during the whole time he has been in that position. The pressure placed on the Treasurer by the opposition last week, and obviously by the coalition backbench, resulted in the resignation last Friday of the cause of the Treasurer’s latest tax problem—Mr Gerard.

speech.para: The resignation of Mr Gerard from the board of the Reserve Bank is proof of the poor judgment of the Treasurer in appointing him in the first place. Despite the strong protestations of government members who have said that the government had no influence over the decision of Mr Gerard to resign, I find that a little bit difficult to believe. The whole affair demonstrates the poor judgment of the Treasurer in this regard. I found it particularly interesting to read the comment of an unnamed coalition member who is reported to have said—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This is very complex legislation relating to the tax act. The member should be asked to return to the details of the legislation from which he has removed himself by a very far distinction in talking about an issue—
(Hon. DGH Adams)—The honourable member will resume his seat. I ask the honourable member for Werriwa to come to the bill.

—In deference to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will do that, but I think my comments reflect on the bill in terms of the decisions being made by the Treasurer, who is responsible for the administration of the tax act. The Treasurer’s problems with taxation do not stop with what occurred last week. As my colleague will probably be able to attest, there was correspondence from coalition backbenchers to the Treasurer—which I referred to last week—that detailed a couple of key issues of concern about this very piece of legislation. It said that, firstly, the legislation should more fully reflect the Treasury recommendations contained in the review of self-assessment report; secondly, the legislation should have specific application to the groups who complained and prompted the Treasury review; thirdly, the legislation should apply retrospectively; and, finally, there should be greater controls on the commissioner’s ongoing ability to retrospectively and unilaterally make determinations.

speech.para: As I said last week, that correspondence was sent by coalition backbenchers to the Treasurer to consider in relation to this legislation. I have no doubt that these are pretty insightful comments but at the same time they offer a damning criticism when they are ignored. And that is precisely what did occur—they were ignored. Unlike the Treasurer in this regard, Labor are willing to consider the issues that have been raised by the coalition backbench. We on this side of the House are willing to take the tax proposals that were rejected by Treasurer Costello and would be prepared to give effect to them as appropriate. I urge all of the signatories to that correspondence to the Treasurer, who have expressed concerns about this bill, to have the courage of their commitment and stand up to the Treasurer. You are on common ground with us in many respects on this matter.

While I feel that the provisions of this bill could have gone further—and, as a matter of fact, should have gone further—I do support the increase in the level of certainty that these changes bring to Australian taxpayers. Having said that, I cannot rise to speak on a bill concerning issues of tax without passing comment on the pretty feeble attempt by the Treasurer to reduce the pages of the income tax legislation by, as he claims, 30 per cent. According to the Treasurer’s media release on 24 November, the Board of Taxation estimates that 2,100 pages of the combined income tax assessment acts can be repealed. The Treasurer claims that this is the largest simplification of tax legislation in Australian history. Of course it is: the tax acts have become so unwieldy that cutting out 2,100 pages is by any means a considerable change. The Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 have a combined total of 6,450 pages. When you take into account the ancillary legislation, there are, as I understand it, some 10,000 pages of legislation.

So the Treasurer has decided that it is time to give the 25-centimetre thick, four-volume tax assessment acts a bit of a prune. This will only get them back to the level of the taxation acts he inherited back in 1996; he will only be able to prune the tax assessment acts back to the size when he got control of the legislation in 1996. That is not reform. Sure, it is important that periodically we do act to trim the size of legislation by removing clauses which are redundant, cumbersome or infrequently used—but let us not kid ourselves: that is not reform. Unlike other so-called reforms by government—such as the Work Choices or Welfare to Work provisions, which tear at the very fabric of Australian society—throwing out clauses in the tax acts that have passed their use-by date is hardly radical reform.

It seems that the Treasurer has lost even the modicum of reformist zeal that he had at the start of his nine years in office in control of the tax system. The Australian taxpayer has nothing to fear from these reforms—mind you, they have little to gain either—but at least there is nothing hiding in the fine print as is the case with many other initiatives of this government. The only changes that the Treasurer has set about making to the tax laws since he has had carriage of them have resulted either in pages being added to the tax laws or in middle Australia missing out on tax cuts. In 1996, the tax acts were 3,500 pages long. Now there are nearly 10,000 pages of tax law—a threefold increase. The Treasurer’s record is not a thing to be admired when it comes to tax reform, and it seems that the coalition backbench is starting to work that out.

Under the Australian income tax system, if you are an ordinary PAYE taxpayer you pay tax. You are not able to avoid tax like some millionaires around the country seem to be able to. I understand that before the 1996 election both parties were advised that it was possible for millionaires to reduce their average tax bill to around 25 per cent. At that time that rate was below the rate that would have been paid by ordinary working Australians on $40,000 per annum. Nine years later, we have the highest taxing government in Australian history and what does a recent study from the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research show us? It reports that the nation’s wealthiest households are still paying a tax rate of around 25 per cent. What a sensational effort by this government: after nine years and a threefold increase in the number of pages in the tax acts, the wealthiest Australians are still enjoying a tax rate below that of ordinary working Australians.

Working Australians in my electorate would love nothing more than to be able to minimise their tax to the same extent that the Treasurer continues to allow the richest among us to do. It is quite clear that there are deep-seated economic inefficiencies contained in Australia’s current taxation regime. A tax regime that allows the highest of income earners to pay less tax than the average income earner has got to be seen as being in desperate need of repair. As the Treasurer said himself in the lead-up to the 1998 election:

quote.para: High tax rates mean rich people spend more time and money on tax planning to reduce their tax liabilities. Low-income earners who cannot afford such advice keep paying more tax.

speech.para: He is dead right about that. This makes complete sense when you consider taxation statistics which show that almost half of all individual taxpayers seek professional taxation advice that produces a total deduction in the tax system of around $1 billion annually. When individual taxpayers consider it necessary and in their interests to spend $1 billion on tax advice, surely we must realise that there is something crook in the system.

When you dig a bit deeper into the tax statistics, the case for reform of income tax starts to become somewhat overwhelming. Probably the biggest inefficiency—and the greatest opportunity for rorting the tax system—comes about because of the sometimes very generous claims for work related deductions that are allowed. Don’t get me wrong: work related deductions are often necessary and do reflect the fact that in order to work many people sometimes need to make purchases directly related to their occupation. But, given the current level of deductions, you would have to ask a couple of questions. In the 2002-03 financial year, there were some 10.7 million taxpayers who reported a total income of $381.2 billion. A total of $20.7 billion was claimed in deductions, about half of which were work related deductions. When billions of dollars are claimed in work related deductions, it seems to me that these deductions are starting to move away from the reasons for which they were introduced and to become means of lowering taxable income and avoiding or at least minimising tax liabilities. While the Treasurer feels that lopping off redundant and unused parts of the tax acts is radical reform, there is an overwhelming need to address Australia’s income tax system at a more fundamental level. I take this opportunity to again call on the government to get serious about tax reform, to get serious about putting incentive back into the tax system and to get serious about providing tax cuts for the more than 80 per cent of income earners in my electorate of Werriwa who missed out on the tax cuts in the last budget and are now seeing their money locked up in a $14 billion surplus that this government seems to have little desire to let go of.

talk.start.para: —The member for Werriwa raised a spark of hope in this place. At one point he indicated that the opposition would be supportive of a more generous response to the great difficulty in which many taxpayers throughout Australia have found themselves in various aspects of their tax affairs and their dealings with the commissioner, which to some degree the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005 seeks to address. So I rushed down in excitement to get a copy of the proposed amendment put forward by the Labor opposition. As is typical, it is best described as a pious amendment. It reads:

quote.para: Whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government ...

speech.para: I thought the member for Werriwa was going to tell us how further positive amendments might be included in this legislation, something that members and the signatories to the letter he referred to, of which I am one, might have taken an interest in. But what is in this pious amendment? It seeks to condemn the government for:

item.para: maintaining and allowing the self assessment system to so seriously deteriorate over a long period of time so these radical reforms are needed;

speech.para: What change does that particular amendment bring to the House? The next clause states:

item.para: failing to provide sufficient certainty on how oral advice will be recorded and made available;

speech.para: That is quite a good point, but there is nothing in black and white to support it. Finally:

item.para: failure to clarify in this bill how the personal tax affairs of a taxpayer will be linked to the tax affairs of a company with which the taxpayer is associated.

speech.para: Okay, if there is opportunity for amendment in that regard, and considering the fact that day after day in this place the opposition complain about their lack of opportunity to properly examine legislation, surely now is the time to put forward amendments of substance and have a discussion and a debate about them. They say these opportunities for debate are so important to them when, of course, if anyone listened to their contributions on the IR legislation, for instance, there was constant repetition of ‘the sky is falling in’ and no proper analysis of the legislation being debated—then or now.

It is not too hard to talk constructively about legislation of this nature. In a speech earlier today, I gave a tick to the member for Rankin for his very sensible remarks about petrol pricing. I live in hope that, when I conclude my contribution, he will bring some light to this debate in terms of positive measures to deliver to the Australian people the simplicity, certainty and equity that define a good tax. But he does not have much opportunity because, presumably, his caucus or his executive have decided that the amendment I just read out is the opposition’s position on this legislation.

I have said in this place time and time again that good tax law will be the responsibility of this parliament, not the government of the day. But I can say with some pride that when the Hawke government and, for that matter, the Keating government brought matters of substance into this place that gave the impression of being good for Australia, such as floating the currency and other matters, it was the opposition, of which I was a member, that said, ‘Good on you.’ I have said before—and I want to seriously discuss this bill—that when Keating as Treasurer proposed the sale of the Commonwealth Bank he was able to get that through caucus as an icon issue for the Labor Party because he could tell them there would be no mischief emanating from the coalition opposition. We believe in privatisation and we supported that measure. As I recollect, there was criticism by the minor parties in the Senate that they were sidelined in the debate because the two major parties actually came to a decision that they believed was right for Australia.

In tax particularly, where scare campaigns are so easy to run, it is time that there was a bipartisan view. It is not helped by the member for Werriwa complaining that his constituents did not get a big enough tax cut. When he is next handing out material that asks people to vote for him, he wants to just check out how many of his constituents actually fell into the previous 42c level. Obviously not all of them would have, but I will bet you there were too many. Of course, it is a fact that, many years ago, to break into those top marginal rates you had to earn 15 times average weekly earnings. Today the figure has reduced to between one and two—I am not sure exactly where it is at this moment. It is silly, it is wrong and it is not fair. It is not equitable. Therefore, there is an ongoing battle in the broader context of tax to have a review of taxation.

I note frequently people standing up and saying, ‘You can only erode revenue so far.’ I do not disagree with that. The Australian people, sometimes unwisely, seem to be more interested in having cash for an overseas trip than to pay the doctor. That is their view; it is not one to which I subscribe. On the other hand, governments are expected by the people to raise money to defend the country and provide certain services. That does not mean that we cannot revisit the structures of tax. As I have informed the House before, there are numerous ways that would allow us to reduce high rates of tax, which I think are very regressive, without significant reduction in revenue. It is not appropriate for me to go through those today having just suggested to another member, who got widely off the issue of income tax, to not speak about it.

The explanatory memorandum gives us clear advice that the principal outcome of this legislation is to address a serious problem for the community—that is, the legal capacity of the tax commissioner to revisit self-assessment arrangements years after the event. Having assessed that the claims previously made by a taxpayer were not consistent with the law—most taxpayers have never had the financial capacity to take the commissioner on in the courts, unless it is a collective decision—the commissioner can say, ‘You avoided x dollars tax. I am applying a 50 per cent penalty and interest rates as high as 11 or 12 per cent compounded up until the point of advice, until the point I have told you that I think you are wrong.’

Those who have dealt in the usury market would soon discover how gigantic compound interest can be. It can double a debt in a very short period. Some taxpayers, shocked by this arrangement, are sometimes reassured by, for instance, promoters of various schemes who say: ‘You’ll be right, mate; hang in there; we are going to take the tax office to court.’ If and when the taxpayer loses, the clock has continued to tick up until that point.

That is not good enough. An example that really concerned me was when a group of taxpayers sought relief from tax by contributing to an agricultural program that had received a product ruling from the tax commissioner of being acceptable under the tax act. Yet, later on, this group received a request for huge amounts of money because, in the view of the tax commissioner—eventually supported by a court—the promoter of the scheme had not complied with all aspects of the ruling. That is fine. You had better sue the promoter. Who does that? These taxpayers were not advised in a short period of that matter. The very high interest rate clock continued to operate.

This legislation is doing something about that. More particularly, it is a step in the right direction. Nevertheless, I am concerned that, if a taxpayer has made full disclosure of all their affairs—which I think is fundamental to self-assessment—but in that process has claimed a deduction for a scheme or other matters that might be in dispute by the tax commissioner, there needs to be a prompt response.

It appears that this legislation, in the normal course of business, will limit the tax commissioner’s opportunity in which to respond to a fair and reasonable tax return to two years. That to me is a fair and reasonable proposition. I am less enamoured of the fact that, where a scheme is involved, the response can be extended to four years. It is better than the never-never plan of the past, but it is still a long time if the clock is to be clicked back to the day of lodgment of the return. I may stand corrected by the member for Rankin, but my understanding is that this legislation says that the commissioner has up to four years but that the clock starts ticking after he writes back. I believe that that should be a component of any legislation. In other words, you cannot be charged, in the case of full disclosure, with interest or penalties until you get an objection to your self-assessment from the commissioner. I will continue to campaign for that arrangement.

I have been told by a very senior member of the tax office that that is possible. I have argued directly to the tax office on behalf of the people of Australia that you ought to be able to have a yellow, red or brightly coloured form that you put on the front of your tax return—I do not know how you transmit that electronically, but we are into coloured copiers now, so maybe it can be done—which says: ‘Red alert! I have participated in the woop woop scheme. Everything I tell you in this return is true. This is how much money I have taken, but I am claiming an additional reduction in my tax of $5,000’—or $10,000—‘because of my participation in this scheme.’ If you give that sort of notice, it seems simple to me that the commissioner’s clock has to start ticking. I would think that in those circumstances something measured in days, or a very short period of months, would be available to the commissioner in which to say, ‘No, I’m not happy with that. I advise you to pay your full tax. On the other hand, if future debate proves I’m wrong, I’ll give you your money back.’ Wouldn’t it be nice if the commissioner added a bit of interest!

The reality is that, whilst this legislation goes part of the way, it unfortunately does not address the circumstances that many people have found themselves in. There has been some moderation of the commissioner’s claims, and I thank the ATO for that. And this legislation does clear up a lot of the grey areas. It is summarised by the advisers in this area in the explanatory memorandum under ‘Summary of regulation impact statement’, which says:

quote.para: The new law will provide improved ways for taxpayers to find out the Commissioner of Taxation’s (Commissioner’s) view on how certain laws apply, so that the risks of uncertainty when self assessing, or working out their tax obligations or entitlements, are reduced. This is achieved by:
making rulings available to many taxpayers on a wide range of matters;
ensuring that the Commissioner provides rulings in a timely manner;
enabling the Commissioner to obtain, and make rulings based on, relevant information;
protecting taxpayers from increases in tax and from penalties and interest where they rely on rulings;
limiting the ways the Commissioner can alter rulings to a taxpayer’s detriment; and
giving protection from interest charges where a taxpayer relies on other advice from the Commissioner, or on the Commissioner’s general administrative practice.

speech.para: All that is positive. I am in here to support the legislation. But I would have been much more comfortable if there had been a greater degree of retrospectivity. I voted against retrospective tax in this place when it was an imposition on the taxpayer. It was a very lonely day. I think six of us sat in splendid isolation on one side of the parliament whilst the entire Labor opposition and the then Fraser government members sat on the other side. We must have gone very close to the problem that Harry Quick had the other night with another piece of legislation.

The reality is that we held out very strongly against negative retrospective tax law or, for that matter, any negative retrospective legislation that shifts the goalposts after the event. I stand by that. But, as this would have been a positive measure, I think that probably we ought to have had a better response to taxpayers who got trapped in the schemes for an inordinately long period. I am not arguing in this place that people who incorrectly reduced their taxation should have got away with paying the tax. But if the ATO is unable to advise them of the failing of their request within a few months, it becomes unfair to the taxpayer, presuming they have made full disclosure. This legislation does not exclude people from the normal processes of the previous tax act where they have taken fraudulent or other actions that are means of evasion. The explanatory memorandum tells us:

quote.para: The unlimited amendment period for cases of fraud or evasion will continue to apply.

speech.para: I am not putting any argument there. But, where people make a full disclosure of their income and consequently seek to have certain reduction in that amount of money, then, if they do that through appropriate advice, they should not be subject to any penalties or interest until the tax commissioner disagrees with their claim. That is not part of this legislation at this point. I trust that the parliament might one day decide that that is a good idea.

As I said, when the parliament can get up and bring in a much more simplified tax system, it could be reduced to not many more items than exist in the new IR legislation when it comes to awards. That would be a good idea. I am a great supporter of the GST. It should be collected at a level that fully compensates the states for all their regressive taxes. I do not think they have one that is a good idea. When people are paying $30 a week throughout their life in stamp duty on their personal residence, that is just an example of how bad some of those taxes are.

All in all, I support this legislation. I would have liked it to go further, but I reject any suggestion that at this point in time the opposition has made any productive contribution to the legislation. Considering the public announcements of the member for Swan, the opposition had a responsibility to put up some decent amendments if it believed in them.

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005.
