This bill arises out of concerns expressed in recent years by taxpayers and accountants in circumstances where the Australian Taxation Office issues an amended tax assessment—often, in the process, overturning previous advice which taxpayers had relied upon. Bills like this, of course, go to the heart of the integrity of our tax system and the stewardship of our tax system. As I speak, we now know that Mr Ron Walker was told by Mr Gerard about his tax problems prior to the appointment of Mr Gerard to the Reserve Bank board.
(Mr Baldwin)—I warn the member for Lilley—
—When we are dealing with the integrity of the tax system—
—Order! Resume your seat. I give you fair warning that the naming of people and going through tax matters, unless it directly relates to this bill, will not be entertained in this chamber.

—It seems that everybody knew about this particular tax problem except the Treasurer, Peter Costello. As every day goes by, the Treasurer gets in deeper and deeper. I say that it is about time the Treasurer came clean on these matters and told the truth. The public has had enough of the Treasurer’s false denials.

speech.para: But let me go back to the bill. Public concern led to a process of review announced by the Treasurer in November 2003. The Review of Aspects of Income Tax Self Assessment was intended to examine whether an appropriate balance had been struck between protecting the rights of individual taxpayers and protecting the revenue for the benefit of the whole community. This bill introduces the recommendations from the review that require legislative change.

In particular the bill proposes, firstly, to reduce the time period within which the ATO can audit a taxpayer—reducing it from four years to two years for those with simple tax affairs and from six years to four years for taxpayers with more complex affairs. Secondly, it proposes to alter the process by which tax rulings are made: to ensure that, where a taxpayer relies upon ATO advice, including oral advice formally requested, that taxpayer will be free from penalties; to expand the situations in which the commissioner is bound by advice tendered to the taxpayer; to specify time limits for the provision of a ruling; to allow the ruling to be made electronically; and to give the commissioner more flexibility about the date at which a ruling applies.

On the whole the Labor Party sees the proposals contained in this bill as progressive and, as such, it will be supported. The nature of our income tax system, with its self-assessment regime, is that it seeks to ease the administrative burden on taxpayers when complying with tax law. The system operates to a large degree on trust, with taxpayers submitting details of their arrangements to the ATO without substantiation per se. However, the system places an onus on individual taxpayers to substantiate their affairs should the ATO conduct a review. Such reviews and detailed audits, if necessary, are conducted on a risk basis, depending on the particular taxpayer’s affairs and whether particular claims are in excess of what would be expected for a taxpayer in similar circumstances.

At most times the system works well; sometimes it does not. It is difficult to get the balance right. There will always be those who seek to exploit the system and avoid paying their fair share of tax. We have seen plenty of debate about that in recent weeks in this parliament. People want to know that the system is administered in an impartial way and that all taxpayers are treated equally. People want to know that there is not a double standard in the tax system, one for a few select mates of the government and entirely another for those struggling small businesses who are coping with the GST and for those working taxpayers who are paying PAYG tax.

On the other hand, there are sometimes occasions when taxpayers find the law confusing and request clarification from the tax office. Typically, they receive advice and act on it in good faith. Occasionally, the tax office may revisit this advice and issue amended assessments to those taxpayers who originally relied on the tax office’s advice. These taxpayers in turn feel aggrieved at this retrospective action, even though the amended assessment is often made with a more contemporary understanding of the tax law, in the light of emerging circumstances that have the potential to threaten the tax base. Given such events, the changes made in this bill are a step in the right direction.

The changes in this bill to make rulings binding in more circumstances and to reduce the time frame for issuing amended assessments should increase the onus on the tax office to get it right the first time. This is a good thing, but ultimately these changes are a compromise. They are an attempt to rebalance the relationship between the taxpayer and the tax office, as each grapples with an overly complex tax system—for we do, of course, have a complex tax system. We now have some 9,500 pages of tax law—up from some 3,500 pages when the government was elected over nine years ago. Those pages include current and inoperative provisions and thousands of pages of taxation rulings and determinations.

Surely if we are interested in improving the administration and fairness of the system we should tackle the root cause. Tedious and overly complex tax law will always result in more disputes than simpler laws. There is a need for simplicity. The truth is we need a simpler tax system that is easier for taxpayers to comply with and for the tax office to police. That is why the integrity of the tax system is so important. That is why the person administering the tax system and its integrity must be seen to have acted in an impartial way and must be seen not to be favouring one particular taxpayer over classes of other taxpayers.

Now, despite promising to cut the burden of red tape, the Treasurer has ‘slashed’ the number of pages in the tax act from an estimated 3,500 to more than 9,000. Given this record, it was extraordinary to see the Treasurer’s announcement on 24 November about cutting some 2,000 pages from the tax act by repealing inoperative provisions. He heralded this as a major reform, but it was a joke. Indeed, he went on to claim that this was ‘the biggest overhaul of legislation that has ever been done in Australian history.’ I kid you not. The truth is this is not tax reform; it is just window-dressing. Ridding the act of provisions that are no longer current is a good thing, but it is not reform; it is just housekeeping. The farcical thing is that tax practitioners will still need to keep the 2,000 pages of inoperative provisions, so that they can deal with retrospective tax assessments.

The truth is, if the government were concerned about simplifying the tax law, they would look at truly streamlining it. That would mean revisiting the complex system of deductions, concessions and tax offsets that have seen expenditures explode under the coalition. It would also mean looking at ways to simplify the way that tax is administered and the way individual taxpayers interact with the tax office. For example, why doesn’t the government contemplate measures that have the potential to end the annual grind of completing a fully-fledged tax return? Plenty of ideas have come forward, like streamlining annual income tax returns by simply issuing assessment notices to those with a history of simple claims and asking them to verify the assessment as is or amend it as necessary. Such a system could deliver significant administrative savings and ease the burden on taxpayers.

I urge the Treasurer to consider proposals such as these. He has not had such a good time of late when it comes to tax, Mr Deputy Speaker—you may well have noticed that—but we know he collects record amounts of it. He is the highest taxing Treasurer in Australian history. That tax take is built off the back of ordinary taxpayers on low and middle incomes, who expect to be treated fairly. I urge the Treasurer to stand shoulder to shoulder with those taxpayers rather than with a few of his mates from the Liberal Party, as he has been doing in recent weeks in this parliament. He needs to reduce the tax and compliance burden. It is a reform that is essential for the economy and one that would be pivotal in boosting our nation’s productivity. These are all substantive issues, and they need to be addressed. The bill we are debating today is a small improvement, but it does not lessen the obligation on the Treasurer to come into this parliament and tell the truth about Mr Gerard.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005. I am pleased to support the amendments to our tax laws in this bill. These are measures designed to improve certainty to taxpayers, particularly in two areas: time frames for tax audits; and public, private and oral rulings. These two areas have caused a great deal of uncertainty in recent years and this is a very important series of amendments to our tax laws.

speech.para: I am pleased to speak to the amendments in this bill because of the distress that uncertainty in the past has caused many individuals, including a number of my constituents who have been adversely affected by what are commonly known as mass marketing schemes as well as employment benefit arrangements—people who believed they had sound advice from financial agents and who acted on the advice of these promoters in schemes that were understood to be legal ways of minimising tax. In many cases the Australian Taxation Commission has altered interpretations, causing great financial and emotional stress to individuals. The changes in this bill will in future remove much of this uncertainty and the associated potential for distress.

As the member for Canning has done before me, I would also like to thank the member for Longman, Mal Brough, for the initiative he has taken as Assistant Treasurer to see sensible settlement of outstanding cases and for his introduction of these amendments to the House, amendments that should help in the future by ensuring that the commissioner is bound by undertakings made. The bill provides a capacity for the taxpayer to rely on public and private rulings or oral advice formally requested from the commissioner without penalty, even if that advice is subsequently deemed incorrect or the commissioner’s interpretation subsequently changes.

The main aim of the tax administration system is to collect revenue with a minimum of compliance and administrative costs. To this end our tax system has operated via a self-assessment system since 1986. Under this system taxpayers’ returns are accepted in the first instance and the tax office may subsequently review the accuracy of the information in the return within a prescribed period. Essentially, the self-assessment system requires taxpayers to perform certain functions and take some responsibility that was previously taken by the tax office. Under the old system taxpayers provided the tax office with the relevant information and the tax office then assessed their liabilities accordingly. Under this system the obligation to the taxpayer was to provide full and true disclosure and the assessment was left to the ATO. After the tax office made assessments they could amend an assessment that had an error of fact or calculation but could not fix errors of law. Under this system taxpayers had a measure of certainty, while the costs to the tax office were borne by the community as a whole.

However, under the self-assessment system the ATO still issues notices of assessment, but returns are generally taken at face value, subject to a post-assessment risk based audit and other verification checks. Under the self-assessment system the tax office is allowed to amend errors of calculation, fact and law after processing the assessment or paying a refund. The self-assessment system changed the balance of cost and risk between the tax office and the taxpayer. The self-assessment system also allows for more efficient use of tax office resources so that more revenue can be collected for less revenue costs.

In the early nineties problems had been identified with the self-assessment system. The problems related to the penalties and interest and the need to provide greater certainty to the taxpayer. We are still trying to come to grips with some of these problems. When the balance changed between the cost and risk of the ATO and the taxpayer under self-assessment, some of these problems emerged due to penalties and interest and the need to provide greater certainty accordingly.

In 1992 the Keating government brought in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Self Assessment) Act, with the most notable changes being a new system of binding public rulings, a new system of binding private rulings, an extension to four years of the period within which a taxpayer could object to an assessment, a new system requiring penalties for underassessments of income tax liabilities based on the requirement that taxpayers exercise reasonable care and a new interest system for underpayments or late payments of income tax based on commercial principles and market interest rates.

Since coming to office in 1996 the Howard government has shortened the period of review for taxpayers with straightforward affairs; introduced binding oral advice; reduced the interest rate on shortfalls and late payments; and introduced the office of the Inspector-General of Taxation, a new statutory office with governance responsibility. This brings me to the current review and the new legislation against those matters introduced since 1986 and subsequently amended and improved.

In December 2003 the Treasurer announced that the Treasury would be conducting a review into the self-assessment system. The review was asked to consider whether certain aspects of the self-assessment system achieved the right balance between protecting the rights of individual taxpayers and protecting the revenue stream to benefit all Australians. The review was not asked to consider fundamental tax policy changes. These amendments do not go to fundamental tax policy changes.

In 2003 the review considered a wide range of issues and held discussions with many groups. Following the initial analysis, in 2004 the Treasurer released a discussion paper and 30 comprehensive submissions were received. Key comments in the submissions were criticism of the accessibility of advice from the ATO, criticism of uncertainty in relation to ATO interpreted decisions—this has been the underpinning of much of what we have in front of us today—criticism about private rulings and great concern that the penalties for failing to follow a ruling discouraged people from applying for private binding rulings unless they were confident of getting a favourable ruling. The discussion paper was amended in the light of those submissions and the final report was released in December 2004. The government subsequently announced that it would adopt the 30 legislative recommendations made in the report.

This bill amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Taxation Administration Act 1953. Schedule 1 of this bill reduces the periods during which the commissioner may amend income tax assessments in a range of circumstances. This is a very important provision. For most individuals with straightforward returns, the period will be two years. Currently it is four years. The majority of taxpayers will fall into this band. A four-year period will apply to taxpayers with more complex affairs. These can include people who carry on a business which does not participate in the simplified tax system; a taxpayer who is a beneficiary of a trust estate; a taxpayer who has entered into or carried out a scheme for the sole or dominant purpose of obtaining a scheme benefit; and other special cases as prescribed by regulation.

The period of review and amendment of assessments involving arrangements with the dominant purpose of avoiding tax will be four years. Fraud or evasion cases will continue to have an unlimited amendment period. These amendments apply to assessments for the 2004-05 income year and later income years and are a very important part of improving the certainty associated with many of these tax issues.

Rulings are the second major area of this legislation. The tax office gives a wide range of advice to taxpayers and their representatives about how, in the tax office’s opinion, tax law applies or would apply. That advice ranges from general information for the public to advice relating to specific taxation arrangements. Since 1992 the tax law has made certain categories of advice, called rulings, binding on the tax office. There are three kinds of rulings: public rulings, private rulings and oral rulings. Oral rulings were enacted in 1999 in response to a range of recommendations. They are available to individuals who apply to the tax office for a ruling on the way in which the income tax law applies to them. Oral rulings are only available on interpretive matters that are straightforward or simple, and they are legally binding on the Commissioner of Taxation if they result in a lower amount of final tax payable by the taxpayer.

The object of the new system in front of us is to provide improved ways for taxpayers to find out the commissioner’s views on applying certain laws and to reduce the risk of self-assessing. Previously, the commissioner was able to give public and private rulings only on issues of tax liability. This included income tax, withholding tax, mining withholding tax, Medicare levy, fringe benefits tax, franking deficit tax, venture capital deficit tax, overfranking tax and product grant and benefit laws. Under the new system, the commissioner will be able to make rulings on the above, plus on matters of administration and collection of those taxes in relation to the rulings regime.

Another new measure under this package is that, where oral advice is provided by the tax office and is reasonably relied upon by the taxpayer, that taxpayer will not have interest or penalties imposed. Also, the new measures will mean that, if an oral ruling is sought in writing, there is protection granted against an amended assessment which would impose a higher primary tax. This bill will also give taxpayers further protection when they rely on advice or other administrative practices of the tax office. Currently, when a taxpayer relies on other advice or general administrative practices of the tax office, the taxpayer is protected from penalties but does incur interest on the tax debt. In many cases, this has caused enormous distress and great uncertainty, with serious bills mounting up. In some cases, businesses have gone to the wall because of this uncertainty and the interest on this tax debt. Under the new system, a taxpayer will be protected from both penalties and interest when relying on other advice or general administrative procedures.

Documents outlining rulings can include any publication that the commissioner makes, such as fact sheets. If a document says it is non-binding, these new provisions do not apply. In addition to the above, this new bill provides that the tax office will produce rulings in a style that is simple and easy to understand. In the submissions received by this inquiry, one of the issues that featured was the difficulty for the general public in understanding public rulings.

There have been some serious problems in many parts of Australia across many groups. The provisions and the uncertainty have been used and abused by those advocating schemes that have caused much uncertainty to many law-abiding people. People who acted in a way that they thought was legal have subsequently suffered from changed determinations by the tax office. This bill will provide a greater level of certainty for taxpayers by expanding the current self-assessment system, giving protection to taxpayers in a wider range of circumstances. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —The reason the parliament is debating the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005 is straightforward: the income tax system is riddled with lurks and loopholes. The complexity of the tax system has increased astronomically under this government and the opportunities for avoidance have risen commensurately.

speech.para: I was a member of a House of Representatives inquiry into mass marketed schemes. That inquiry was originally about employee share ownership arrangements and ostensibly was about more closely aligning the interests of employers and employees through concessionary arrangements for the acquisition of shares by employees. But the inquiry unearthed a very high level of tax avoidance, not only through employee share ownership schemes but, much more prevalently, through managerial arrangements where very well paid executives got into tax avoidance through schemes that were promoted aggressively by unscrupulous operators. That inquiry heard evidence that a conservative estimate of the contributions to such schemes was $1.5 billion. We on the Labor side suspected that it would be much larger than that, because that estimate was not much more than a back-of-the-envelope calculation.

There has been a proliferation of private binding rulings, and this legislation clarifies the rules applying to those rulings. In that sense, it is welcome legislation and Labor supports it. But, to give you some idea of the dimensions of the problem, during the inquiry about which I spoke we heard evidence on 11 May 2000 from officials of the tax office that every year the tax office would issue over 3,000 private binding rulings. That is an astonishingly large number of private binding rulings and it certainly does highlight the complexity of the tax system.

During the winter recess, while that inquiry was still under way, the Auditor-General issued a report entitled The Australian Taxation Office’s administration of taxation rulings. On page 99 of that report, it says:

quote.para: For the calendar year 2000 the ATO issued 89,779 PBRs ...

speech.para: No, you have not misheard me: it was not 8,900 private binding rulings but 89,779 in one year. Upon further investigation, it became clear that a large number of those were in relation to the so-called streamlined new tax system for the new century, the GST, which was meant to simplify tax arrangements. It had obviously done anything but that, as evidenced by the fact that the tax office in one year alone had to issue such a massive number of private binding rulings.

I have not been successful in obtaining information from the government on how many private binding rulings have been issued since then. I do believe that it would be in the public interest for us to know that. I am not sure that it is a state secret, but I am sure that the government is a little reluctant to provide that information. So, in anticipation of the debate, today I have lodged questions in writing. We will see if we have more luck in this term of the parliament in getting answers to those questions. I certainly will be pressing the matter if we have a repetition of the situation in the past, where I have put questions on the Notice Paper, have pleaded with the Speaker to get answers from the Treasurer and have been unsuccessful right through the term of the parliament. At the end of that parliament, those questions lapse. Then you start all over again and he just sweats it out for another three years. He will not get away with it this time. I will make a very big fuss about it if these basic figures are not provided.

Further evidence of the poor state of repair of the income tax base in Australia is provided by the annual statement of tax expenditures. These are basically the concessions, the tax breaks, that are available, which do cost money in revenue forgone but also have the characteristic of making the income tax system ever more complex. That does not mean that Labor or I oppose every such concession. For example, superannuation tax concessions are very important in promoting retirement incomes in this country. But, again to give you an idea of the dimensions of these concessions, there are now more than 240 tax expenditures and fully 89 of those have been created in just the last nine years of the coalition government. So, from the beginning of the Income Tax Act—I think it was 1932—through to 1996, in excess of 150 were created, but another 89 have been created in the short space of time since then. It shows that the income tax base in this country is under siege. It is under siege from a Treasurer who seems to place no weight on the integrity of the income tax system in this country.

Further evidence of that are the new business tax arrangements that were introduced in the year 2000. Some members will recall the Treasurer sitting at the table, completing the negotiations with the then shadow Treasurer, the member for Hotham. The whole basis of those negotiations was that, yes, there was a case for reducing the company tax rate from 36c to 30c in the dollar but that this would be self-financed. That is, it would be revenue neutral, paid for by removing some of the tax concessions, the tax breaks, in the system and therefore providing a simpler company income tax system. Quite important in that equation was legislation related to the alienation of personal services income, which meant that sham contractor arrangements would be seen through by the income tax system. We supported that legislation, but the long and short of it is that, very recently, documents that were obtained by the Australian newspaper under freedom of information legislation revealed that the government has no idea as to how that particular piece of legislation is working. In other words, it has not put any genuine effort into enforcing the legislation that was part of that arrangement between the two major political parties in this country.

I would also point out that part of that arrangement was the taxation of trusts in the same way as companies. The Treasurer signed a letter saying that would be part of improving the integrity of the income tax system, but he was rolled by the National Party. Here we have the Treasurer of the country being rolled by the member for New England, who himself was then rolled out of parliament. But the member for New England rolled the Treasurer and the government reneged on that commitment.

You do get a sense from what I am saying—89,000 private binding rulings, 240 special tax breaks, the breaking of promises in relation to improving the integrity of the income tax system—that this Treasurer does not have his heart in doing what he should be doing: his job of ensuring that there is tax integrity and some tax morality in this country. Indeed, in the past week the Treasurer has done more to debase tax morality in this country than any Treasurer for 25 years. It is a big statement and goes a long way back. But when we do go back 25 years to what I am referring to we reach the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, when the previous Liberal Party Treasurer, now the Prime Minister of Australia, presided over a massive tax evasion industry. It was called tax avoidance at that time, but it was outright evasion. They were contrived schemes. The Treasury begged the Treasurer of the day to legislate against the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes—the wet Slutzkins and the dry Slutzkins. He was dragged kicking and screaming, by Labor, to do something about it. The Treasurer of the day, the now Prime Minister, did not want to repair the income tax base back then. As a result, the remaining honest taxpayers were left with a top marginal rate of 60c in the dollar.

Let us remember that the top marginal tax rate under the Fraser-Howard government was 60c in the dollar. In fact, the relevant marginal rates were all high because the government needed to obtain from honest taxpayers the revenue that was being avoided or evaded by dishonest taxpayers. Does that sound familiar? Come forward 25 years and here we have the same Liberal philosophy; that is, if you have some wealthy mates who can go their hardest in avoiding or evading tax, this government almost says that that is a legitimate activity. The government turns a blind eye to it. As a result, we have had high marginal rates of income tax incurred by people who are not necessarily wealthy but who are honest—and that is the difference. The honest taxpayers confront the high marginal rates of tax.

The Australian newspaper, through a survey called HILDA, was able to confirm that the wealthiest Australians do not pay the top marginal rate of 48½c in the dollar. In fact, their average tax bill is about $28,000 a year, which is less than would be paid by an honest taxpayer earning $100,000 a year. For the very wealthy, the income tax system in Australia is essentially a voluntary tax, as it was when the current Prime Minister was the Treasurer of this country during the notorious bottom-of-the-harbour arrangements.

I say that the Treasurer has done more to debase tax morality in this country than any other Treasurer has for 25 years on the basis of the defence that he launched in favour of Mr Gerard. I recognise that I do not have the time to go through all of the statements that the Treasurer made in defending Mr Gerard, so I will point to only a couple to illustrate that point. The Treasurer said that Mr Gerard had ‘broken no law’. He got whacked with a penalty tax of 45 per cent. A penalty tax of 45 per cent is applied by the tax office in the case of blatant, contrived tax evasion arrangements. I do not think tax evasion should be condoned in this country, but the Treasurer spent last week saying that Mr Gerard was a fine man and a fine person to have on the board of the Reserve Bank. The Treasurer also said in this parliament that Mr Gerard had not avoided one dollar of tax—that was not for want of trying. Mr Gerard tried his little heart out to avoid paying $150 million of tax, but in the end he was caught by the tax office and defended stoutly by the Treasurer. The Treasurer said:

quote.para: ... Mr Gerard is eminently suitable to be a member of the Reserve Bank board.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. In examining the bill, I cannot find any determination, requirement or paragraph to do with Mr Gerard. I request that you bring the member back to the bill, which is the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005 and that he not continue some witch-hunt that the Labor Party is undertaking.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order: the Assistant Treasurer should have done his homework and looked at (3) of the second reading amendment to the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005, which condemns the government for:

quote.para: ... failure to clarify in this bill how the personal tax affairs of a taxpayer will be linked to the tax affairs of a company with which the taxpayer is associated.

talk.start.para: (Mr Baldwin)—There is no point of order.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I repeat that the Treasurer said:

quote.para: ... Mr Gerard is eminently suitable to be a member of the Reserve Bank board.

speech.para: There you go: someone who has been whacked with a 45 per cent penalty tax is eminently suitable! That tells us a lot about the philosophy of this government and about the approach of the Treasurer.

I do not always praise the member for Wentworth, Mr Turnbull, but on this occasion he has had the courage to say that the way to reduce high marginal rates of tax in this country is to repair the income tax base to remove some of these lurks, concessions and loopholes. That is what the member for Wentworth has been saying and he is right. Every self-respecting economist in Australia will tell you that the way forward for tax reform is to repair the income tax base and use the proceeds to reduce the marginal rates of tax that cause genuine disincentives in this country.

I have argued long and hard, and will continue to do so, that a very important rate to reduce is the 42c rate. The 42c rate is paid by one million taxpayers who earn between $70,000 and $125,000 a year. One million taxpayers at present confront the 42c rate, but within the next three years 400,000 more taxpayers will confront it. They will move from a marginal rate of 30c to a marginal rate of 42c. These are people who are trying to get ahead, who are deciding whether to go for promotions and whether to work overtime—and 42c is a pretty steep rate.

In a prebudget submission that I lodged with Treasury, upon invitation by the Treasurer to anyone who wanted to make a submission in advance of the budget, I suggested that an instalment could be made in the forthcoming budget to reduce the 42c rate to 36c, on the way to its total abolition—halfway, indeed, to its total abolition. If that were to happen, think of the sort of system we would have. Ninety-seven per cent of taxpayers would face a top marginal rate of no higher than 30c in the dollar. That is genuine incentive. That is the restoration of incentive to work hard and to improve oneself.

I differ from the member for Wentworth where he argues that the most important rate to reduce is the top marginal rate of 48½c in the dollar, counting the Medicare levy. That rate is paid by three per cent of taxpayers. It is clear to me that the much stronger case is to abolish the 42c rate.

But then we have to consider the forgotten people. Who are they? The forgotten people are those who are on incomes of between $22,000 and $52,000 a year. The parliament will be astonished with this fact: under this government, between the year 2000 and the year 2008, the forgotten people—hairdressers, receptionists, account clerks, metalworkers, farmhands and hospitality workers—will have had a tax cut totalling—wait for it—$4 a week. This is the famous ‘sandwich and milkshake’ tax cut that was delivered by this government in 2004. Yet by 2008, in that period, through bracket creep alone—that is just with the effects of inflation—they will be paying extra tax of between $17 and $31 a week.

The reality is that the forgotten people—those of them who do not have children and therefore do not benefit from increases in family payments or any family payments at all—are footing the bill for the family payments system, which has been extended in this country to the very wealthy. The forgotten people are being smashed by this government. They are being hit with incentive-crushing, high marginal rates of income tax, yet they will have had one tax cut, and one tax cut only, of $4 a week in the entire eight-year period from 2000 to 2008.

Their lot could be improved in a very affordable way by giving them a tax cut of $12 a week. How do we do that without making it completely unaffordable? The answer is: by increasing the low-income tax offset from $235 to $625 and converting it into a weekly or fortnightly pay-as-you-go payment. So they would get $12 a week, which is double the derisory tax cut that low- and middle-income earners received in the last budget; but the cut in the 42c rate to 36c would deliver very substantial tax cuts and improvements in incentives for people earning between $70,000 and $125,000. This proposal is a proposal for genuine reform. It is a down payment on an ultimate reform package that I also outlined in that submission. But, if we are going to genuinely achieve reform in this country, we must repair the income tax base.

This legislation simply highlights the numerous tax lurks, concessions and holes that this Treasurer has poked into the system, very much at the urging of those on his backbench. That is why people get into trouble with mass-marketed tax schemes—because the promoters of these schemes are forever saying, ‘I can give you 100 per cent return overnight if only you get into this scheme.’ People get into the scheme, get into trouble and the rest, as they say, is history. We support this legislation, but Labor fundamentally support genuine tax reform. That means repairing the income tax base in order to fund reductions in the high marginal rates of tax faced by people on welfare and by those in the middle-income and higher income reaches as well. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005. I probably will not be speaking about Robert Gerard this evening, because this amendment bill is really not about the high-flying, high-avoiding taxpayer. It is very much about the average taxpayer who pays their fair share, largely through PAYG—about eight million individual taxpayers and about 745,000 very small businesses that do the right thing and deserve the trust of our government in a way that Robert Gerard does not.

speech.para: Firstly, I would like to comment on the name of the amendment bill. In the last couple of weeks we have seen this government play very loose with names when it comes to the truth. We have seen a Fair Pay Commission which is not fair; Work Choice, which is not about choice; and Welfare to Work, which is not about getting people to work. When I first saw the name of this bill, ‘Improvements to Self Assessment’, I found myself thinking, ‘Oh no, they’re going to scrap self-assessment,’ because so far we have found very much with this government that the bill’s name usually reflects the exact opposite of the intent. But I am pleased to say that this bill really is about improvements to self-assessment, and it really does achieve substantial gains. I have not had much good to say about this government in the last couple of weeks, but I would like to acknowledge that this is a substantial improvement for nearly eight million individual taxpayers and 745,000 small businesses.

These amendments came about thanks to a report called Report on aspects of income tax self assessment, released by the Treasurer in December 2004. The review commenced in November the preceding year and examined whether the right balance had been struck between protecting the rights of individual taxpayers and protecting the revenue for the benefit of the whole Australian community. There were 30 legislative recommendations made in the review. The first of the bills which gave effect to some of these changes, the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No.1) 2005, was passed into law earlier this year with the support of the opposition. This second piece of legislation gives effect to the remainder of the reforms.

It is very rare that I would commend this government for acting quickly. Many reports brought down during the term of this government have been ignored completely. This is one case where there has been quite speedy action, although the calling of the review could have taken place a number of years earlier. The review recommended a number of refinements to the current self-assessment system that will reduce uncertainty and compliance costs for taxpayers while preserving the tax office’s capacity to collect legitimate income tax liabilities.

Our current self-assessment system was introduced in 1986-87 by the Hawke-Keating government. Under the self-assessment regime, taxpayers’ returns are generally accepted at face value in the first instance. A taxpayer submits their return to the ATO. Once the ATO receives the self-assessment—the tax return—it issues a notice of assessment. It is that assessment which creates the formal obligation to pay tax. Underpinning this whole process is the notion that the vast majority of taxpayers can be trusted—that they will act in good faith. Given the sheer complexity of tax law at the moment, one must also accept that even taxpayers acting in good faith will from time to time make mistakes in good faith. This amendment bill certainly recognises that.

The ATO does not usually check the accuracy of the tax return before sending out the notice of assessment, but it can, and often does, do it later. The ATO may verify the accuracy of the return and, if it so decides, amend its assessment of the tax return at a later time. The ATO now has the power to reopen assessments after many years. This leads to considerable uncertainty for taxpayers and many calls for constraints on the Commissioner of Taxation’s capacity to enforce payment and penalties long after the original tax return has been submitted. Concerns of this nature have received some attention recently because of schemes propagated by a number of promoters and mass-marketers. Many people were caught by these schemes, even though they appeared to be quite legitimate and the commissioner had given rulings which appeared to legitimise them.

This amendment makes substantial improvements to the self-assessment system and substantially swings the balance of power in the relationship between the Australian Taxation Office and the taxpayer towards the taxpayer. It moves the balance of fairness markedly in favour of taxpayers who act in good faith, and it does so in two main ways. It reduces the time period in which the ATO can audit and amend an assessment. For a taxpayer with simple tax affairs, it reduces the period from four years to two years and, for those with complex tax affairs, from six years to four years. For eight million individual taxpayers and 750,000-odd very small businesses, this creates certainty and closes the door on their tax returns within a reasonable time frame.

One unusual element in respect of the government’s approach to this amendment is that the bill does govern for people who behave well. I have said in this House recently that many of the past amendments to legislation that have been introduced by this government, whether they be about super choice, industrial relations or welfare to work, assume that the vast majority of people behave badly and that most people will break the law unless forced not to. This amendment, however, does completely the opposite. It builds on a level of trust that was established by the Keating and Hawke governments. It assumes that people act in good faith, and it does so until they are shown to have acted otherwise. It trusts taxpayers, and it reduces the time given to the ATO to revisit assessments to the minimum time required to do the job. In doing so, it reduces uncertainty for the taxpayer, or at least it does so for taxpayers who are doing the right thing. Where the ATO believes there is fraud or evasion, an unlimited amendment period continues to apply. The unlimited amendment period kicks in with cases of deliberate bad behaviour—that is, people who engage in calculated behaviour to avoid tax.

The amendment recognises that taxpayers need to operate in a state of certainty about the law. It recognises that people who seek the advice of the tax office and act on that advice should not be penalised later if the tax office changes its mind. The tax rulings system has been controversial for many years. Taxpayers have rightly complained that the commissioner can change his interpretation or withdraw a ruling after the event. There has also been consternation about relying on oral advice from the ATO and facing penalties later when the ATO changes its mind.

This bill outlines a whole new process by which private and public rulings are provided. There are a number of key changes. Firstly it ensures that, if a taxpayer relies upon ATO advice, including oral advice, the taxpayer will be free from penalties. An oral ruling can be requested, which becomes binding and provides protection from imposition of any additional primary tax and a later increase in the quantum of the original tax owing prior to interest or penalties—in other words, if the ATO gives the taxpayer advice and the taxpayer acts on that advice, the taxpayer is protected from changes later on. It expands situations in which the commissioner is bound by advice given to the taxpayer, and it specifies a time limit of 60 days on the provision of a ruling. After this period, the taxpayer can request a ruling within 30 days. If the commissioner fails to respond, this can form a valid objection to the commissioner’s assessment. Again, this provides a level of certainty for taxpayers making decisions about the way they conduct their affairs on a day-to-day basis. Originally the government planned that the legislative changes recommended in the review would apply to assessments from the 2004-05 income year. It did not meet that deadline; nevertheless, from December 2004 until now is really quite fast for this government, where we sometimes wait several years for promised action.

There are many who quite rightly criticise the government for the dramatic growth in the sheer height of the tax law. We do not deal with it in numbers of pages anymore; we measure it in inches. This amendment does simplify the tax regime for many taxpayers. It does not reduce the number of pages in the tax act, but it does make life simpler for hundreds of thousands of small businesses and millions of everyday taxpayers. Unfortunately it does not go far enough for the taxpayers already caught by past advice from the tax office, which some of my colleagues on this side of the House and some on the government’s side have already mentioned. We on this side would have liked to have seen some protection for those taxpayers who acted in good faith and have been caught much later in the ATO net. There is also a remaining unresolved issue about how the ATO will keep records of its oral advice so that taxpayers can be free from penalties when relying upon this advice, but on the whole they are small amendments. This is quite an effective amendment that provides certainty for millions of Australian taxpayers.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr BROUGH

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank all the members who participated in this debate for their contributions. The main objective of Australia’s tax system is to efficiently raise the revenue required to facilitate the good running of the country, the maintenance of things such as aged care, pensions, the Defence Force—and on it goes. We try to collect this revenue with the minimum administration and compliance costs possible. The Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005 goes to the heart of these issues.

speech.para: On 24 November 2003, the Treasurer announced a review of aspects of income tax self-assessment. The review examined aspects of Australia’s self-assessment system for income tax to determine whether the right balance had been struck between protecting the rights of the individual and protecting the revenue for the benefit of the whole Australian community. The review concluded that a number of refinements to the present arrangements were needed to improve certainty and reduce compliance costs for taxpayers without significantly affecting the capacity of the tax office to collect legitimate income tax liabilities.

This bill continues the process of reform of self-assessment by implementing the remaining legislative recommendations of the report. The first schedule of the bill makes a number of changes to reduce the period during which the Commissioner of Taxation may amend income tax assessment in a range of circumstances. The period in which the commissioner can amend an assessment for most individuals or very small businesses will be standardised at two years. A four-year period of review will apply for taxpayers with more complex affairs.

The period for review and amendment of assessments involving arrangements with a dominant tax avoidance purpose will be four years. This will reduce the current period, which is known as part IVA, antiavoidance provision, from six years and also applies to other cases with a dominant tax avoidance purpose. Where a taxpayer returns a nil tax liability for an income year, the taxpayer will have a limited period of review, either two or four years depending on the complexity of their affairs, rather than an unlimited period of review, as is presently the case.

Many people have suggested that the review of self-assessment provisions should be retrospective. This suggestion has been made in the light of the mass marketed schemes that were prevalent in the mid-nineties. This argument is often raised as a result of those issues, but if the government were to do that it would throw into doubt every assessment that has been lodged in good faith and would create an enormous amount of uncertainty. The commissioner, I might add, would still have four years to amend the circumstances for those individuals, so it is doubtful that many, if any, of those caught unfortunately in the mass marketed schemes would benefit from the retrospectivity of this particular bill.

Making the shorter review period recommendations retrospective would potentially reverse many amended assessments, including those based on general antiavoidance provisions in income tax legislation. It would also restrict the Commissioner of Taxation’s ability to raise amended assessments for those years, despite the claim of tax benefits being considered to be unavailable under the law. I am sure no genuine, honest member of parliament would want to see that happen. In such circumstances, the proposals would be unfair to those taxpayers who had correctly self-assessed their tax liability but who subsequently settled their disputes with the ATO. Moreover, retrospective operation would invalidate action taken by the commissioner that was sanctioned at the time, with a dramatic consequence for taxpayers’ confidence in the system. This is the reverse of what the review of aspects of tax assessment has set out to achieve.

The amendments proposed in this bill should be considered in a broader context. This government has a good record when it comes to improvements in tax administration, and this bill is merely the latest in a long list of changes. As the review points out, over the last few years this government has shortened the period of review for taxpayers with straightforward tax affairs, introducing binding oral advice, reducing the rate of interest on shortfalls and late payments, and introducing the office of the Inspector-General of Taxation, a new statutory officer with the responsibility for investigating systemic tax administration issues.

While dealing with the issue of binding oral advice, I know a couple of members, including the member for Parramatta, who is in the chamber currently, asked a question seeking clarification as to how that would apply. It is a valid question. This has always been a bone of contention with taxpayers who say that they have rung the ATO and been given some advice but it is not binding and they cannot clarify who it was from. Approximately $11 million has been allocated by the ATO to improve oral ruling systems, including introducing a voice recording system. An oral ruling includes a registration identifier—in other words, a number—so that the ruling can be identified, if required, at a later time. This is under proposed subsection 360-54 of schedule 1 to the Taxation Administration Act.

In line with recommendation 2.24 in the report of aspects of income tax self-assessment, which is an administrative recommendation, the ATO has purchased voice recording equipment which, when it is fully rolled out, will provide a more robust recording system for oral advice. The first phase of the implementation of the new oral advice recording system will occur from early 2006. To put everyone’s mind at rest, this will allow taxpayers to ring the ATO to get either binding tax advice or a ruling. They need to keep that number in their records so that, if they are ever audited or questioned at some stage further down the track by the ATO, they simply quote that number and it will refer to a particular oral ruling that has been provided. This is a quantum leap forward from where we have been in the past. It provides certainty and confidence to taxpayers that the advice and the rulings that they are receiving can be relied upon.

Importantly, schedule 1 to this bill improves certainty by reducing the periods allowed for the Taxation Office to increase a taxpayer’s liability in a wide range of situations. Around eight million individuals and over 745,000 very small businesses will have a shorter period of review. The changes will take effect with the assessment of the 2004-05 and later years of income.

The second schedule to the bill implements a better framework for the provision of tax office advice. The tax office presently gives a wide range of advice to taxpayers and their representatives about how, in the commissioner’s opinion, the tax laws apply or would apply. That advice ranges from general information to the public to advice relating to specific taxpayers and arrangements. This schedule expands the current advice and ruling framework in scope and effectiveness to provide protection in a wider range of circumstances. I thank the member for Parramatta for her acknowledgment of that very fact.

Under the new framework, all tax office advice provides a level of protection for taxpayers who have acted in good faith and who have reasonably relied on that advice. In addition, this schedule expands the categories of legally binding advice to cover matters of administration, procedure and collection. Importantly, this schedule improves the arrangements for taxpayers to find out the commissioner’s view about how the taxation laws apply so that the risk of uncertainty when they are self-assessing is reduced. The changes will take effect from 1 January 2006 or from royal assent, whichever is the later. The measures contained in this bill are important steps in improving the taxpayers’ experience of the self-assessment system. The government is committed to improving certainty for taxpayers by improving the Australian taxation system, and this bill is just another example of that commitment.

The member for Hunter raised one other issue I will deal with before closing, and that was in relation to the shortfall interest charge changes applying retrospectively. This bill does not contain the government’s shortfall interest charge changes at all. Those changes were dealt with by the parliament in the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 1) 2005, which received royal assent on 29 June 2005. Those changes are not part of this bill at all.

For the reasons I have outlined above, I commend the bill to the House. I am sure that Australian taxpayers will have a better relationship with the tax office and continue to have strong confidence in the tax office. Most importantly, they can now get things such as oral rulings, know that they are binding and have confidence that the advice they have received can be relied upon. The period that taxpayers have to retain their records, the period in which the ATO can go back and review the predominant number of Australian taxpayers, has been reduced. This legislation gets the balance right between the need to raise revenue in a fair and equitable manner in the interests of the nation and protecting the interests of the taxpayer. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: (Mr Wilkie)—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Hunter has moved as an amendment that all words after ‘That’ be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

speech.para: Question agreed to.
Original question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebateinfo.title: Consideration of Senate Message and Unrelated Amendments

amendment.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 2, page 3 (table item 2, 3rd column), omit “$1,708,574,000”, substitute “$1,711,574,000”.
(2) Schedule 1, item 2, page 3 (table item 3, 3rd column), omit “$1,671,190,000”, substitute “$1,673,153,000”.
(3) Schedule 1, item 2, page 3 (table item 4, 3rd column), omit “$1,685,437,000”, substitute “$1,680,474,000”.

talk.start.para: —It is my duty to make a statement to the House concerning two of the Senate amendments with respect to this bill and the matters of constitutional principle they raise. I understand that proposed Senate amendments (1) and (2) will, if enacted, have the effect of moving expenditure between financial years. The view has been taken that legally this would amount to a change in the destination of the appropriation. There is doubt that the Senate may proceed in these circumstances by way of amendment because of section 53 of the Constitution. Among other things, this section prohibits the Senate from amending a bill so as to increase ‘any proposed charge or burden on the people’.

speech.para: I am advised that the view has been taken that, where expenditure is to be transferred in such circumstances, section 56 of the Constitution requires that the proposed appropriation must be recommended by a message from the Governor-General. I understand that such a message has been obtained in this case. The House will need to consider the way in which it should proceed to deal with the matters raised in Senate amendments (1) and (2). If it wishes to entertain the proposals reflected in the amendments, it may choose to proceed by alternative means. The matter for consideration is not so much one of the privileges and rights between the two houses as one of observance of the requirements of the Constitution concerning the appropriation of revenue.

para.inline: That the House endorse the statement of the Deputy Speaker in relation to the constitutional questions raised by Message No. 216 transmitted by the Senate in relation to the Higher Education Legislation Amendment (2005 Budget Measures) Bill 2005.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: —I would like to indicate to the House that the government proposes that Senate amendment (3) be agreed to, that amendments (1) and (2) be disagreed to, but that amendments be made in place thereof and that a further relevant amendment be made. I suggest, therefore, that it may suit the convenience of the House to first consider amendment (3) and when that amendment has been disposed of to consider amendments (1) and (2) and then the further amendment. I move:

para.inline: That Senate amendment (3) be agreed to.

speech.para: Senate amendment (3) decreases the 2008 other grants funding under the Higher Education Support Act 2003 to reflect the bringing forward of 2008 funding for the University of Western Sydney to the 2006 and 2007 funding years. Because there are no constitutional issues surrounding an amendment which decreases an appropriation, this amendment made by the Senate can be agreed to by the House.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak very briefly in support of the amendment and thank the Senate for their work in putting this proposal forward. The University of Western Sydney is very much an icon over a very large area, and it is extremely important to the people of the area. It is a very young university, with particular needs because of its youth—the need to grow its campuses, the need to grow its courses and the need to grow its student population. Also, it has a particular problem because of the sheer area it covers. With campuses spread over an enormous area, it can take 45 minutes to one hour to travel from one end to the other. The university has asked that the funding be brought forward, with $3 million in 2006. The Senate has moved an amendment in accordance with that, and I thank them very much for doing that and support the amendment.

—I add my support to the support that has been voiced by the member for Parramatta. The University of Western Sydney has asked that funding be brought forward, and we are strongly supportive of the additional funding going to the university. It is much needed, as the member for Parramatta has outlined, and I formally indicate the opposition’s support.
—The question is that Senate amendment (3) be agreed to.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: —I thank the opposition for agreeing to that amendment. I move:

para.inline: That Senate amendments (1) and (2) be disagreed to.

speech.para: Without repeating my earlier comments in support of the Deputy Speaker’s statement regarding the constitutional questions raised by Senate amendments (1) and (2), I need to point out to the House that these amendments would have increased the University of Western Sydney’s other grants funding for 2006 and 2007 to reflect the bringing forward of funds from 2008. The amendments I will shortly be moving will pick up on the intent of Senate amendments (1) and (2). I point out that it is at the particular request of the University of Western Sydney and that it will enable the university to move more quickly in its new building program, which was supported by the Australian government in this year’s budget and, as we have just heard, by the opposition.

talk.start.para: —The question is that Senate amendments (1) and (2) be disagreed to.

speech.para: Question agreed to.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation for the bill and proposed amendments announced.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: —I move amendments (2) and (3) in place of the Senate’s amendments which have been disagreed to:

amendment.para: (2) Schedule 1, item 2, page 3 (cell at table item 2, 3rd column), omit the cell, substitute:
(3) Schedule 1, item 2, page 3 (cell at table item 3, 3rd column), omit the cell, substitute:

speech.para: These amendments have two purposes. Firstly, amendment (2) will facilitate the transfer of unspent collaboration and structural reform—or CASR—funds from 2005 to 2006 by increasing the appropriation for other grants for 2006. Secondly, amendments (2) and (3) will also accommodate the intent of Senate amendments (1) and (2), disagreed to by the House for constitutional reasons, by increasing other grants funding for the University of Western Sydney for 2006 and 2007 to reflect the bringing forward or rephasing of 2008 funding for UWS. These amendments affirm the government’s commitment to more efficiently facilitating UWS campus developments and to promoting university collaboration and restructuring. I commend the amendments to the House and present the supplementary explanatory memorandum.

talk.start.para: —While we will not oppose these amendments, because we do not want the money to be lost to the universities, it is very disappointing that the government has not been able to spend this money, given the huge demand in our universities for the funding from the Collaboration and Structural Reform Fund. As I understand it, the whole purpose of the fund is to achieve better higher education outcomes in teaching, learning, research and innovation by promoting structural reform in the sector. I think these might even be the government’s own words. So it is very disappointing to see that we have such a serious level of underspending.

speech.para: As I understand it, we have had a mere 10 projects funded this year, with a total amount of $3.8 million allocated from a $41 million program which was supposed to fund over $13 million this year. I am sure many of the universities are very disappointed that so much money that could have been allocated and that could be put to good use at so many places around the country is not being spent. We are very disappointed. I think it is certainly not good for the universities to see the government fall behind in this way. Nevertheless, it is very important that the money stay in the fund.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: —I can assist the opposition in this regard. The Collaboration and Structural Reform Fund is, as the member for Jagajaga points out, intended precisely for that—collaboration and structural reform. It is one of many facets of the $11 billion reform program in higher education. I made a conscious decision to rephase the money and not to specifically fund all of the projects that came forward this year. The reason for that is that the 10 that I agreed to fund as the minister responsible were those that I really thought would deliver collaboration and structural reform—that five or 10 years from now we would look back and think, ‘Yes, reform was achieved through the expenditure in that way.’ There were a myriad of other projects which came forward which had value, but I could not see that there would be significant reform in the sector as a consequence of that. I have informed the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and other people in the sector of the reasons for the decision, and I think it is fair to say that they are quite comfortable with the outcome.

—I thank the minister for that. I would be interested to know how many applications were received and would appreciate it if the minister could let us know, maybe after this debate, which applications were not agreed to, given that I think both sides of the parliament agree on the importance of collaboration. I do think that this is a way for the university sector to go. I would be interested to understand from the minister how many and which applications were rejected.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: —I move the further relevant amendment (1):

amendment.para: (1) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 10), after item 1, insert:
1A Subsection 41‑45(1) (cell at table item 1, column headed “Amount”)

speech.para: This amendment will facilitate the transfer of the unspent collaboration and structural reform funds from 2005 to 2006 by decreasing the 2005 appropriation for other grants under the Higher Education Support Act. Amendment (2) provided for the related increase in CASR funding for 2006. This will facilitate earlier and more considered allocation of CASR funding for applicants in 2006.

talk.start.para: —Minister, will you provide us with the number of applications and those that were not successful?

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: —I will take the question on notice. I will certainly provide the opposition with information in terms of how many institutions applied and the variety of purposes for which applications for grants were made, but I will take advice on the consequences of publishing all of the applications that came forward.

speech.para: There were a number of applications which my department recommended not be funded, there were others they recommended could be funded but advised were not of particularly high quality and there were others that were recommended as being able to be funded. As I said earlier, the reality is that those which I did not provide funding for were very worthy projects; I am not suggesting for one minute that they were not worthy. But, in terms of driving medium- to long-term reform in the sector, they certainly did not meet that benchmark and in many cases were things that I think the universities ought to be doing in any case.

I will take advice on it. So long as it is not prejudicial to the institutions or the individuals who applied for them, I would be happy to make that information available to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.
Question agreed to.

debateinfo.title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT AMENDMENT (ABOLITION OF COMPULSORY UP-FRONT STUDENT UNION FEES) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 May, on motion by Dr Nelson:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —It is a great pleasure for me to rise in support of the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. It is longstanding coalition policy, and I will be very pleased when it finally passes though parliament.

speech.para: Since the resumption of this debate, I have been reminded by colleagues that similar legislation aimed at ensuring that freedom of association principles apply to all Australian students has, in fact, been introduced in every parliamentary term since the first coalition victory in 1996. It is about time this legislation was passed by the parliament so that Australian students, including those living in the electorate of Stirling, are able to choose how to spend their money and the organisations they want to be members of.

This bill will amend the Higher Education Support Act 2003 to prohibit all higher education providers, both public and private, from requiring a person to become a member of a student association, such as a union or guild. It will also prohibit all higher education providers from requiring that students pay fees for non-academic student services.

As a Western Australian and former university student, the debate about voluntary student unionism is one that I have followed closely. As a student, I was forced to pay guild fees, regardless of whether or not I utilised the services on offer. It is a situation that all Australian students currently face. As somebody who believes that in our democracy nobody should be forced to join an organisation, I am passionately opposed to compulsory student unionism. I will always defend the right to free association and freedom of choice, just as I will the right to freedom of speech.

I have been amazed by some of the comments that have been made in this place prior to this debate being resumed tonight. The Labor Party have spent a lot of time lately talking about freedom of association, yet they plainly want to deny Australian students this basic right. The arguments that have been put by some on the other side of the House have, in some cases, been plainly ridiculous. Members opposite have stood in this chamber time after time and tried to make out that this is some sort of ideological debate designed to crush student guilds and the student union movement. But nothing could be further from the truth. This bill is about choice and giving university students the freedom to exercise that basic democratic right.

In the arguments put, those on the other side of the House have claimed some extraordinary things. They have tried to claim that this bill will do everything from jeopardising Australia’s proud sporting identity to suppressing freedom of speech, even to undermining the values of Australian mateship. Listening to those on the other side, I am reminded of one of the sad realities of modern day politics, which is that those on the Left no longer value freedom and are always ready to use coercion to get what they want. It is part of an intellectual snobbery that people on the left of politics always believe they know what is best for other people. They think that, if we allow people to exercise their own free will, it will result in terrible things, which the smarter people in the Australian Labor Party know are not good for them.

Listening to previous opposition speakers, you would think that this bill abolished student unions—you would think that the government were pursuing a vendetta against their ideological opponents to wipe these organisations from the face of university campuses. That is simply not the case. All we are doing is providing students with the freedom to choose whether or not they wish to join these organisations.

The higher education support amendment is about the right of students to choose whether or not they will pay for a service or product that they do or do not require. It is about the right of people to complete their education and receive their results without being forced to join a particular organisation or pay for a service that they do not want or need. It is about the right of students to spend their money on textbooks or sporting activities that they enjoy, not on those that they do not, and the right of students to support a political party that they believe in instead of the one that the student association likes most.

The National Union of Students, an organisation that receives $5 per full-time student from every affiliated organisation, spent almost a quarter of a million dollars at the last election campaign playing politics. Considering where this money ended up, it is no wonder that the Australian Labor Party want to defend the privileged status of these organisations on Australian campuses. I have no doubt that much of the membership of the organisations from which the money had been compulsorily acquired would have preferred to have seen the money spent on services.

I cannot think of any other area of life where people are forced to join a specific organisation, and I cannot think of any rational argument about why Australian students should be exempted from these fundamental rights. In all the political posturing and scaremongering that we have seen about this bill, I am yet to find one person who has answered either of these questions satisfactorily. Instead, the ALP have argued in this place that we must have compulsory student unionism because if we do not student unions will collapse.

It is a telling argument that speaks volumes about the Labor Party’s belief that no-one would want to be part of a student guild or union unless they are forced to be. Can there be any clearer indication that even the opposition know that students do not value the frolics of their current unions in their present state? And why should they? Woeful unions around the country waste the forcefully acquired money they get on such things as stickers that urge students to bomb the White House, which was done in appalling taste after the attacks of September 11. As I detailed earlier, they have also used other people’s money to campaign for a Labor victory during last year’s election.

As we are resuming this debate—and it has been some time since this matter was last debated in this place—I would like to remind those present about some of the other contributions that have been made, because I think that they bear repeating. The member for Boothby pointed out in his speech that last year, during the six-week period of the federal election campaign, the National Union of Students spent over $75,000 on broadcasting electoral advertisements, over $40,000 publishing such electoral advertisements, nearly $50,000 on producing campaign material like how-to-vote cards, posters and pamphlets, and almost $90,000 on direct mailing. That is over a quarter of a million dollars of students’ money being used to campaign during the last federal election. To emphasise the point about which party this advertising favoured, the mailing address on the NUS return mail to the Australian Electoral Commission is ‘care of Trades Hall, Victoria’.

This would be quite a different proposition if the funding to student unions had been given voluntarily by people who shared the political views of the NUS. But that is not the case. We need to be reminded that this money was compulsorily acquired. Given that, I am not surprised that the ALP wants to defend its mates. I would venture to say that much of the money spent funding this electioneering previously belonged to students who would rather have seen that money spent on services on campus.

Claims from the other side of this House that allowing students to choose what services they use at the university or whether to join a student union or association will destroy sport in this great nation are equally ludicrous. Ensuring that someone who does not play sport does not have to pay for the upkeep of university soccer ovals and squash courts will not reduce participation when the student was never involved to start with.

It may come as a surprise to some members of this House that voluntary student unionism does not spell the end of student unionism and student guilds. We only need to look at the experience of Western Australian universities when the Court government introduced voluntary student unionism in 1995 to see that democracy and student representative bodies can actually coexist.

Between 1995 and 2002, student unionism was voluntary at Western Australian universities. The practice of voluntary student unionism in WA did not decimate sport in Western Australian universities. It did not silence student guilds and indeed it did not remove or damage the concept of Australian mateship. What it did do—and I think this is very important—was force the various student organisations and bodies to focus on providing services that were of value to students. Funnily enough, I always assumed that this was what a representative organisation was supposed to do—provide services that were valued by its members.

In 1998 a study was commissioned to report on voluntary student unionism in Western Australia. The review studied the impact of voluntary student unionism on Western Australian universities. A quick flick through the pages of the report shows that, rather than services reducing during this period, they actually improved. The report concludes:

quote.para: ... most student services have been maintained since the implementation of VSU in Western Australia.

speech.para: It goes on to say:

quote.para: ... Despite the introduction of VSU, student guilds have, in most cases, added services in response to the needs of their members. This has been achieved with lower guild fees and without university loans or subsidies.

speech.para: In short, when VSU was implemented, student guilds and associations in Western Australia became better and more responsive organisations. They provided services that responded to their members’ needs. And all this happened despite a smaller membership base and less income.

Far from demonstrating the need for compulsory student unionism, the Western Australian experience demonstrates the very reason that we need to have voluntary student unionism Australia wide. We need to do it not only to ensure that students enjoy the same freedom of association as all others in our community but to ensure that student organisations are accountable and responsive to their members.

It is unfortunate that this promising start to voluntary student unionism in Western Australia was summarily dismantled when the current Gallop Labor administration was elected. Labor has turned the clock back in WA and made students pay compulsory up-front fees unrelated to academic study for purely ideological reasons. It was a costly and retrograde decision for university students.

The decision to reinstate compulsory up-front fees was made despite overwhelming evidence that the voluntary system was working. As a result, students in my electorate of Stirling—and those in your electorate of Swan, Mr Deputy Speaker Wilkie—are now forced to spend their hard-earned cash on amenities fees that fund services that they do not use, that they have no intention of using and that they will not use in the future—essentially to fund services that they simply do not want.
