I mention that simply for the fact that Peter did not just affect people politically as a person of substance and a person standing in our movement; Peter affected people personally. He affected people personally the world over, including in the halls of power in Beijing. He was an internationalist, a citizen of the world, the international secretary of our party and a person who had as one of his ambitions for his life ahead how to craft a new page in Australia’s relationship with China, the economy which he identified as being the economy that would become the largest in the world in the 21st century and therefore one which would be of great import to Australia’s future as well.

He was an intellectual, an internationalist and also, as I said, a passionate social democrat. Peter Cook was a social democrat, a Labor man to his boots. Many have spoken of his background at a time when of course I did not know him. But, if you worked with him in this place, you always sensed that in him, through his veins, coursed the blood of the Australian labour movement. He had about him a passion as a Labor man, a Labor politician, the product of the labour movement, which you stood in awe of. Here was a man who, when it came to industrial relations reform, understood what it was like to get the balance right between bringing about flexibility in our labour market and at the same time not jeopardising the legitimate demands of working people for basic protections, both in the wages they earned and in the conditions they had in their workplace. Peter was always working his way through these challenges—but in a way which was rooted in his compassion and his deep orientation as a social democrat. He was an intellectual, an internationalist and a passionate social democrat.

Peter was also a total professional, and it is here that I would like to make some remarks today about his achievement in the trade portfolio. In an interview soon after he took over the trade portfolio in March 1993, Peter described himself as ‘a trade junkie’. Developing a particular interest in trade as a backbencher, including during his time as chair of the committee on trade and resources, Peter took to the portfolio with great enthusiasm, saying in an interview at the time:

quote.para: For me coming to the portfolio is in many ways an ambition that I hold. I am excited at the challenges of this portfolio. It is one that I have had an interest in for a long time.

speech.para: Many of those speaking in this debate today have spoken about Peter Cook and his role in this portfolio. It was through that portfolio that he dealt with many of us.

It may come as a surprise to many members participating in the debate, as it did to me, to actually look back at the relatively short time that Peter held the portfolio. He became Minister for Trade on 24 March 1993 and remained in that portfolio until 30 January 1994. However, in a little over 10 months, Peter had the good fortune, the good timing and, above everything else, the great capacity and intellect to deal with the trade matters which were then of great importance to our country. Within a short period, Peter had mastered the brief and skilfully prosecuted Australia’s interests in the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations, successfully assisting in drawing that round to a conclusion at the end of 1993.

As part of that round, Peter also played the important role of chairing the Cairns Group of free trading agriculture-producing countries that was established by Labor earlier and was successful in getting agriculture onto the international trade agenda. At the time of its conclusion, the Uruguay Round was described by the GATT, the forerunner to the WTO, as the most complex round of multilateral trade negotiations in GATT history. The round entailed item by item and formula reductions, resulting in tariff reductions by industrialised countries by one-third on average. Agriculture, textiles and clothing were finally brought into the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

There were new agreements on services known as GATS and on intellectual property known as trade related intellectual property, or TRIPS. This became an alphabet soup in which Peter was one of our party’s few exponents and capable of simultaneous bilingual interpretation. This was a challenge which Peter took further during his chairmanship of the Senate inquiry into the Australia-US FTA. This was a difficult task but one which, once again, Peter took to with his characteristic enthusiasm, drawing on his great trade knowledge and ultimately steering a course for the Labor Party that included the development of Labor’s amendments on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and local content on television. The Uruguay Round also agreed to establish the World Trade Organisation, an institution which greatly respected Peter’s contribution and which he continued to visit and work for in different capacities, including authoring a manual on the workings of the WTO for developing countries. If ever there is evidence of someone’s commitment as an internationalist, it lies in Peter’s work on that score.

The Uruguay Round was of major significance to Australia. In addition to reducing industrial tariffs and establishing new rules for trade in services, the Uruguay Round was particularly important for Australia’s rural industries as it finally managed to get agriculture onto the table. Notwithstanding significant resistance from protectionist forces, most notably the European Community, we nonetheless prevailed. The last few frenzied hours at Uruguay and the intransigence of the French—does anything ever change?—in particular are apparent from the following description contained in a Sydney Morning Herald article of 18 December 2003 which reflects back on that period:

quote.para: At the stage in the exhausting proceedings when the chief American negotiator, Mr Mickey Kantor, had lost his voice, when at least one senior figure had to be held up in public for fear that he would fall over and go to sleep, and when Australia’s Trade Minister, Senator Peter Cook, was shivering with a 24 hour virus, the French were still going strong in arguing their case.

speech.para: When we consider the current difficulties of the Doha Round in the lead-up to next week’s ministerial meeting in Hong Kong, it appears that very little has changed with regard to the EU’s attitude to liberalising trade. It is always a difficult and arduous process—step by step, clause by clause, tariff by tariff.

Peter, however, took to all this with great energy, great commitment and, for Australia, great success. In Peter’s view, the EU was so caught up in the question of tradition, culture, special interests and internal wrangles that it was no more than seeking for itself to become a short-term winner at the expense of the rest of the international economy. The long-term winners would be those economies with the dynamism and the courage to seize the challenges and to restructure themselves to take full advantage of the liberalising world trade environment.

In his Senate valedictory speech in June this year, Peter said that the trade achievement he revered the most was the opportunity to serve his country and negotiate in the endgame of the Uruguay Round. In doing so, he recognised the work of the preceding ministers, who had worked for more than eight years prior to that on those negotiations. Those remarks by Peter again reflect the man’s modesty in reflecting on the contributions of others.

Again it is important to go back to the time of the conclusion of the round in December 1993. While Peter had been a part of a significant achievement, there remained a sense of frustration emanating from Peter’s great understanding of the contribution of trade liberalisation to economic growth and development. Peter told the final session of the round:

quote.para: It’s three years overdue. Had we got there sooner, the international recession might not have occurred or been as deep as it was. The truth is if we’d got there earlier many more people would have been in full employment, fewer businesses would have gone bankrupt and world growth would have been better.

speech.para: Thus spoke Australia’s Minister for Trade, Peter Cook, with characteristic Australian candour. As Minister for Trade in 1993, Peter also had the opportunity to represent Australia at the fifth APEC ministerial meeting before the first APEC leaders meeting held in Seattle. Peter understood fully the complementary and supportive role APEC played in pursuing Australia’s multilateral trade and investment objectives at the regional level throughout the Asia-Pacific. Peter continued to be a great supporter of APEC, believing it had an essential role to play in developing a more prosperous and stable network for Australia. While he chaired the Senate inquiry into the Australia-US FTA and conjured a way forward for us, Peter always remained a multilateralist at heart. After all, that is where the biggest trade and economic gains were to be had for Australia, that is where the biggest trade and economic gains were to be had for the developing world and that is where the biggest trade and economic gains were to be had for the global economy overall.

Peter cemented his beliefs in Labor’s trade policy platform—a platform which committed Australia to continuing Australia’s firm commitment to an open international economy, a commitment that recognises the importance of free trade as the means of generating the growth necessary for enhancing the living standards of every Australian. This was the intellectual battle in which Peter Cook engaged; this was the intellectual battle in which he prevailed. On trade, as the current occupant of the shadow portfolio, I have a great sense of coming after someone who has been very great indeed in the execution of their responsibilities within this portfolio. These are very big shoes to fill.

On a personal level, I had the great privilege, as I mentioned before, to visit Peter in hospital in Sydney only several weeks ago. Visiting him in hospital, I could not but be impressed by Peter’s singular tenacity, his absolute belief in his ability to prevail despite this thing. We talked of little else but sailing. I gave him a book about sailing. I am pleased to report that he did not already have that book on sailing. Sailing was his passion, as so many have said in this debate. But, beyond sailing, you could not keep Peter down. There he was, sitting in his wheelchair, holding forth on how we should go forward in order to win. He provided me with at least three recommendations to place before the strategy group of our party when we next met. So much for Peter being burdened by the challenges he faced. His wife, Barbara, about whom the Deputy Leader of the Opposition spoke so eloquently, has been the complete living embodiment of a tower of strength—such extraordinary love, such extraordinary devotion, such extraordinary strength.

So how do we sum up the man, Peter Cook? An intellectual, an internationalist, a passionate social democrat, a professional, a trade professional, a person whose motivation in politics was driven by his deep compassion for people who had grown up on the wrong side of the tracks and, beyond all that, a person gifted with great tenacity to see the job through. Peter Cook, we the party, the people and the parliament all salute you.

talk.start.para: —Peter Cook and I met on 10 January 1984 in Old Parliament House. On that day, I had started working for the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Peter Walsh. I was walking along the corridor with its creaky floorboards and a dank smell about the place. I suppose that is an apt description of the Senate at times. It certainly was then, but it is vastly improved now. As I walked past a fairly young bloke—I was quite a bit younger—someone said, ‘This is Cookie.’ I thought it was good to meet a new staff member. There I was just finding my feet and I had already met another staff member, Cookie. So fondly was he regarded around the place that he was not called Senator Cook or Peter, but Cookie. Everyone from the Labor people to Senator Messner and Senator Chaney knew him as Cookie. Such people held Cookie in very high regard from those very early days onward—and he had been elected only a year earlier.

speech.para: The next big memory that I have of Peter was in the uranium debate within the ALP at the 1984 conference. It was a debate which, understandably, was full of emotion. Peter himself had to make a big decision on that. He was in the Centre Left grouping, and the Centre Left would ultimately determine the position of the party on the uranium issue. There were a lot of arguments coming from the Right and from the Left. Peter was being hammered from both sides really. I remember how he agonised about that. He ultimately supported the position of the Right, but only after going through a lot of soul searching, checking his conscience and seeing whether it was the right thing to do by the people of Australia. He made that judgment. Whether the judgment was right or wrong is not a matter for debate here today. I was very taken by how committed Peter was to getting what he believed to be a good decision.

That took us to the end of 1984. Not long after—early in 1985—we began the great tax debate. We seem to have them every 20 years or so. We certainly had a big one back then. In the 1984 election campaign, Bob Hawke had decided to say that we would have a tax summit. A lot of people who were into heavy-handed control thought that that was a particularly stupid idea, but nevertheless Bob thought that it was a way of dealing with the tax issues without having to have every detail of every possible tax change in front of the Australian people at that time.

We had the great tax debate of 1985. The GST was around then, and Treasury were very firm advocates of it. They thought it was beaut. In particular, it would have the value of being able to cut the top marginal rate of tax, a rate which many Treasury officials confronted. Along with many other ‘productive’ people in the community, they thought that that was a pretty good thing. They saw the broad based consumption tax as a way of doing that. I was a fresh economist on staff. From my training, I would ordinarily have been obliged to think that it was a good idea too, but I did not. And Peter Cook was a bit of a sceptic. I can reveal now that Cookie and I ‘cooked up’ more than one or two papers on what a dreadful thing this broad based consumption tax was. Peter bore a few scars by releasing those papers, arguing against the broad based consumption tax, on his own behalf and on behalf of others in the Centre Left.

Nevertheless, the white paper was produced. The broad based consumption tax was option (c). There was an option (a), which was ultimately adopted. No-one ever really talks about option (b), which was our option. That shows what an inspired idea option (b) turned out to be. Peter believed that a GST would be very unfair—that low-income earners could not be compensated adequately for it, that it would rise over time and that it would not bring the great benefits claimed in terms of export competitiveness and improved incentives. I think that Peter was right then and that his view is right now. Nevertheless, we have the GST. It is a $38 billion tax and no-one is seriously arguing that we should get rid of it.

Peter applied the same standards to the debate on the GST: what would this particular policy proposal do for the Australian people and, most particularly, what impact would it have on the most vulnerable in our community? On the basis of believing that a broad based consumption tax would have an adverse impact on the most vulnerable in our community, Peter opposed it.

Our next engagement was in relation to Tasmanian forests. Peter had a really hard brief here. Graham Richardson was advocating—as was I, I must say—a very expansive policy in protecting the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests of Tasmania. We held the Helsham inquiry and ended up adopting the minority position against the majority position. The minority position was to put on the World Heritage List a very large tract of land—I think 282,000 hectares give or take an inch. Peter’s job was to run the contrary case within the cabinet. He had developed a much smaller set of proposals. We were despatched by Bob Hawke to go to Tasmania and see if we could get some support for this much more modest proposal.

Someone who did have a view on forest policy in Tasmania was Lloyd Rees, a rather well-known painter. Through his son we visited Lloyd. Peter eloquently, I must say, put the strongest possible case as to why this was a responsible forest policy. It took about three hours of having cups of tea and then, at the end of it, after Lloyd had taken in all of the arguments, Peter said, ‘What do you think, Lloyd?’ Lloyd said, ‘Yes, but why do you want to cut down the trees?’ I thought that said it all. So we reported back to Bob Hawke that Lloyd had a fairly clear view that the trees should not be cut down, and probably the proposal that ultimately got up would have been unsatisfactory to Lloyd too because it did involve cutting down some trees. But it was certainly a memorable experience for all of us.

Peter was promoted to cabinet by Paul Keating when Paul became Prime Minister. The fundamental reason why Peter was promoted to cabinet was that he always ran the arguments, he ran the case. What Paul used to say about Cookie was that he would run the brief of his department. They did not necessarily have to agree with every aspect, but Paul fundamentally believed that the various portfolio ministers should come together and represent the views of their departments. They could depart from them but they should put that view into the policy debate in the cabinet room. Peter was fantastic at that. He worked tirelessly to get across those briefs and always put the best possible argument in the cabinet process. That is why Peter was promoted permanently to cabinet by Paul Keating.

I then dropped out of the scene for a fair while but, on coming back in 1998, there we were again: fighting the GST. I was again delighted to work with Peter as he chaired the Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee inquiry into the GST and a new tax system. I am sure that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would agree that Peter worked tirelessly on that, day in, day out and all around the country, again bringing forward all the arguments but with that fundamental criterion in mind: what does this proposal do to the most vulnerable people in our country? On that basis Peter was again able to say that he did not support the GST.

We then moved on to a Economics References Committee inquiry into the Fair Prices and Better Access for All (Petroleum) Bill 1999—petrol prices are in the news again—and Peter again applied that rigour. We produced what I think was a very responsible report. It was not just opportunistic, saying, ‘Oh, petrol prices are high; they ought to do something about it.’ Specific proposals came out of that report. Those proposals are still relevant today, and again there was the rigour and energy that Peter applied to it. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition referred to a trip to China, which I think was a real highlight of all our careers, not only for the great work and the level at which we were engaged but the camaraderie that we enjoyed as we got to know each other. It was just a fantastic time. Peter was the great helmsman. He got us around China and into all of these meetings, and he did it with great distinction, the sort of distinction that he had gained in the negotiations in which he was so deeply involved towards the end of the Uruguay Round. It was, as others have said, a highlight of his career to be able to sign off on that Uruguay Round.

I will speak a bit more about trade in a moment, but the other great achievement of Peter Cook, Cookie, was the introduction of enterprise bargaining. It seems to me that that is the fundamental reform that has led to so much productivity growth, together with the other economic reforms. In the labour market that is the reform that created genuine productivity growth, not what the government is going on with now. That is not reform; that is just brutality. Enterprise bargaining was not an easy transition. In convincing the union movement and employers that this was a good thing, but particularly the union movement, Peter had to apply all his skills, good graces and goodwill. He did that with distinction. It made me think that if you had a career and you wanted to say, ‘I did two great things. I had two great achievements in my career, which spanned the 1980s and 1990s,’ it would be hard to go past signing off on the Uruguay Round and introducing enterprise bargaining. Although it is not immediately obvious, both of those reforms did fundamentally help the poorest people in our community by creating jobs, both through enterprise bargaining and through trade liberalisation. Peter had that conviction about him and he knew that was what both of those major policy reforms could do, and they have done.

Peter Cook was a compassionate human being. He taught us all compassion. He had enormous integrity. He knew that there were many causes that he was championing that were unpopular. He was coming up against people whom he respected and liked who could not understand why Cookie was doing these things. But he did not flinch. He did not say, ‘I’d better rethink this; I am making myself unpopular.’ He was always pleasant but always determined to achieve the outcome.

In politics, honesty is a precious commodity, and Peter Cook had a very large amount of that. He was just such an honest man. If he disagreed with you, you knew absolutely. There is a lesson for all of us in that. Peter was a man of principle. I think he paid a high price for being so principled—but, in the end, he probably would not have minded. If when you are dying and you look back on your years and can say yes to the questions ‘Was I honest? Did I have compassion? Was I a person of principle? Did I have integrity?’ you have led a pretty good life. Peter Cook led a very good life.

When Peter was diagnosed with cancer and he was leaving this place, I went around to see him and I gave him a hug because I knew that things were very bad. Cookie always said, ‘I’ll keep fighting, I can beat this,’ but I knew the prognosis was bad. Even as things worsened and through all the operations that he had in Sydney, he just kept fighting—always thinking, ‘Maybe there’s some hope; even if things are gloomy I’ll do the very best I can.’ He never flinched under pressure on the policy front and he never flinched under pressure when he was dying. Peter Cook was a great man and a great friend and I miss him very much.

The strength and love that Barbara displayed for her husband right through their lives but most particularly in that last terrible 12 months is almost indescribable. Barbara, we are thinking of you today. You have done a fantastic job.

talk.start.para: —I would like to make a contribution to this condolence debate on Peter Cook, and I thank the member for Fraser for allowing me to slot in at this particular time. I probably come from a different perspective—a perspective of minister to minister. When I was Minister for Natural Resources in the Greiner government in New South Wales, which I took over in 1988, Peter Cook was the Minister for Resources in the Hawke government here in Canberra. Of course, one of the great debates at that time was the forestry debate in New South Wales. I suppose it continues, but it was a great debate at that time. In fact, it was the debate that brought me into politics in 1984, because I believed that the whole debate was distorted and dishonest and we had to get the truth across as to what was really going on in the management of forests in New South Wales. I suppose I would have to admit defeat on that issue.

speech.para: One of the issues I had to deal with at the time was the management of the south-east forests, which was to do particularly with the chip-milling at the Harris-Daishowa mill at Eden. In that instance, the Commonwealth had to give licences for the export of chips, so Peter Cook and I became entwined in that issue. To his great credit, Peter rang me up and said, ‘We have to deal with this issue. Would you mind if I came across and had a talk to you?’ I said, ‘Fine, come across.’ Peter flew to Sydney and we sat down with his staff and my staff and we decided that we should spend some time trying to come to an agreement on what areas would be needed for the timber industry—not only the chip industry but also the tablelands sawmills and the sawmill down at Nowra.

It was an extended process. Peter flew to Sydney almost weekly for nearly three months to go through the issues. Peter had to take into consideration the environmental position of the Hawke government and I had to take into consideration not only the environmental issues but also the issue of jobs. To his credit, Peter Cook acknowledged that and, not surprisingly, with his background of looking after the interests of workers, he was very much aware of the situation and uppermost in his mind were the jobs of the workers in the forest industries of New South Wales—the greatest decentralised industry we had in rural New South Wales.

It was a very serious issue that we courteously went through. We tried very hard to set aside areas that we believed were important to the environment. We also tried to set aside areas where we would have a long-term, sustainable forestry industry in New South Wales. My youth was spent in the forest industries on the North Coast of New South Wales, so I understand clearly the management that is necessary. I understand how you can maintain the resource on a very sustainable basis. From that perspective, I was able to make a contribution, with Peter Cook, on this issue.

We reached an agreement on how the area should be set aside for the environment and for the industry. The agreement was signed by Prime Minister Hawke and by Premier Greiner. To my great sadness, I have to say that, in the name of the Australian Conservation Foundation, the now member for Kingsford Smith managed to get Nick Greiner’s ear to get the agreement changed. It was not the Labor government in Canberra; it was our government in New South Wales that reneged on the agreement that Peter Cook and I had reached. I think there is a certificate to this day on the wall down at Harris Daishowa saying, ‘That’s how much you can depend on Australian governments,’ which is rather sad because the agreement was very good . It took all areas into consideration. It was a template that could have been used in forest industries across Australia. It is rather sad that it fell by the wayside.

When Peter Cook was diagnosed with melanoma, I was a bit of a kindred spirit because I had been diagnosed with secondary melanoma some time before and I knew what he would be going through. I do not think you can explain the feeling you have when your doctor says, ‘You have secondary melanoma.’ You just go cold because you know very well what you are dealing with. Specialists are not the people who will give you a lot of hope; they tell you exactly how it is. They say, ‘You’re dealing with a monster,’ and it is a monster that is very hard to contain.

I rang Peter Cook—having had all that time with him—and gave him my assurance that I would certainly pray for him and would like to speak to him and help him along the way. We did from time to time have a discussion about these matters. I dare say he realised what he was up against; he realised the odds. Even when I had a clearance, after an operation, to say that they could find no more cancer in my body I was rather relieved and said to my specialist, ‘That’s good news, doctor.’ He looked at me and said, ‘Yes, that gives you a 50 per cent chance.’ They are very serious odds to deal with. Peter Cook and I both knew that we were fighting a big battle and the consequences were unknown.

They say only the good die young. I have been very lucky because I am three years down the track and there is still no sign of any secondaries. Peter did not have that luck—unfortunately, secondaries showed up fairly quickly. In fact, my specialist said to me, ‘If I’m still talking to you in 12 months time, then we are part way down the track.’ That is how quickly it moves. As I was driving home from a function on Saturday—we are sending out Christmas cards at the present time—I said to my wife, ‘Remind me to send Peter Cook a Christmas card and I’ll drop him a note.’ It must have been about the time he lost the battle. I did not realise he was so low at the time.

I did not know his family but I know what they would be going through. It is a terrible tragedy to lose someone and it is a terrible tragedy to suffer with them. I have seen that type of suffering in my own family. It is very hard to deal with. I can only just imagine what his wife has gone through. She must have been stoic to go through it the way she did, from what I hear from others. My sympathies certainly go to the family. I will always remember Peter Cook. He was a very decent man to deal with and I believe that through a lot of hard work and perseverance we came to an agreement that was a very good agreement. It is just a pity that it did not stick.

talk.start.para: —Peter Cook was my friend for 35 years. But you did not need to be his friend to appreciate the significance of his contribution. For example, it is highly likely that the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations would not have finished as well as it did or as early as it did without Peter Cook’s robust, skilful and intelligent leadership of the Cairns Group. There are serious, senior figures in international trade discussions who have said there probably would not have been a satisfactory outcome of the Uruguay Round at all without Peter Cook’s role. I had the privilege of succeeding him as Minister for Trade and, while I do not think any individual can be responsible for anything as substantial as the conclusion of a major round of international trade negotiations, there was nobody I met who did not conclude that the result was earlier, better and better received as a result of some extraordinary initiatives that Peter took as chair of the Cairns Group.

speech.para: He left a few bruised egos behind because he set up a subgroup in the Cairns Group, he took them to Europe, he negotiated with the Europeans, he negotiated with the Americans and he hammered out a deal. When you set up a subgroup, by definition someone gets left behind. They all felt that this was a bit presumptuous and I had to smooth some ruffled feathers afterwards. It was a very small task compared to the task of getting that agreement. The world is a better place for that agreement and Peter’s contribution was extraordinary. This is an achievement which would satisfy a lifetime’s activity. If at the end of 30 years of activity you could say that is what you achieved then you could feel very proud. But it is a mere staging post in a long and brilliant career. I have chosen to highlight it at the beginning of these remarks not just because it is so significant but because the combination of commitment, will and intellect which it displayed was the outstanding feature of his public career.

I started off by saying he had been my friend for 35 years. I read in an obituary in the Australian today that Peter came to Perth in 1970, and I met him within a few days of his arrival. I thought: ‘No, that’s wrong. It can’t possibly have been 1970—that’s 35 years ago.’ But sadly I remembered that it was right. That means I am 35 years older than I was then. Sometimes it feels like twice as much and sometimes only half. But it must have been so because I remember in 1971 he and I were campaigning in the streets about the South African rugby tour. I am not sure that all the obituaries have referred to this and nor do I think, of those that have, that they have all been totally accurate about it. They say Peter was not an activist outside the official political realm. I remember seeing him put in the back of a paddy wagon as a result of activities during that protest against those South African rugby tours. He was most put out because I was there with the megaphone calling out and he was in the crowd, and they picked him up and not me. He was always put out about that. I cannot say that I ever minded.

He was very actively engaged in a wide range of activities. The ones that come to mind in hindsight—there were many others as well—were those South African rugby tour campaigns and the war in Vietnam. I heard in the Senate debate on the condolence motion Senator George Campbell talking very eloquently about Peter’s very powerful role against certain laws introduced by the Court government—the government of Sir Charles Court, not the subsequent government of Richard Court—which restricted freedom of association and led to various trade union officials being charged for holding public meetings. Incidentally, they led to me being charged on one occasion for holding a public meeting. Peter fought against those in a manner that was effective and successful.

Over those 35 years he went from—when I first met him—being a junior, organising with the Miscellaneous Workers Union, to working for the building workers union and becoming assistant secretary of the labour council and then secretary of the labour council. I was very pleased to play a role in creating the opportunity for Peter to become secretary of the labour council. His predecessor had done a fine job. It was time for him to move on and we found a decent way in which he could make a contribution elsewhere, which he did very substantially, and Peter took his place. Subsequently, I was pleased to have a role in getting a preselection for him in those tumultuous days of the double dissolution of 1983 which led him to come to the Senate.

In all those things and in the role he played in the trade union movement, as vice-president of the ACTU—he was originally involved in negotiating what became the accord from the trade union side, although he finished up implementing it from the government side, when the Labor Party was in government—he was a very distinguished figure and a very significant minister in a range of portfolios. I was very pleased to hear the remarks made by the member for Page. I thought he made a very cogent argument in a simpler way than those of us who were close to Peter in other ways could have about the quality and integrity of his negotiation and commitment. I was grateful for the remarks that he made.

Peter was Minister for Resources, Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, but he was always proudest and made his most significant contribution as Minister for Trade. It is hard to believe that, in a long career of more than 35 years, he was trade minister for only 10 months. But there was a fortuitous combination of capacity and opportunity—the skills that he had developed. Somebody described Peter in an article in a newspaper today as possibly the best negotiator they had ever met. I know at least one other person who would be a competitor for that title. But he was certainly an outstanding negotiator who had the capacity to bring people together, to come to agreement, to go to the essence of the argument that you need to find agreement and to enable people to move away from the side issues that they are finding difficult to overcome and focus on the central issue. He made an ongoing contribution to trade policy, and I want to come back to that when I comment on what he did after he left parliament.

When I became trade minister, I found there were a substantial number of people all around Asia whose attitude to Australia, to Australians and to Australian government policy was the better for the relationship they had developed with Peter. I want to briefly mention two, and they are both very significant figures in an ongoing way. One was a very controversial figure, and was very difficult for Australian ministers, including yours truly, to deal with—the incredible Malaysian trade minister, Rafidah. I know that you, Madam Deputy Speaker Bishop, know Rafidah Aziz, as I do. She has been a very powerful, forceful and controversial advocate for the policies of her government for a very long time but has not been easy on Australia. She gave us a hard time. Peter discovered that he and Rafidah had the same birthday. They used to joke about this and he broke the ice with it. That did not mean that either of them made agreements other than by forcefully arguing the interests of their country. But he broke through the difficulties we had in building a decent working relationship with a government that at that stage we had difficulties with—the government of Dr Mahathir. When they were at their low point, one of the intermediaries was always Peter because of his relationship with Rafidah.

The other relationship—and in some ways an easier one because it was with a person much more amenable to the sorts of issues we were pushing—and one of great long-term significance, was with Dr Supachai. Dr Supachai was at the time the Deputy Prime Minister of Thailand, responsible for trade policy. He went on—and he has just concluded a term, I think—to be the Director-General of the WTO, a very important figure in that organisation. As far as I understand, he is now the head of UNCTAD. He is a distinguished international citizen, a significant player in the trade policy debates in ASEAN when we were trying to negotiate the first steps of the relationship between Australia and New Zealand through CER and ASEAN. It was Dr Supachai who was a significant factor, and his friendship with Australia was substantially built on his relationship with Peter.

I would like to move on to Peter’s role after we left government. A number of people have commented on his chairmanship of various committees, and I will mention three of them only quickly because they had been mentioned at great length by others—the GST inquiry, the ‘children overboard’ inquiry, and of course the final report he brought down on the issue of cancer. All of those were very significant, but the report that is underestimated, I think, is the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee, which he chaired, on the idea of a Pacific community. The committee brought down a unanimous report—and that sort of thing happens often on that Senate committee but it was something that Peter was very good at achieving—and made some far-reaching recommendations about the nature of our relationship with other countries in the Pacific. I think that in 10 or 20 years time the report will be looked back on as more significant than all of the others which are of contemporary political significance. I would like to think that the cancer report will be similar, that it will make a change in public policy, but I am not so optimistic. But I think that the report from that committee which Peter chaired on the idea of a Pacific community—and many other people on the committee also made a good contribution to the report—will be looked back on as another significant achievement.

Very briefly, I want to say something about how and why Peter left the parliament. In hindsight he would have left pretty soon afterwards anyway because of his health. Peter should have been endorsed for the last election. I am not commenting on the person who took his place and who was the beneficiary of issues that surrounded Peter’s preselection and who now has the opportunity to prove himself as a worthwhile successor. I certainly do not know him well enough to comment on whether he will do that or not, and I make no comment on him. I do not hold him at all responsible. He was offered the opportunity to make a contribution in the Senate, and why would he not seize it. Peter had given me a lot of support over many years politically and I tried to return the favour. I found intransigence from a group of people—and there was a roomful of them—who, if they had all combined their will, their commitment and their intellect, would not have been the equal of Peter. They conspired to pull him down to avenge years of dissatisfaction with the positive role he played in stopping them doing the things they wanted to do. He was right to stop them; they were wrong to pull him down. I do not know what they are thinking today, but I know what I am thinking. His reputation will be unsullied by their activities, but I do not think that theirs will be.

After he left he was always amused by the idea of being an adjunct professor. He had been introduced at a function on one occasion as Professor Cook and he thought this was wonderful, having been Senator Cook for so long. He expected everyone to call him Peter or Cookie really, but to be Professor Cook was a source of great amusement and pleasure to him. Through the Curtin University and the WTO—other people have referred to his significant contributions and I will not repeat them—he produced a book to assist developing countries in taking advantage of opportunities that the WTO offered.

What has not been commented on is the significant role he played through the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association in going to parliaments in developing countries and advising parliamentarians on the role they could play in assisting in trade liberalisation in those countries. He was an advocate for trade liberalisation but also an adviser on how to go about it as a parliamentarian, to be effective, to have scrutiny and to do all those things that we would take for granted. It was just another part of his long-term commitment to trade liberalisation.

He played a significant role in our party in the formation of the Centre Left. He played a significant role in creating it—it is not fair to say that he created it, but for many years he carried it on his back. History will probably judge that the Centre Left was a flawed concept, but his will, his intellect and his ability made it succeed and made it contribute for 20 years. He played a positive role through that and for the party in government and in opposition.

I want to conclude by saying something about Barbara. A lot of people have spoken correctly about the very significant role Barbara played in her wonderful support for Peter during his illness. Robyn and I drove down to Sydney on a few occasions to offer Barbara and Peter and bit of support and comfort, and she was always wonderfully strong. She was unbelievable in how she was able to sustain her support and good humour. She should not be underestimated as a strong and independent woman who has made a very substantial career of her own and a very substantial public policy contribution across a range of areas in Western Australia. Barbara sustained that right up until Peter’s retirement. They were going to enjoy a wonderful retirement, but it has been cruelly cut short. She rang me on Saturday, as strong as ever, to ask me to ring mutual friends overseas who did not know how ill Peter was and how imminent his death was. It was only a couple of hours before he died. That she had the thought to ring me and to be concerned about those people was, I thought, a great tribute to her. I know that, after the mourning and the grief, she will return to make a contribution of her choosing, because she is a woman of talent and strength.

Peter Cook’s death on Saturday marks the premature end of an outstanding Australian life, but Peter goes in the knowledge that he lived his life in accordance with his values. He made a substantial contribution to Australia and achieved the only real accolade any of us can hope to achieve. He can leave us knowing that the world and the nation are the better for his contribution.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to associate myself with the condolence motion for former senator Peter Cook, or Cookie as he was known to all of us. I must say how pleased I am to follow on from the member for Fraser, because he and I, like Senator Cook, cut our teeth in the Western Australian branch of the ALP. The member for Fraser, first as a senator and then as a member of the House, and I subsequently joined Peter in the parliament.

speech.para: I want to start by recording my sympathy to Barbara and to Peter’s family. I have known Peter for a long time as a Western Australian colleague—although not for quite as long as the member for Fraser. My first contact with Peter was in the mid- to late-1970s. He was about to become secretary of the TLC and I was a delegate to the state executive of the Western Australian branch of the party from the Perth Electorate Council—the seat that I now have the great fortune to represent.

My real contact with Peter came when I became State Secretary of the Western Australian branch of the ALP in the late 1980s—by then he was a senator and was soon to become a minister—and subsequently I joined him as a colleague. I think the highlight of Peter’s public contribution—his contribution to public service, to public life—was as a minister in the Hawke and Keating governments as Minister for Resources, Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Trade. I will not go through all the details of those achievements. I have always thought his most significant contribution was in the trade portfolio where, on any measure, he can lay claim to have been one of the best trade ministers that our nation has had the benefit of having.

I also think his contribution in opposition to the parliament and to the Labor Party, following our fall from office in 1996, is underappreciated. When we fell into opposition in 1996, I think it is true to say that Peter was initially very disappointed at no longer being in government and at the role that he had in opposition. But after a very brief time he showed what I thought was very much the true application of his personal characteristics.

In Labor’s period in opposition, Peter was Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. He showed his true colours as a parliamentarian when, no longer on our executive or frontbench, he chaired a number of Senate inquiries, including the Senate Select Committee on A New Tax System, the Senate Select Committee on A Certain Maritime Incident—the ‘children overboard’ inquiry—and, most recently, the Senate Community Affairs References Committee inquiry into services and treatment options for persons with cancer. All of these inquiries showed Peter’s personal characteristics. It has struck me for a long time that in many respects the best of Peter’s characteristics was his great integrity. You always knew where he stood, and he certainly let you know what he thought of where you stood. If you entered into a conversation with Peter and subsequently came to an agreement about policy or politics, it was always honoured. There was no honouring in breach, it was always honoured.

I think it is true to say that, whilst Peter had an avid interest in politics, his real passion was the politics of public policy. He was in politics not for the game of politics but for what politics could achieve—public policy outcomes and public policy contributions. Whilst, I think, far and away his most significant public policy contribution was as Minister for Trade during the Uruguay Round, his contribution as Minister for Industrial Relations, forging enterprise bargaining, was also by any measure a most significant achievement.

There are two personal anecdotes I am always left with when I think of Peter. The first is one I always threatened to tell about him when he was out of public office. I never went into the full details with Peter, and I think that from time to time he was worried about what I might say. Underappreciated in Peter’s ministerial career was his time as Minister for Resources. In our first term in opposition in 1996, I was shadow minister for resources and energy. Peter searched me out for a lunch meeting he had organised with representatives of the Western Australian minerals and petroleum resources industry. He started the lunch by saying: ‘I may or may not be in the next Labor cabinet, but Stephen Smith will be. I want him to have a complete understanding of the mineral and petroleum resources industry and I want you to show him every convenience and every support.’ He did that for three reasons: (1) his ongoing commitment to trying to ensure that the Labor Party was in government, not opposition; (2) his selfless devotion, in his own right, to advancing good public policy; and (3) wanting to advance the interests, in the national good and in the public interest, of an important industry.

I think it is true to say that, just as Peter was underappreciated as Minister for Resources, the resources industry itself has for a very long time been underappreciated; it has only been in more recent times that it has come to the fore. It has always struck me that there was no reason for Peter to do that for me personally and no personal reason for him to do that for himself. He did it because he thought it would advance the interests of a great industry and advance the interests of the Australian Labor Party.

The second anecdote is the one that I will go to my own grave remembering Peter for. It is not known by many—but known by Peter and Barbara—that Peter and Barbara have been constituents of mine. At the local level in my electorate, one of the great achievements of the Hawke and Keating governments was a Building Better Cities project known as the East Perth project, which saw the establishment of Claisebrook Cove and the revitalisation of East Perth as a thriving, modern community.

It was a week or so before it became public knowledge that Peter was suffering from the cancer and, given his and Barbara’s demeanour, I am sure it was before Peter and Barbara were aware of the advice and the diagnosis. But, as is common with me on a Saturday or Sunday afternoon, I was on my own walk from my house, with Jane, along our oft-trod path to Trinity and the WACA via Claisebrook Cove. In Claisebrook Cove there are a number of restaurants and coffee shops, and one that Peter and Barbara often frequented was Lamont’s. And, as we were walking past, there were Peter and Barbara on a Saturday or Sunday afternoon. It was a beautiful Perth day. Peter was close to the water. The sun was shining. So we stopped our walk, went onto the balcony and just had a quick chat.

It was typical Peter. We had a chat about public life and politics. We were of course going through tough times and, once we analysed our tough times, he saw hope and optimism for the future. This was always Peter’s way. There were things that we could and should do to advance our cause. So we had a conversation about politics, a conversation about life, a conversation about family, and there was Peter in his element: with Barbara, chatting about politics, policy and life, and close to the water—on this occasion, the Swan, not the ocean, but nonetheless close to the water. As we walked away, I remarked to Jane just how happy he and Barbara were and how carefree and casual he seemed about life and our political predicament. And that is how I will always remember Peter and how I will always remember Peter with Barbara. I express my deepest sympathy and condolences to her and Peter’s family, and I mark my admiration for Peter Cook’s contribution to Australia’s national interest and to our public life.

talk.start.para: —I join many people here today in wanting to pay my respects to Senator Peter Cook. We have heard a lot from other people about Peter’s career—people who are far more qualified than I am to talk about that—and it has been interesting and instructive to listen to the last few speakers. I did not know Peter personally at all until I arrived here in this parliament about five years ago, but I have had a number of opportunities in the last few years to get to know him. Peter always struck me right from the beginning as a man who never gave up. He always seemed to know what he was fighting for, and he took every opportunity to advance the cause.

speech.para: I came to know Peter after what I guess many people would regard as the peak of his parliamentary career, but it seemed to me that he did not regard his work as anywhere near finished, and I admired him for that. His work, as far as I could work out, was the Labor Party and what it could do for Australia and for Australians. He was not interested in the machinations inside, only as much as it meant better things for our country. I admired Peter’s energy and his unflagging interest and personal commitment in continuing the fight for the things that he regarded as important. He always seemed to stay very focused on the real game and was often several jumps ahead of everybody else.

This unflagging interest and commitment to the real game was evident in how he dealt with his illness. I think the last of the many Senate inquiries that Peter chaired—many of them of great national importance—on cancer, was typical of Peter and his focus. I note his very practical response to the difficulty many people find when they are diagnosed, with a bewildering range of advice and options that people have to work their way through. I know from personal experience with members of my own family of that very bewilderment that people have to go through.

I want to put on record my thanks to Peter for his support for my own parliamentary career and for his role in its beginning. I regard my start here as a direct result of Peter’s and others’ interest in the health of the Labor Party. Peter cared very much about the Labor Party, as I said before, because he saw it as the best way of looking after the interests of Australia. I want to pass on to Barbara, Peter’s wife, my heartfelt sympathies and to wish her well as she comes to terms with Peter’s death and her loss.

talk.start.para: —As chair of the Western Australian federal parliamentary Labor Party, I appreciate the opportunity to speak on this condolence motion for Senator Peter Cook. But I also speak as a friend and as one who will mourn the loss of Peter—as a friend, as a colleague, as a senator whom I admired and as a senator who made a great contribution to his adopted state of Western Australia. He made a great contribution to his nation and to the party of which he was a dedicated and conscientious member and servant for so long. I do not want to speak of Peter’s enviable record since he came to this parliament back in 1983, as others have done that already. But in paying my respects to Peter I say that he will be sadly missed, as men of his ilk, dedication, professionalism, intellect, compassion and loyalty are always missed for they are men of rare character, particularly in politics.

speech.para: I want to pay tribute to Peter’s wife, Barbara, who stood resolutely beside Peter as his partner, his mentor, his critic and indeed his closest friend. Barbara and Peter had a wonderful relationship. As hard as these last few months were on Peter, they were also indescribably hard on Barbara. But she never flinched or weakened in her love for him or in her resolve to stand by Peter and to fight beside him, with him and for him to the end. I just want to say to Barbara that you have our admiration, appreciation and thanks for the loving and caring way in which you looked after and nurtured Peter, our friend and colleague, during these difficult times. On behalf of myself, my wife, Noelene, and the WA parliamentary Labor Party, I wish Peter fair winds, calm seas and above all a peaceful voyage.

talk.start.para: —It is really hard to encapsulate in a few words what you feel about someone who has had a real impact on your life here in federal parliament. I first met Peter when I started working for Senator Michael Tate back in 1988. I was just an electorate officer and occasionally I would wander up to Old Parliament House and be involved in what was then called the Centre Left faction. I remember going to a meeting in Melbourne and, as an electorate officer, listening to the wisdom of the so-called wise men who made up the Centre Left—and there were quite a few of them in those days. I remember then coming up and sitting in some of the committee rooms when we moved up to this place and once again seeing the men and women at the table discussing issues of national importance, taking in those gems of wisdom, thinking about them and perhaps changing my idea about what contribution I might make if I ever got up here. I well remember coming up here in 1993 as a raw backbencher and moving from the advisers’ seats up to the main desk and thinking to myself, ‘How can I contribute pearls of wisdom to these people?’ One of those people was Peter.

speech.para: I know when we write the next chapter of the history of our party Peter will feature greatly because he has made a magnificent contribution to the Australian Labor Party, not just in Western Australia but nationally. He was the sort of bloke who would listen to all the various points of view put around the table and then had that wonderful capacity to sum up, point out the deficiencies in the nicest way of some of the arguments that had been put forward and then come up with what in most cases we agreed was the position we should take.

‘Cookie’, as he was lovingly called, was a wonderful bloke. He was one of those mentors, one of those role models whom you meet only once or twice in your life. I consider him to be one of my mentors in the 13 years that I have been in this place. He would not dogmatically tell you what to do, how to do it and why you should do it; he was just there, as I said before, with pearls of wisdom, channelling, directing, and challenging you to think about issues.

Much has been mentioned about his wonderful wife, Barbara. There are many examples in history of two people working together in such a way that it has a dramatic impact not only on their family and their state but also on their nation and on so many other people. I have had the pleasure of enjoying their hospitality in Mandurah at that lovely house down on the beach. One of the regrets for me is that Peter never made it back to Mandurah. Rod Sawford, the member for Port Adelaide and I, with the permission of the whip, ventured up to the Mater Hospital recently to see Peter and spend a day with him in Sydney. Despite the fact that there were tubes coming out of a whole lot of orifices and there were bags hanging off him in two or three different positions, he was determined to get out of there, to feel the sun on his face and to feel the breeze. He was confident that he would get back to WA to see the sea that he loved. He was happy knowing that he had sailed his boat part of the way from Western Australia up to the Northern Territory.

It is really hard, as I said at the outset, to say what is in your heart about someone who you really loved, who had an enormous impact on your life. He will always be there even though he has gone. We will send him off next week—most of our party and the former Prime Ministers who had the pleasure of serving with him in the Hawke and Keating governments. People have spoken today about the fact that he is taking the next journey. I know where he has gone. He will be happy.

We are always going to be there for Barbara. It is going to be tough. I say to his family that you have known a wonderful person whom you can remember for the rest of your lives. He has made a wonderful contribution to Western Australia and Australia and on the world stage he is held in great admiration and respect. Barb and his family have my sincere condolences for the loss of a wonderful man. Sixty-two years is far too short a lifetime but he has contributed more in those 62 years than most of us could ever contribute in several lifetimes.

talk.start.para: —Peter Cook was a great friend, indeed a mate. I, along with many others in this place, am going to sorely miss him. My wife Carmen and I offer our condolences to Barbara and his family. On a number of occasions over recent years we thoroughly enjoyed the hospitality of the Cooks both in Perth and Mandurah, which the member for Franklin referred to. It is a delightful place where Peter was very much at home and full of vigour and life. Peter and Barbara were and are amazing people. Peter’s superb political and policy skills were very much complemented by this very great zest for life. He was a man who loved the outdoors and had a particular passion for the sea and sailing. It was my privilege over recent years to have shared in a number of aspects of both his professional life here as a politician and also some of his outdoor sea based pursuits.

speech.para: Others have referred to Peter’s achievements both as a minister and as a parliamentarian. In a number of crucial areas, particularly in committee work in this parliament, Peter made a very considerable mark. Others have referred to the role he played on the Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee on the GST and a new tax system inquiry, on the Senate Select Committee on A Certain Maritime Incident, the ‘children overboard’ inquiry, and so on. From my point of view, given my role as a shadow minister with a particular interest in Pacific affairs, Peter made a very substantial contribution. In 2003, Peter chaired the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee inquiry into Australia’s relations with Papua New Guinea and the island states of the South Pacific. The committee report A Pacific engaged: Australia’s relationship with Papua New Guinea and the island states of the south-west Pacific, very much underpinned Peter Cook’s leadership, direction and chairmanship of that committee and made some extraordinarily powerful recommendations about taking forward Australia’s relationships within the South Pacific region. A key aspect of the report was the proposal for a Pacific political and economic community. It is an absolutely seminal idea which, in my capacity as a shadow minister and always noting Peter’s role as the author, I have taken forward, producing an ALP discussion paper on Pacific islands policy. It picks up this concept, which originated very much with Peter Cook.

In the course of preparing that report, Peter travelled extensively through the Pacific. I know from my subsequent travel there that he has an unsurpassed reputation in that region among leaders—political, social and economic—for the creative ideas that he drove very much through that Senate report. I was always intrigued after the production of that report to have accompanied Peter to a number of seminars at places like the ANU where his ideas were developed and reinforced. He certainly had a very substantial impact on thinking within Australia, both in the policy and academic areas and among Pacific islands leaders.

Peter never shied away from the tough ideas or the crucial issues. For example, one of the very interesting ideas that Peter pushed through the report A Pacific engaged, on a bipartisan basis, was the notion of trialling temporary short-term access for limited numbers of Pacific islanders to work in Australia, typically in seasonal employment. Given Peter’s own background, this was a tough area for him to address, but he understood the crucial and unavoidable nature of the proposal, emanating from Pacific communities. He was prepared to give very strong credibility to that proposal in the context of his thinking about the development of a Pacific community, so crucial to Australia, given our geographic proximity to that region. Tough ideas like that need considerable selling in the Australian community. He was never one to shy away from taking tough decisions when they were needed. Peter was a role model for many people in this place, including me, and a role model for people elsewhere. His life was far too short but it was a wonderful life. He has left his mark on many of us forever.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the condolence motion. I was deeply saddened when I heard of the death of my friend and colleague Peter Cook on Saturday. I extend to his wife, Barbara, and his family my deepest sympathy on his passing. He will be sorely missed among friends and members of this great parliament. It is fitting that this parliament pay such a tribute to Peter Cook because he was a parliamentarian of great intellectual substance and public stature, and had consummate political skill—personal and professional attributes that have been acknowledged by both sides of the House in this condolence motion.

speech.para: Much has been said already about Peter Cook’s industrial and political career—a career that spanned decades and brought him to great service on behalf of all Australians in this parliament. In government he served in many ministerial capacities: as Minister for Resources, Minister for Industrial Relations, Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Minister for Trade, Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. He had an enormous range of portfolios and he equipped himself very well in everything that he tackled. He was a great contributor to the life of the Senate in various capacities, both in debate and on committees, and was widely regarded for his capacity for political detail and his strategic political thinking, be that in the Labor Party itself or for Australia generally.

He grew up in the industrial movement, a tough operator who, down through the years, made many friends as well as many enemies—as we all do in this place. But there was one thing both friend and foe shared in their view of Peter Cook: they respected his knowledge and his skill in not only handling people but managing the wider political task.

I entered the parliament in 1993 and I had three years in government when I was able to observe Peter Cook in his role as a government minister and as a senior member of the federal parliamentary Labor caucus. My first impressions of Peter were of a serious and very credible minister who was, as many have termed it, a workhorse for the government. I came to know him more intimately in opposition when the internal realignments of groups within the Labor caucus brought us into close orbit and personal contact.

Peter Cook possessed political skills that were honed in many years of active service in the industrial wing of the Labor movement and later in the political wing. He possessed an encyclopaedic knowledge of the history and personalities of the Labor movement. He was a gifted strategic thinker, borne of hard years of policy development and the execution of it in government. He was a very practical man, always dealing with the art of the possible. He was a brilliant negotiator—another skill honed on the way through his political life, and which was eventually brought to bear with consummate effect for the benefit of all Australians in the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations. He was a true Australian patriot, never surrendering the independence of this nation as a minister or as a senator in those negotiations that he conducted on Australia’s behalf. He was politically tough but very patient with rookies like me when we entered this parliament.

When we look at his party and union involvements, once again we can understand the stature that Peter had within the Labor movement. He rose to become Secretary of the Western Australian Trades and Labour Council and Vice-President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The party positions? Well, he occupied almost all of them: Convenor, State Industrial Relations Committee; Delegate, ALP Federal Conference; Member, ALP National Executive; and Member, ALP National Executive Committee. He was also a member of the Western Australian state executive.

It was an extraordinary breadth of experience and he really brought to bear a unique insight into the political process because he was master of the machinations that took place in the union movement. There were very few politicians within the Labor Party who understood the various machinations of the senior executive levels of the party. It was in that role that he became a force for moderation, balance and strategic thinking when others were going about pursuing their own political ambitions at the expense of the party.

Here in the parliament, he was a great strategic planner and thinker for Labor both in government and in opposition. I believe it was that unique combination that made Peter Cook one of the most outstanding parliamentary contributors and performers over the past two decades in this place. It was only in the later years that I came to know him in a personal sense.

For those who understand the machinations of the Labor Party, we have two rather large groupings. In the middle of those two large groupings are some independents and other people from various groups that have existed historically in the party. Those groups came together to form an independent group, a balancing group, within the Labor Party’s caucus. It was in this role that Peter played an extraordinary part in counselling and guiding members such as me in the art of staying alive in the ALP. He also brought these great skills to bear for the benefit of the caucus in moderating the excesses that sometimes occur with the concentrations of power and the massive egos that often dominate the political stage. He recognised the importance of a centre balancing group within the caucus and the party structure. He gave great guidance and wise counsel. He was a mentor to us all.

I never got to sail on his ocean yacht. I happen to have an interest in yachting. When Peter found that out, he issued an invitation to visit him in Perth once he had left the parliament, to spend a weekend there and to take me sailing. I looked forward to that because it was an opportunity to get to know a man whom I had not got to know completely in the years that I had spent with him here in the parliament. My eternal regret is that I never got to Western Australia to join him on the yacht, to drink a few reds out on the ocean and to chew the fat on what was going on in the Labor Party and the nation.

He was a person whom I think everybody around this House respected for his wise counsel. It will be in that capacity politically that he will be sorely missed. He knew the realities of political life. When the challenge came to his preselection he fought hard, but he knew the realities of the Labor Party and it was to our crowning disappointment in the Centre group that Peter was defeated. We knew in that defeat that the caucus had lost a very valuable contributor to political debate and to the management of egos and other matters in the caucus.

It was the same tenacity that he brought to his struggle against cancer. Indeed, I think his struggle for preselection became a metaphor for his later struggle against cancer. I had the good fortune to speak with Peter about his illness and, like many others, I preferred to him a person who I believe might have been able to help him on that journey. It was a very difficult journey, but I know from people who were closely associated with his struggle that he brought all the magnificent qualities to bear on it and gave great dignity and indeed great hope to those around him.

As Peter Cook could only do, his latter days were spent in the service of other Australians—that is, politically bringing a focus to the issue of cancer and the impact it has on families and bringing a focus to possible treatments that people might be able to avail themselves of in facing this terrible disease.

Most of all, he joined this struggle with Barbara. What a wonderful person we have all come to know in the Labor movement. This was a couple who were loved dearly by their fellow parliamentarians and associates. That love now extends to Barbara in Peter’s spirit to support her through a most difficult time.

In concluding my comments, the Labor Party has lost a great friend and a great warrior for the cause. To Barbara let me simply say this: as sure as night turns into day, as the sun has set on Peter’s life the sadness of this moment will gradually be replaced by warm memories of a great political life and a great life together.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on this condolence motion in respect of the Hon. Peter Cook. I first met Peter Cook when I came to this parliament as a backbencher in 1998. I first worked with him on the GST inquiry, which was referred to in the condolence speeches by the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Hotham today. It was an opportunity to get to know Peter and to see his formidable political skills in operation.

speech.para: I also had the opportunity to work with him in that period, as I was deputy chair of our caucus committee on national security and trade and he, as shadow minister at that time, held the trade portfolio. As people may recall, one of the biggest political debates we had at that national conference in that period of opposition was the debate about free trade versus fair trade, as it was stylised. I got to see once again Peter’s great political skills at work in resolving that issue for the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party.

But it was in the last parliament—not my first parliament but my second parliament—that Peter and I became friends. I believe that we became friends because of a common understanding about the kind of values that one should bring to one’s life in politics. Peter understood the value of loyalty, the need for originality and the need to have the courage of your convictions. It is because of our shared belief in those things—the value of loyalty, the need for originality and the need to have the courage of your convictions—that we came to be personal friends in the last parliament.

I also had the opportunity to meet his family. I met not only his wife Barbara, about which much has rightfully been said—she is a truly amazing woman and every attribute of her strength and her character has been displayed in the way in which she has cared for Peter in this most tragic period—but also other members of his family, and it was my very great honour to launch the painting and drawing exhibition of Peter’s brother. Bill Cook is an artist and he had created an exhibition called The Presence of Absence—a Greek Odyssey. It was a painting and drawing exhibition in honour of his wife and his wife’s family, who were Greek migrants to this nation. So in the last parliament I had the opportunity not only to get to know Peter but to share events like that with Peter, his brother Bill and his extended family who were all gathered together. That will always be a very special memory for me.

In the period since Peter was diagnosed with the illness which tragically has taken his life, I have had the opportunity to meet and deal with him on a number of occasions. I have had the opportunity to dine with him in Canberra and to visit him in hospital. I have had the opportunity to share some social time with Barb, who was in Sydney caring for him for such an extended period. But, beyond this, I had the opportunity to work with him on the cancer policy, about which so much has been said in this condolence debate. I think it says something very special about Peter Cook that, having been given the worst possible news about the state of his health, he did not withdraw and turn inwards but dedicated much of his remaining strength to publicly raising the issue of cancer care on behalf of all cancer patients. He did this within this parliament before his term as senator expired, but he also did it beyond this parliament.

Once again, a very special memory for me is the launch of Labor’s cancer prevention policy, which I devised with Peter Cook in Perth in my capacity as shadow minister for health during the last election campaign. At that stage Peter was very unwell, but he was prepared to take part in a public discussion of his health, partly because he wanted to do what he could within the confines of his strength at that time to support Labor’s election to government. Obviously, the cause of Labor was something in which he passionately believed.

He also wanted to use some of his strength to raise clearly with Australians the cancer prevention message. Peter’s illness started off as a melanoma. He was exposed to the harsh WA sun for long periods as a young man, particularly because of his love of water sports and yachting at a time when it was not clear to us and certainly not understood in a public health way that the sun was so dangerous. We have seen a revolution in community understanding and community attitudes to sun exposure in the last 10 or 15 years. But when Peter Cook was a young man, out there on the yacht and undertaking a variety of sports in the harsh and unforgiving sun of South Australia and Western Australia, where he grew up and where he spent most of his life, that was not someone not heeding health messages; at that stage the health messages were not known. He has paid such a terrible price for that. He wanted, in the course of advocating a cancer prevention message in the last campaign, to make sure it was clearly understood by young Australians, who can often feel bulletproof—particularly young men, who never think anything is ever going to happen to them—that there is a terrible price to be paid for not understanding how dangerous sun exposure can be.

He not only undertook that activity but, as has been said by others, he spent much of his remaining time post diagnosis, when he was still in this parliament, raising the issue of cancer care through a bipartisan inquiry conducted by the Senate Community Affairs References Committee. When the report of the Senate inquiry was released, Peter said this, and I think it stands as a testament to what he was trying to achieve through that inquiry:

quote.para: … in my experience people diagnosed with cancer often have to make life affecting decisions at short notice, in a traumatised state of mind with very little information about the range of options available to them.

Specialist health care in Australia is among the best in the world but there is a bewildering number of adjuvant therapies and less conventional approaches which offer varying degrees of help, some over stated some not, which can be significant, if not decisive in aiding the healing process.
Patients often need assistance in assessing how these stack up and which of them might provide help.

The health debate is understandably dominated by Doctors, health care professionals, health bureaucrats and academics all with the apparent needs of the patients at heart but with transparent self interests of their own.
If this Inquiry can stand in the shoes of patients, and unambiguously take their point of view it will be a breath of fresh air.

speech.para: The report, entitled The cancer journey: informing choice, was filed on 23 June 2005, just before Peter left the Senate. It received 105 submissions and conducted seven hearings.
