The report makes a number of very sensible recommendations and it is my hope that we can work together in a bipartisan fashion to make sure that these are implemented as Peter’s lasting legacy. I raised this matter with the Minister for Health and Ageing personally on Friday and through text messaging during the weekend. I believe that the minister is seriously looking at this matter and is considering adopting some or all of the recommendations of the report in memory of Peter.

I would particularly stress the need to adopt a Medicare item to ensure multidisciplinary case conferencing, because it was Peter’s experience that when a patient is trying to coordinate the vast array of advice into a treatment plan it is the patient who ends up navigating between the doctors. It is really the doctors who should get together and navigate a pathway for the patient, and if doctors could be paid to do that it could revolutionise the way in which cancer care is provided so that people find out all of their options far more easily, without having to struggle through it the way Peter struggled through it. As Peter would so often say, he is a man who brought to that task every advantage. He was an intelligent man, an experienced man, a man who had been in public policy all his life and a man who had contacts all around the country. And if he found it difficult to navigate that pathway, then clearly this is almost impossible for someone who comes without those advantages. We will miss Peter Cook. We will miss him dreadfully. If we can, in his memory, initiate that kind of change for cancer care, then that will be a lasting testament to his life’s journey.

talk.start.para: —It is interesting that the member for Lalor spoke about the values of Peter Cook. That is where I am going to start: where those values actually came from. We were both children of waterside workers in Port Adelaide and we were such stunning individuals as young 10- and 11-year-olds we did not recognise each other at the wharfies’ picnics that were held at Largs Bay beach each year. We both embellished the stories about who won the sprint races. I won them; he swore he won them. But I do remember one year when a girl beat both of us. She was not allowed to be in the race, so she raced outside the lanes and beat both of us.

speech.para: The context of the 1950s established Peter’s values, and for us in Port Adelaide they were times of strikes and poverty. People have talked about Peter’s stoicism. Let me tell a story about what happened at that time. Some of the strikes lasted for three and four months. There was no income. I remember my father sitting in a rocking chair, reading a book and smoking a roll-your-own cigarette. I said to him, ‘There’s no food in the house,’ and he looked down over his glasses at me and said, ‘It won’t kill you,’ and continued reading. A couple of days later we walked the five miles to Port Adelaide from where we lived in Largs North to collect our rations—sugar, flour, bread, a pound of meat and some butter, soup vegetables and maybe a few apples. That lasted our family of three for a week. Peter’s family would have been the same. Poverty was part of the life that we lived. But stoicism was part of that Midlands and Scottish heritage that we shared, and I will come back to that stoicism a little later.

This was also a period of great change. Peter was a great advocate of trying to deal with change. As kids we would not have understood it at the time, but Port Adelaide was going through a tremendous change. There were 3,000 wharf labourers and 1,000 casual labourers. I can remember my father saying to me that within a short period of time—he did not call it containerisation; he did not use the term—there will only be 300 wharfies in Port Adelaide. In fact it turned out to be 100. It was a time of dramatic change. I remember the debates within our families—they were always about politics. There were strong arguments, and in our family we talked about religion. We had very strong religious views—Protestant, Catholic and nonaligned. I remember on one occasion when I was about 12 years old saying to my grandfather, sick of the arguments about politics and religion, ‘How come we never have any sensible conversations about sex?’ I remember the backhander coming very quickly and I never mentioned that again.

Peter’s family was similar. Politics was always spoken about, argued about and valued. The commitment that Peter always had to change, and that change can benefit people, came from when we were young men. We played football together—not on the same side. Although he was the son of a Port Adelaide wharfie, he actually played senior Colts for North Adelaide—we always used to regard them as a B-grade Labor club but, nevertheless, a Labor club.

I suppose the next time I met Peter was in the context of factional politics within the Australian Labor Party and the formation of the Centre Left. I was not a founding member of the Centre Left; I was Mick Young’s campaign director at the time. I thought the Centre Left was just as silly as the other two factions, to be quite honest, and I was not a member. But eventually I did join that group and watched Peter’s contribution. He was a heavy hitter, and he was an original thinker.

From 1996 I actually shared accommodation with Peter at Kingston. In the first couple of years, we shared with David Beddall, the former member for Rankin, and then with Harry Quick, the member for Franklin. Later, Peter and I shifted out of Kingston and moved to Palmerston, that terrible place out there on the highway—it would take us about an hour to get in in the morning. We argued about the formation of the independents and, with Michael Duffy of the non-aligned group, we actually formed the independents in 1996-97. Gavan O’Connor, the member for Corio, and I were the first co-chairs of that.

When we lived together, there were not many people in the Senate other than from your own state that you developed a close relationship with. We seemed to operate at different hours. We both had a couple of agenda items: I was trying to give up smoking in 1996; he was trying to give up eating. We all talked about the ‘push away’ technique, which of course is the only technique to stop smoking or eating too much. You can see I gave up smoking for eight years, but I have not managed the ‘give up eating’ part. We used to have nightly briefings at the end, at 11 or 12 o’clock at night, and we ate toast and tea and fruit loaf and tea—far too much. We talked personally, politically, professionally and procedurally. We would talk about our beginnings. We talked about the waterfront in Port Adelaide and how things had changed. We talked about change, strikes, football, sailing, horseracing, religion, poverty, race and gender.

We talked about our heritage in terms of a special humour that we enjoyed coming from port cities, a Midlands humour in which you juxtapose one given against another and you just drive in a punchline. They tell stories of your childhood, your first job, falling in love, getting married, difficulties in marriage and death. Maybe I should give a couple of examples of these sorts of silly folksy stories, because they epitomise that stoic sort of view that we both enjoyed and both had imbued in us. There is a little kid crying on the corner of Dale Street in Port Adelaide in the middle of the Depression. The vicar comes past and he says, ‘Why are you crying?’ The kid says, ‘My parents are fighting.’ The vicar says, ‘Who’s your father?’ He says, ‘That’s what they’re fightin’ about.’

There are stories about death as well: there is a death in the family and no-one has dealt with a funeral before. Mum calls in all the family and she says to everybody, ‘Well, Mum’s left no instructions as to whether Grandma is to be embalmed, cremated, buried or whatever.’ And the husband pipes up, ‘Take no chances: do all three.’ That was the humour. Some people do not understand it; others do.

He had a great thrill also in learning and knowledge. It is interesting that the debates on education in this country often focus on a knowledge economy and knowledge in education, which, for someone from my background, is a load of nonsense in many ways. Knowledge is a lowly intellectual skill. Peter came to a much more pragmatic view about what education could do and how it could change. He understood it was a lowly intellectual skill. His skills were in being able to expose a point, to translate, to interpret, to predict, to summarise, to identify the attributes in an issue and to categorise. He had insight, intuition and analysis skills. He was very methodical; he was innovative; he was original. He could find a way through a problem. That is why he was so successful in negotiation and so hard-nosed, so determined and so strong an advocate of the issues that he stood for. But, as Julia Gillard mentioned, those skills were softened also, because he had a particular courage, loyalty, integrity and honesty, and he respected other people who had those skills and reciprocated them.

He was not averse to publicity though—he loved a bit of publicity. I remember the competitive efforts put in by his staff, in particular a tall, gangly New Zealander called Don McKay who was a press secretary to Peter. The competition was with Gareth Evans’s office as to who would get the serious stories in the serious press—not the tabloid nonsense, the real stories. It was funny to watch and funny to listen to him retelling those stories, particularly late at night, when he could be self-deprecating in a way that other people perhaps did not see. But I also enjoyed bringing him back to earth in those nightly meetings. He would always start off resolutely defending the position that he took. It did not last too long before he burst out laughing and came back to earth.

Since Peter and I lived together for a number of years from 1996, our wives got to know each other very well. We shared a lot of family stories. Barbara—what an amazing woman. She connected with Peter intellectually, emotionally, physically and spiritually. That latter element in particular will never die. That goes on eternally, ethereally. It is in the ether; it remains; it continues on with all the people that he has affected and mentored and appointed and befriended. When things were not going too well—and there were times before his illness when things were not going too well for our group and we were getting dudded all the time—we used to console each and say, ‘We weren’t too bad for sons of Port Adelaide wharfies, after all. When it is all said and done, it isn’t too bad.’ Well, Peter, it was not too bad at all.

As I said, Peter Cook was a heavy hitter, but that does not mean he could not be wounded. All of us can be wounded in this game, and wounded he was—by treachery and betrayal that so dominated his last attempt at securing a further term in the Senate. It should not have been that way, but it was. We do terrible things to each other in this game of politics, and terrible things were done to Peter’s reputation at that time. We shall never know its true impact on his health. It may have been considerable; it may not have been. But if it was considerable, we should take his passing and that of other people in this place as some cause for reflection and regret. Peter had dreams like all of us—the Mandurah house on the ocean where we shared accommodation, meals, a few drinks and a few laughs with other colleagues, such as Harry Quick, Bob Sercombe, the late Jane Gerick and many others. And there was the yacht. They no longer will carry any earthly domain, but they will carry Peter’s spirit forever.

I suppose that, when is all said and done, the pawn and the king finish up in the same box. But Peter Cook, I think, was a giant of the labour movement. Even that is reduced to other things. When all is said and done, in this place, on this earth, it is the friendships and the quality of the relationships that you develop throughout your life that continue to mark your life far more than anything else. The friendships that Barbara and Peter developed, maintained and cherished throughout their life will remain. Hopefully, they will sustain Barbara in this difficult time of grief.
Peter Cook’s was a life cut short but a life well lived and a life to celebrate in the quiet pride that his heritage will determine. Vale Peter Cook. Bye. See you some time later.

talk.start.para: —I join in the debate on the condolence motion commenced earlier today with the contribution made by the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives. I mourn the passing of Peter Cook, as do many people across this nation. He was a good man, a man of deep conviction and principle, a man of integrity, a man of formidable intellect and a charismatic personality.

speech.para: Cookie was a friend of many years, dating back to our days together in the union movement and more recently when our paths crossed as colleagues in parliament. He was always a person of good sense—a person of good sense but also one with a great sense of humour. He was generous in spirit and optimistic by nature. This morning he was described by our leader, Kim Beazley, as a man of ‘ordered passion’. I have certainly seen the passion in Peter, but it is true to say that he never just wore his heart on his sleeve: as committed as he was to a range of social justice causes, he was a great strategic thinker, a good negotiator and a man, as I say, who always had integrity in his dealings with people.

It was his optimism that gave him the strength and the courage to face the battle against the cancer which took his life all too soon, at the age of 62. Glancing at many of the obituaries written this morning, I was struck by a particular headline which read ‘Political life a labour of love’. It is true. Peter Cook loved the labour movement and served it with great distinction in both its industrial and political wings. He never lost sight of his roots and was always a staunch defender of working people and their families.

It is not surprising that his working class background helped to shape the nature of the man and his convictions. His grandfather was a Broken Hill miner blacklisted for his union activities who died from consumption at the age of 26. His father—as Rod Sawford, the member for Port Adelaide, has commented—was a waterside worker. The Sawford family and the Cook family shared many attributes.

Peter left school at a very young age—15. But that was never a barrier to the immense contribution he made throughout his working life. His union involvement began in the clerks union in South Australia, working then as a clerk in an abattoir. He moved to Western Australia with his young family in 1970. By force of personality and hard work, by 1975 he had risen through the ranks to become Secretary of the Western Australia Trades and Labour Council.

It was during this period that I came to know him well as a friend and colleague. I well remember the election in 1981 in Sydney at the town hall when he was elected as Vice-President of the ACTU. I hope in some small way I assisted in that outcome, which saw his rightful elevation to a position of prominence in the national union movement.

Peter and I had cause to reflect on that experience in 1981 when, as a relatively young woman in the union movement, I ended up on a ticket with Peter Cook and John Halfpenny and I was in the third spot. I spent a whole day going around telling my colleagues from the teachers union that it was very important that they did not put me as No. 1 on that ticket and that, in order for Peter to be elected, it was vital that I had no first preferences in the ballot. The teachers were somewhat perplexed about this, never having been part of a broader union movement or understanding the importance of tickets, but, as it was, they did the right thing: they voted for Peter and Peter was elected to the position of Vice-President of the ACTU.

In total, he served the trade union movement with distinction for some 17 years before he decided to move to the federal political arena. In 1983 he was elected to the Senate and gave 22 years of dedicated public service in that chamber until his retirement in 2005. Peter was always an effective team player. He was never one to just sing about his own contribution. As others have commented, he served the Hawke and Keating governments in a range of portfolios, including industrial relations and trade and as Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. He was a cabinet minister for six of those years and also served with distinction as Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. In his departing speech in the Senate, Peter Cook had this to say about his career:

quote.para: If I have a high point of my career, I am proud of … the industrial relations reforms, but I think the proudest is sitting behind the Australian flag … in the closing stages of the Uruguay Round and, on behalf of Australia and the Cairns Group, negotiating a successful outcome.

speech.para: I remember very well Peter’s position as minister in the IR portfolio. By that time I had also advanced in my career in the union movement and I had cause to deal with Peter on a range of industrial relations issues. He held the portfolio of industrial relations longer than any other portfolio and was rightly proud of his achievements. I again quote from his Senate speech. He said:

quote.para: Industrial relations was a portfolio that I held longer than any other. In that, we wrote a new industrial relations act—the first new industrial relations act since 1904. We took the first steps towards a decentralised wage-fixing system. We introduced the best practice program in which we went to workplaces and encouraged cooperation rather than conflict. Under the guidance of John Prescott, then the general manager of BHP, we created reform in the workplace by having an emphasis on skill and training and by managers flattening the hierarchy down to one or two and relying on the workers’ knowledge of how best to run their plant. That program succeeded in increasing productivity quite dramatically. The brains of the work force was harnessed rather than alienated in the exercise of the push by particular companies to achieve success. I think that was a great scheme.

speech.para: I concur with those comments. I think one of Peter’s lasting legacies will be his key role in moving to a more deregulated industrial relations system, one which nevertheless protected all working people, as was his commitment, by enshrining the award system as the industrial safety net. He always cared about those with the least bargaining capacity.

This morning I read Cookie’s first speech in the Senate, a speech he made on 4 May 1983. That speech covered some of Peter’s long-held commitments and principles. In that speech, as a newly elected member of the Senate, he reflected on the national economic summit that tried to bring people together rather than on the conflict and the division that we had seen in the lead-up to the summit. He talked about the positive aspects of the prices and incomes policy approach that, as we know, underpinned the historic accord agreement between Labor and the union movement. He talked about the issue of taxes and, with a classic quote that is so much Peter, he said:

quote.para: The essential problem is not to make the rich pay higher rates of tax than the poor. It is to make the rich pay any income tax at all.

speech.para: Those comments were prophetic and still as true today as they were when he said them in 1983.

He talked in his first speech about the importance of the union movement and its importance particularly to maintaining the living standards of all Australians. He talked with some conviction about the issue of job security, an issue that is still very much with us today. He ended his speech with his pledge to work hard to ensure world peace and nuclear disarmament—issues that he carried with him throughout his life.

The last thing that I did pick up in his speech—and I had not been aware of the comments he made then, but it says something about the man back in 1983 when the promotion of women in public life was not so much a mainstream issue as it is today—was his comments on the then recent state election that had been held in Western Australia and the federal election. He was really proud of the fact that a number of women had won seats with huge swings—seats that had never been held by Labor before. He commented also on the achievements of his colleague Wendy Fatin, in the federal seat of Canning, who came to the House with a 13 per cent swing. I would just like to read some extracts from that speech. About the increased representation of women, Peter said:

quote.para: Some observations can be made about those figures. Firstly, the figures indicate that the affirmative action program of the Australian Labor Party in selecting women candidates is successful. Secondly, the result removes completely and, I believe, for all time any suggestion that women candidates cannot succeed in being elected to office. Thirdly, it may even open the question that women candidates are a positive advantage to the political party they represent.

speech.para: As I say, those comments were made at a time when the issue of women’s representation in political life was not part of the mainstream agenda and were certainly made before Labor instituted constitutional changes to ensure that this parliament better reflected the community that we are here to represent.
When Peter was diagnosed with cancer he explained then that his dominant emotion was one of shock and numbing disbelief. He said:

quote.para: Most of my time in politics, I’d been in economic portfolios. I’d spent virtually zero time worrying about health issues. I found myself naked and alone at the bottom of a very steep learning curve, wondering: how do I deal with a problem that I know very little about?

speech.para: As we all know, Peter, in his formidable manner, tenaciously turned adversity to advantage. They were the words used by the member for Hotham in his contribution this morning in the House, and I thought those comments ‘adversity to advantage’ were so true. In his last months as a senator, as we know, he was instrumental in setting up an inquiry which looked at the myriad treatment options for cancer patients and encouraged politicians to work to help people find more effective ways of fighting the disease—a disease that ultimately claimed his life. As Peter presented the report of the inquiry on his final day in the Senate, he said:

quote.para: When I was diagnosed I knew nothing about the disease. Initially it was a frightening and frustrating experience. With little or no knowledge I had to make life-critical decisions in an urgent time frame. Faced with that immense task it is very easy to despair and give up.

speech.para: And so it would be, but not for Peter Cook. He said:

quote.para: I have learnt that there is no such thing as a silver bullet here—no single, one solution—and that the answer, if there is one, lies in integrating a number of treatments.

speech.para: He commented in that speech that he had sat on numerous inquiries—very important inquiries dealing with the GST and the issue of the ‘children overboard’—but that this inquiry may ‘well be the most important inquiry I have sat on.’ I trust the government will respond promptly and comprehensively to the recommendations of the report and, in doing so, provide a lasting legacy to the years of devoted public service given to the people of this nation by Senator Peter Cook.

In concluding, I join with all earlier speakers in paying tribute to Peter’s wife, Barbara. She was his tower of strength, and I know from my personal conversations with Peter how indebted he was to her, not just in their dreadful struggle with his cancer and through those dark, black days but in their loving and productive personal and political relationship that helped ensure that Senator Peter Cook was able to make a very significant contribution to public life in this country.

talk.start.para: —I feel somewhat humbled following the excellent contribution of the honourable member for Throsby. I wish I could stand before you and say that I knew Peter Cook very well. Although I had served in the caucus for many years with him, I cannot make that claim, but there are a number of claims I can make. The late Senator Peter Cook was very much a product of the labour movement and the trade union arena, where he served in the highest positions—as the Secretary of the Western Australia Trades and Labour Council and as Vice-President of the ACTU. Never once did Peter deny his involvement with the trade union movement. On the contrary, he was always proud of it. He started off life as a fitter and turner—in crude working class language, we would say a ‘titter and feeler’—but he added to that by undertaking a university course.

speech.para: He served in the parliament for so long. It was only on 1 July this year that he retired. He had such a short retirement. The member for Throsby mentioned his period as the Minister for Industrial Relations. It was a period of great change. It was not one where we tried to divide the bosses from the workers; in fact, it was quite the reverse. We got rid of so many demarcation disputes. The one statistic that I would like to quote is that in the automotive industry there were 304 separate awards that impacted on it. In Peter’s time, we reduced them to nine. In fact, I am fond of quoting the words of a union delegate in Tasmania. When trying to describe the breadth of the changes that Peter had initiated in industrial relations he said, ‘Prior to these changes when I clocked on at work, I was expected to leave my brains behind; but with these changes, when I clocked on at work, I was expected to bring my brains with me.’

Peter worked so hard at collapsing that traditional divide between management and the work force and at involving the work force. I have always thought that involving the work force in key decisions was the most sensible management practice. If I think of Peter, the changes he wrought in the industrial relations system will always stay with me. It is such a contrast with what is being done today where there is almost zealotry to separate workers from management, to re-introduce the gulf, to not make workers part of the productive process. Peter was an outstanding Minister for Trade. People have talked about all he did with the Uruguay Round and establishing the Cairns Group and what a force for change that was. Indeed, it was significant. In a number of areas, the Hawke-Keating years gave to Australia a sense that we are a country capable of punching above our weight and, in trade, Peter was no exception.

Of all Peter’s contributions, the thing that should stay with us is that he was prepared to so publicly share what was a tragedy. Notwithstanding all his contributions—as a relatively young man he had given long service to the trade union movement and then to the parliament as a very senior minister and Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate—we should remember that he so generously shared with us the calamity of his own disease and diagnosis. What courage he showed. Would I have the same courage? I am not sure. I do not want to reflect on you, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott, but would you have the courage? I am not sure. But the thing I can say about Peter Cook is that he did have the courage. Like the member for Hotham and the Leader of the Opposition, I commend Peter’s wife, Barbara, for the services she performed. The term ‘in sickness and in health’ now has a new meaning for what Barbara did over the weeks and months of Peter’s illness. It is, I think, a renewal of the inspiration of the relationship between a man and a woman. I express my condolences to Barbara and to Peter’s four children. I think Australia is the better for the life of Senator Peter Cook. I mourn his passing.

talk.start.para: —As I recall it, I first met Peter Cook in the early eighties when I became active in the organisation of the Australian Labor Party. He was someone on the move and subsequently became a senator for my state of Western Australia. He was very impressive and persuasive even then. I joined the group to which he belonged in the Western Australian Labor Party. If people look at Peter’s career, they will see a ministerial and parliamentary career of great substance—indeed, a career which many of us envy and seek to emulate. With his selfless service, Peter has provided a great role model for future parliamentarians. He diligently discharged his duties as a minister and a senator. He was always a flexible thinker as well—curious and well informed. Peter always had a book in his bag and was willing to ask people their opinion. He read extremely widely. Perhaps because his own education was initially curtailed, he informed himself and continued his education every day of his life. Peter Cook was intelligent and articulate—sometimes to a fault—and always a great advocate for the causes he embraced. He had a great respect for evidence; he would always test ideas against the facts. He was not doctrinaire, although he held his values strongly. He was always able to argue from first principles and make a very persuasive case.

speech.para: One of the things that always struck me about Peter was his unflagging energy. You have to have that to be a senator from Western Australia. The travel alone would defeat most people, but I do not think I ever heard Peter complain about that. In fact, I think he was most distressed not to continue as a senator. But, as he had always done, he made the necessary adjustments and got on with the rest of his life. Sadly, the rest of his life was not to be much longer.

A lot of people have already spoken eloquently and in detail about the areas of public service for which Peter was best known—his contribution to the economic life of this nation and, in particular, industrial relations, resources and trade. He was responsible for very significant reforms, working with other ministers in the Hawke and Keating governments to transform the nation’s economy and industrial relations. But these are matters that have been well canvassed by others. I simply want to say that the contribution he has made is peerless, and I hope his family will be comforted by the fact that so many people recognise that contribution. But something that has perhaps not been made much of is the fact that Peter was always very alert to the social consequences of these reforms. He was not hard-nosed or careless about it. He understood the need to compensate those people who might have lost from the reforms and the need to support those in the community who are without power.

The other thing that perhaps has not been much remarked on is the fact that he was a true internationalist, whether in relation to trade or to disarmament. He understood the need to spread the globe’s wealth. He was acutely aware of poverty and the suffering of others. I remember having a discussion with him about HIV, retrovirals and the fact that a lot of the big pharmaceutical companies were very reluctant to allow their intellectual property to be diminished by providing such drugs to the Third World. He argued very strongly in favour of that move. As we have heard, he was also a strong supporter of international disarmament.

Something that I discovered in making some inquiries today, as I was not aware of it, is that he understood the problems of resource depletion. As Minister for Resources he really did come to terms with the fact that there are limited resources. He also understood the problems of environmental degradation. The initiatives on salinity that he was responsible for and the attempt to reverse the damage to the Murray-Darling Basin are the basis for the work being done today; indeed, I think he was impatient with the fact that not nearly enough progress was being made.

He made an unparalleled contribution to the ‘children overboard’ inquiry, as it has become known, conducted by the Senate Select Committee on A Certain Maritime Incident. We have also heard about his recent contribution to cancer support in the inquiry by the Senate Community Affairs References Committee that was to mark the end of his parliamentary career. I do hope that those responsible take up many of the recommendations of that committee. I for one have seen far too many people struggle with cancer.

I simply want to say, rather than going through the details of his career, that Peter was always a man of unfailing good humour and considerable wit. He was someone with whom you would always enjoy having a conversation. He was a generous, unassuming man. He never measured his friendship. He was not the sort of person to look over your shoulder to see who in the room might be more important. He was generous to a fault, and I certainly had reason to notice that when I had difficulties of my own. I want to pass on my sincere condolences to Barbara, to his children and to their extended family. I know how difficult this period has been for them with Peter’s extended and very painful illness. I know that they will miss him in ways that we cannot imagine, but I hope that they will be somewhat comforted by the fact that so many people had so much regard for him and his work.

talk.start.para: —Serving 22 years in the national parliament is a long, long time by any measure and in anyone’s language, but for those who travel from the west and back again on a regular basis I think it is an enormous period of time. The pressure it puts on the physical wellbeing and on the family unit is something that can only really be contemplated by those who have endured that trek backwards and forwards. So Peter Cook’s commitment to public life in Canberra was very much a physical one but, more important than that, it was an intellectual one. As so many speakers before me have said, few people could match the intellectual contribution in this place of one former senator: Peter Cook.

speech.para: Peter and I probably had more in common than he realised, and I regret in a sense that I had not ever at any time discussed that with him. You think of these things too late. Like Peter, I was a tradesman, someone who left school at a relatively young age, keen to do a trade and to work with my hands. Like Peter, I know that it is an experience that I would never relinquish. I remain proud of my time in my trade and the real life experiences it delivered to me and the way in which that contributed to the development of my being and personality. I know that Peter would say the same thing of his own experiences. Peter was a rebel in a sense, and I consider myself a nonconformist from time to time. Peter always stood up for what he believed in, which were always those things that conformed with Labor principles, and I like to think that I do the same thing. At the same time, like me, he understood that times change and that the way in which Labor ceased to successfully implement its principles changed, as the world changes. I am sure that Peter would agree that he saw it that way as well. His strict adherence to Labor tradition and Labor Party policy and principles will, of course, go unchallenged.

I would like tonight to briefly speak for a few people who are not here that I know would like to make a contribution to this condolence debate—all of them colleagues of Peter Cook and two of them former cabinet colleagues. The first is Paul Keating, who I know had a very high regard for Peter Cook and considered him a valued part of his government. The second is Laurie Brereton, who of course also shared a time in the cabinet with Peter Cook and who I know valued his friendship very strongly. I know they have their own opportunities to express their sympathies to Peter’s family, but I know that they would appreciate being acknowledged as people who were very close to Peter Cook over those many years.

The third is Mark Latham, the former Leader of the Opposition, who again, I know, like me and so many in this place, developed a very high regard and respect for Peter Cook in the period in which he was in this place. I know the feelings were mutual, and I know that Peter Cook saw in Mark Latham great potential and that he was very supportive of Mark’s work in this place. I know that Mark would want to acknowledge Peter Cook’s wise counsel, advice and guidance in the period when Mark Latham was leader of the party in this place.

Peter Cook spent most of his life working in the interests of others not only in this place but, prior to that, as an active member of the trade union movement. Ironic is not the right word, but it is typical of Peter Cook that he spent his last months with us working for those who would follow him, working in support of those who will face the challenges posed by that terrible disease we have not really come to terms with and which, in a generic form, we describe as cancer.

Like so many other people in this place, I feel very pleased to have known Peter Cook, to have been a colleague of Peter Cook and to have been a friend of Peter Cook. I was speaking at a local ALP branch meeting just yesterday when I moved a motion asking the branch to acknowledge the great contribution of Peter Cook and to express its sympathy on the occasion of his passing. I made the point there that you meet many people in politics, many and varied in their personalities and many and varied in their depth of contribution to public debate, but that those that really stand out are those who demand silence when they speak. Everyone knew that when Peter Cook wanted to say something he indeed had something to say and all would quickly listen very carefully. I think that is a very important measure of the regard in which he was held in this place and in wider circles, and we will miss him very dearly.

I regret the way in which he departed this place. I thought it was unfortunate, given the contribution he had made. In many senses I know that that was retribution for certain actions he took out of a determination to achieve the wider good of the Australian Labor Party. In many senses, that will stand for a long time as a dark mark against my own party, but we move on from that. He will be much more remembered for the wonderful things he did for the party and the wonderful things he did for his wider community, and we will miss him dearly.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 5 September 2005:

item.para: On what date was application No. 1063 by Novartis—Photodynamic Therapy for Verteporfin (Visudyne) for Subfoveal choroidal neovasculanisations—received by the Medical Services Advisory Committee.
On what date did the Medical Services Advisory Committee (a) meet and consider the application 1063 and (b) advise Novartis that its application was unsuccessful.
What were the reasons for the delay in advising Novartis that its application was unsuccessful.
Was the application processed within the normal processing time.
What steps were taken by the Medical Services Advisory Committee during the assessment stage of the application to communicate any concerns with Novartis.
Has Novartis submitted an application to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) for Verteprofin to be listed on the PBS; if so, when will the PBAC make a decision on this application.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Application No. 1063 was received by the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) secretariat on 1 November 2002.

item.label: (a)
item.para: MSAC met and considered the application on 19 November 2003.

item.label: (b)
item.para: the MSAC provides recommendations to the Minister for Health and Ageing on whether public funding should be supported for a new technology or procedure. The Minister for Health and Ageing advised Novartis of his decision on 11 March 2005.

Following an MSAC recommendation the department makes a submission to the Minister for Health and Ageing that includes policy advice. This review was complex and presented a number of policy issues which the department needed to consider thoroughly in providing advice.

MSAC’s assessment of this technology was completed in 13 months which is at the lower end of assessment timeframes. The continuing dialogue between the department and the Minister on the MSAC recommendation, policy options and correspondence from Novartis to continue interim funding, extended the decision making process.
MSAC had no concerns regarding this assessment.

Novartis has prepared a submission to list Verteprofin on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme for consideration by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). This submission is currently under consideration by the PBAC.

item.para: The Australian Government is providing $6 million over three financial years from 2004/05 - to Tourism Tropical North Queensland and Townsville Enterprise - to develop the Great Green Way Loop Discovery Drive Project.
Payment is being made in six instalments - two per financial year. To date three payments totalling $2,900,800 (plus GST) have been made to the project proponents.

There has been no delay in the provision of the funding - all payments have been made in accordance with the contract between the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources and the project proponents.

The Great Green Way itself has not been extended to include Bowen and Cooktown. In negotiating the project parameters with the designated proponents the concept of a loop drive, centred on the Great Green Way, was embraced - to spread the benefits of the project to all tourism regions in the Tropical North. The Loop extends from Townsville in the south, west to Charters Towers, north west to Lynd Junction, north through the Atherton Tablelands and on to Cooktown, then south through the Daintree to Cairns and down the coast to Townsville via the Great Green Way.
See (3) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 3 November 2005:

quote.para: Did AusAID engage Mr Bill Nicol as a Strategic Management Adviser at a cost of $381,700; if so, (a) what services were provided under the terms of this contract and (b) why was it necessary to engage a consultant rather than using AusAID staff.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Yes. AusAID has engaged Mr Bill Nicol as a Strategic Management Adviser to the Director of the Aceh Agency for Reconstruction (BRR). This Agency was established by the President of Indonesia after the tsunami to oversight and coordinate all donor activities in Aceh. The final cost of Mr Nicol’s contract is $346,116 (including 10% GST and 9% superannuation).

item.label: (a)
item.para: Mr Nicol was contracted to provide advice and support to the Director of the BRR and his team and to build capacity in the following areas: business policy and strategy; organisational culture and governance; management systems and practices; program design and delivery and issues management and communication.

item.label: (b)
item.para: AusAID does not possess the expertise required for this position within the Agency. As per standard practise a suitable expert was therefore contracted to provide these services to the BRR. Mr Nicol has the requisite skills to undertake this work. All reports from the Director of the BRR indicate the services provided by Mr Nicol are of a high standard.
